cons: A&B has the healthiest work environment I've enjoyed throughout my career. I would have liked the opportunity to begin working with them earlier.

pros: None. Wait, the building is nice and in a nice area.
cons: This company doesn't care about its employees, AT ALL. However if you like free lunches over sustainable compensation, or the billionaire owners come to the company to visit tell you the company is in great financial condition and don't worry about your jobs to then lay off over 50% of the company a week later w/ no notice or severance package then this is the company for you!

title: Things Could Have Been Better!
pros: They take a chance on those with no mortgage background. Everyone is very helpful when they can be. Some departments had the flexibility to work from home. It was typically very easy to take time off when you needed it.
cons: Hard to get promoted. There's a lack of transparency with what is going on with the company behind closed doors. it's hard to get promoted, especially if your are good in your roll. Can be extremely over-worked. HR isn't very helpful when it comes to employee concerns. There aren't any people of color in Executive Level Management, actually there wasn't but a couple of POC in management at all. There's no diversity & inclusion team, no team building - many of us worked in the office together but had no idea who one-another was as me only sat in one section over from one another.

title: Perpetually Toxic Environment
pros: Some employees (Mostly sales) gets bonuses.
cons: A perpetually toxic work environment with constant back stabbing and finger pointing between teams. Management is oblivious to this festering culture and in some areas contribute to its continuation. There is no upward mobility in the company. Most of the time you will just be moved into an equal paying job with no bonus structure and they will call it a promotion. CEO only cares about his sales reps. Every other member of the company could leave and be replaced (Which he has made happen before) and he would never notice anyone was missing.

title: This Company Laid-Off Staff w/No Notice - Employees were Blindsided
pros: The leadership provided lunch for employees on the last 2-business days of the month.
cons: Angel Oak Mortgage Solutions laid-off most of it's workforce in Atlanta on March 24, 2020, in the middle of the Coronavirus COVD-19 global pandemic, with no advanced notice given to employees. Employees were told that they would only be paid through that day, March 24, 2020. I was completely blind-sided by the insensitivity and lack of concern for employees and their families by the Angel Oak leadership team.

title: Very disorganized organization but good experience
pros: Got good experience in manual /Non QM underwriting (valued when going to other positions) Lunch paid for twice a month Was lucky I had a great manager
cons: Where to start lol - can be very stressful. Loans are complicated and can take hours to underwrite. I am lucky I an a naturally fast learner and can teach myself because they kind of throw you to the wolves and it is not the easiest learning how to manually do everything and with their system High stress enviornment - conditions could take as long as a new loan. You were constantly swamped when it was busy. Also if you had a bad underwriting assistant then you work could double. Luckily i had great ones The AEs are brutal and most of them are cutthroat. Wont accept a no for an answer and will go over you to get a yes. The annoying part is - sometimes management caved to them and you would be put in uncomfortable position of approving something you would not sign your name to Hours could be long and even when you take time off you could almost not enjoy it because leading up to it you had to make sure all your loans were mostly taken care of - otherwise people would moan and whine about it when you came back. Also when i said that i liked to leave work for hour lunch ppl laughed and said you’ll quickly leanr you cant here. They were right - after training - i never left the office for lunch during my entire time there. I had lunch at my desk because it was the only way to finish your work Benefits were not great compared to what you had to pay and pto was nothing special either

title: Toxic corporate work environment
pros: Free snacks and drinks every day when in office, lots of Brandywine branded swag, good health benefits, some great people to work with, huge budget for projects.
cons: The work environment at the company is characterized by a pervasive culture of competitiveness, where personal advancement often takes precedence over ethical conduct. Interactions with colleagues are marred by an ulterior motive to extract information that can be later used against individuals. Furthermore, the marketing department is overseen by managers lacking design expertise, leading to a lack of understanding regarding project complexities and time requirements for designers. Employees are unfortunately treated as expendable resources due to the abundance of job applications received. The marketing department witnesses a high turnover rate, except for upper management, who remain insulated from these changes. Attempts to address the excessive workload have been met with dismissive responses, fostering a tense atmosphere in the office. Interpersonal conflicts are rampant within the department, exacerbated by the exclusivity of decision-making among a select few individuals. Until the company acknowledges and acts upon the feedback provided, particularly concerning the need for a manager with a design background who can advocate for the designers, this cycle of high turnover is likely to persist. Unfortunately, the current project manager has not demonstrated the willingness or ability to fulfill this role. Additionally, the company does not prioritize the mental well-being of its employees, focusing primarily on meeting deadlines and discouraging expressions of concern. It is imperative for the company to reevaluate its management approach, fostering a supportive and inclusive environment that values the contributions and mental health of its workforce.

title: BDN review
pros: Great work-life balance; company has early closing on Fridays during the summer and also before most national holidays. This gives employees the opportunity to get a head-start to the holidays, especially if they need to travel.
cons: No clear path to advancing within company. Being a lean real estate company, with low employee turn-over, sometimes it feels as though there's no clear path to taking on leadership roles within company. You more or less have to wait till senior people move on, which does not happen often. If it does happen, it may be at a location that is not convenient.

title: Waspy and Plastic
pros: The office is beautiful and some departments are great.
cons: In accounting it is a toxic working environment. The workload is unreasonable and you are expected to work late everyday as well as on weekends and while on vacation or leave. Office politics are heavy and so workload is distributed unevenly and they suffer from being severely understaffed. As a result the turnover rate is incredibly high. When things go wrong there is no accountability from management and the blame is often unfairly shifted. There is also a 'firing culture' unlike anything I've ever seen. Anything bad that happens they sweep under the rug and because of the culture people are too afraid to speak up. It really is a nightmare workplace. Steer clear of accounting. There are so many other great places to work in Philadelphia, don't choose this one.

As more companies place more emphasis on their employees, this one says they are but they’re not actually doing anything to improve the employee experience.

title: This is hands down the best company I have ever worked for.
pros: Here’s the updated review incorporating your new points: 5 Stars - The Best Employer I’ve Worked For Starting with CBL 9 months ago has been one of the best career decisions I’ve ever made. After 22 years in the industry and working with countless management companies (many of which left much to be desired), I was blown away by how different CBL truly is. Their vetting process was extensive and, though it was intense, you could tell they were on the right path and committed to finding the best fit for their team. From the very beginning, it was clear that they take the time to know their people and ensure they’re making the right decisions for both the company and the employee. From day one, CBL has exceeded my expectations. The interviews were engaging and professional, and it was apparent they do things the right way. Their commitment to excellence shines in every aspect of the organization, from onboarding to competitive pay and generous benefits. At the same time, CBL expects the same level of dedication and work ethic from its employees. But that’s easy to deliver when you work for a company that genuinely supports you, values your input, and stands behind your decisions. The work is challenging—this is not a company for slackers—but it’s rewarding. About a month ago, when the mall I worked at went on the market and was sold, I was initially devastated. Typically, when a mall changes ownership, the staff either transitions to the new owners or is left in a precarious position. After only 8 months in my role, I feared losing CBL as my employer. However, I reached out to HR to express my interest in staying with the company, and to my surprise and gratitude, they went above and beyond to retain me. Despite being new, they recognized my situation and offered to transfer me to a mall in another state. This level of care and support is something I’ve never experienced with a management company. The benefits CBL provides are incredible—almost entirely employer-paid, generous paid time off, and an exceptional work-life balance. The management team is phenomenal, with centuries of combined experience, and my boss is hands-down amazing. The pay is on the higher end of the spectrum, if not the highest, and everyone I’ve worked with LOVES this company. It’s no wonder employees stay for 20+ years. In fact, I’ve heard of many who left to try other companies, only to return months later because the grass is simply not greener on the other side. This review is completely unsolicited—I’m writing it because I feel compelled to share how great this company is. If you are top talent, this is a company you must work for. As long as you do your job, they will always show up with your check and have your back. CBL is, without a doubt, the best company I’ve worked for. I trust and value my coworkers implicitly—they’re not only great people but also immensely talented in their fields. I couldn’t ask for a better employer or a better team.
cons: None-- and I love to complain

title: Outdated HR Policies
pros: Opportunity to grow within the company, great co-workers
cons: HR policies when I was there were terribly outdated. ALL employees received ZERO vacation days for their first year of employment (no, that is not a typo). I do hope that has changed since.

title: Quality People Quality Company
pros: This company offers excellent opportunities for professional development and growth, supported by a team of great people in a public organization.
cons: Some properties have considerable potential for growth, requiring attention.

title: A company highly invested in its employees
pros: - You will be working with a team of supportive individuals - You will be encouraged to follow & build upon your strengths - CBL & Associates has a strong history of investing in its employees & their success - Excellent Work/Life Balance
cons: - No cons have been encountered during my time here.

title: Great company to work for!
pros: Overall amazing company to work for!
cons: Working at a satelite office can have more variablility than the home office

title: Disconnect
pros: Fun in the beginning, then too many layoffs
cons: Home office does not understand or connect with the field

title: Admin Assistant
pros: Great Team, work hours, and pay-including PTO.
cons: No cons- I enjoyed my job.

title: Great place to work
pros: Management in shared service was supportive and seemed to really care about employees. Fair pay as well as fair workload.
cons: I don't have any cons to list.

title: No balance
pros: great co-workers in the department
cons: no life-work balance. lots of overtime work and top management has no appreciation of accountants

title: Great Place to Work
pros: Super nice people that give you the autonomy to do your job.
cons: Pay is not the best

title: A Truly Great Place to Work
pros: A strong diverse executive team has led the company to be a fun and rewarding experience. This company is not static and continues to identify ways to grow to meet the needs of its employees.
cons: Management teams are spread thin making things stressful at times.

pros: People are the best part
cons: Low salary. Promote only favorites.

title: Senior Management Not intouch
pros: It's a job, lower level employees very friendly
cons: Upper Level Management was so removed from Mall Level Managemnt. Pressure was on cut back. Cut backs are fine as long as you have place to cut back we did not. HR upper level management was not approachable. They hired diversity management company and you had to conform. I would never work for CBL. Go to their competitors. They treat us better.

title: Outdated HR Policies
pros: Gained a lot of experience.
cons: Outdated HR policies that I hope have changed since I was there. Zero weeks of vacation for the first year of employment and ONE week of vacation for the second year, regardless of experience.

title: Many good people, management at the top is exceptionally disconnected.
pros: There are some fabulous people that work at this company. If you're lucky to have a strong boss, you'll be shielded from much of the nonsense that goes on and actually be able to be productive and have individual growth.
cons: Corporate is clueless and quite disorganized. There are distinct cliques and "favorites" and a resistance to inclusion on many levels. I was actually at meetings where there was not a single female speaker featured and there was an exceptional celebration of sports coaches from Utah and of sports in general (I don't mind sports, but when that is ALL that is featured, it gets old). They will tout how important family is, however, they have no compunction about forcing work/travel on weekends without giving any comp time in exchange, which is just silly. I truly feel that the only reason one of the larger developers haven't done a take over of this company is that it would be too much work to sell the 50 ugly properties in order to secure the 15 solid ones and the 25 so-so ones. The IT department has a stranglehold and will actually actively discourage or tell VP level managers no to simple requests because they are quite convinced that they'll be hacked. And if you'd like to have a career path there - good luck. There is minimal opportunity for growth.

title: CBL Properties
pros: CBL offers much corporate support
cons: CBL does not offer remote roles

title: Loved my experience with CBL!
pros: Tight-knit teams, family-like atmosphere, good benefits, opportunity for growth
cons: We used Microsoft teams - haha!

title: Great company to work for
pros: This job has plenty of opportunities to grow!
cons: There are some mandatory holidays to work

title: Your experience depends on who you report to.
pros: Great field level team Flexibility when needed
cons: High pressure Pay isn't always competitive

title: When it's good, it's all good, but when it's bad-look out!
pros: They are a very family oriented company. They have great relationships within the company. I feel like I have been compensated very generously.
cons: They focus too much on ROI! They need to extinguish the realtionship with ERMC that is slowly sucking the life out of our properties. Everyone rushes to make everything look pretty when we have a property review when in reality the property has their hands locked and not able to do what it takes to make the property look nice and run smoothly through out the year. Some regionals seldom visit properties and dont offer the help that we need. U feel like you are own your own! They promote people to higher positions that people in the field know of significant wrongs they have made yet go unnoticed. It's like if you click with them, your automatically in! There has been times, us in the field has sat begging for help and would get no emails, no nothing back-we would start working with each other because of no responses, yet this person got promoted?? I've seen too many times, regionals start with a project only for it to get dropped by the waist side!

title: Great Place to Work
pros: Company pulled through bankruptcy + Covid and has positioned itself for the future. Great team of hardworking people, and executives who actually care.
cons: Outdated pto + leave policies, no room for advancement outside of Chattanooga

pros: Well established retail REIT. Good people Decent place to get some fundamental experience.
cons: Nepotism at its finest. Just look at leadership masthead. Conservative in development and redevelopment possibilities and very slow to change. This has almost cost them everything. Their heyday was in 70s-early 2000. The last 20 years has been denial of changing consumer and retail needs. Lack of opportunities. Many good and talented people left especially if not from Chattanooga. If local it’s one of very few public employers in town (the only Real Estate) Employees know that and so does company, so many stay because it’s the only thing around.

title: I did not work at CBL/Columbia Place in 2015, I was RIFED in September 2004?
pros: Being able to work and interact in positive manner with office and home office personnel, store owners and managers Responsibilities included making sure payable's, receivables, balancing check books, processing internal income were done in timely manner. Interaction with office personnel store owners/managers, customers, home office personnel.
cons: Their lack of appreciation for loyalty, hard work, extra hours worked to accomplish their goals. Their lack of belief in long time productive employees over short term, lower paid, employee, ie: RIF the higher paid employee with 25 years of service, keep the three year less knowledgeable of company and policy.

title: Fundamentally "ok"...but needs so much help.
pros: Overall good group of people to work with.
cons: Out of touch upper managment. Severe nepitism. A multi-billion dollar company that is run like a mom & pop developer. Outdated business model and unwilling (or unable) to adapt to a very competitive environment. Low salaries, ridiculous PTO.

title: Nice People, Disorganized
pros: Some of the nicest people work for this company. Really they are friendly and kind, but also a disorganized mess.
cons: They micro manage the staff, but have no clear training, so it makes it very difficult to do a good job. Odd policies, and no guidance, you have to assume that the person telling you what to do is correct. If they spent half as much time actually communicating as they spend talking about communicating it would be a great company.

title: Well respected company, it's a facade
pros: Some good working relationships Opportunities to move around Casual days
cons: Very reactive environment, no looking ahead The work load is chaotic, there is no chance of getting caught up The gossip culture is toxic It's who you know, if you want to get promoted CEO gets a 34% raise while the workforce is lucky to get 1% 'we've always done it this way' mindset runs rampant Let's not forget the constant Flux of lawsuits

title: Could Be Better
pros: Decent pay and benefits.
cons: Management needs to modernize; still operates like it's 80's and has little to no insight how to treat good employees. Everyone really wants to do their best, but management only knows how the find and focus on things [it] finds wrong. There is no appreciation for going above and beyond . There is little to zero training in anything, it's sink or swim. The first 8 months was the most miserable time of my life. Direct managers seemed to enjoy tearing you down instead of building you up and never had anything encourage to say...EVER!

title: Children at the helm. Literally.
pros: Benefits are ok. Company appears to be financially sound.
cons: Top down culture. Input from the field is not solicited. Bullies abound. Company is strictly driven by Return on Investment. Work environment stessful.

title: My experience has been good but strained as the job is not what I enterviewed for - deceived.
pros: CBL is a family owned business and has a family philosophy. Employees work hard but family life is respected and time with family is honored in my department.
cons: Not very flexible on schedules for most part and old fashioned ideas about dress code..no denim even on casual days. In reference to technology, somewhat behind...still using Lotus Notes. Some departments lack the manpower needed and employees are exploited.

title: Love the people, culture could improve
pros: Good insurance, good location. Most of the people who work there are great people.
cons: IT staff is underpaid and underappreciated. Little room for professional growth. CBL prefers to hire outside the company rather than promote from within. Those who do get ahead are those who don't mind stepping on others. It can be difficult knowing who to trust. Many workers are unhappy.

title: Great people, just not so great at business
pros: Excellent coworkers, pay was competitive and earning bonuses was very easy. Lots of autonomy and each day was new and exciting. Never a dull moment.
cons: Lots of people in leadership positions who weren’t knowledgeable and/or earned their position via suspect means. Lots of favoritism. If you shared an opinion, you were deemed as “not a term player”. Management didn’t want to hear the truth; they want everything sugar-coated. Little to no room for advancement.

title: Great company for professional development
pros: Open door policy creates for a collaborative and nurturing environment. This is a great company to learn and grow with professionally.
cons: Behind on the times. They have a weak portfolio due to unfortunate locations but also due to lack of creativity to adapt in a rapidly changing retail landscape. Company is also predominately made up of white males and not the best place for women or POC.

title: A great company with great leadership
pros: - Opportunities for advancement and growth - Personable and reasonable leadership - More casual and friendly than some corporate environments - My supervisors went beyond being bosses, and took the time to be mentors and friends
cons: - No true cons. Every workplace will have it's little nuances, depending on your personality and needs, and the same holds true here.

title: Amazing coworkers!
pros: The people at CBL made it a great place to work! Enjoyed the opportunities for growth and how upper management followed an open door policy. Solid benefits and pay was fair.
cons: Slow to make decisions and execute changes to established business procedures; outdated technology in some departments; few vacation days when you first begin

title: Nepotism Reigns
pros: Large publicly traded company. National presence. Large portfolio>
cons: Company run by one family. Key positions held by family members despite not being qualified. Family members are grossly over compensated. Worst benefits package imaginable. Employees are not valued for their input. Very patriarchal. Need to kiss butt if you want to survive.

title: No more for growth and you are their slaves.
pros: Professional environment only in dress code, great health benefits, reasonable pay
cons: Gossip environment, working OT with no compensation, highly stressful, no room for growth, not a friendly environment, Lebovitz arrogant

title: It’s a stepping stone at best
pros: - Decent work/life balance. - Ample PTO policy when you’ve been there a while. - Some really decent people that work there.
cons: - No room for growth. There is no where to go for career movement. - Questionable pays scale. Raises are NOT performance based. It’s a set amount for anyone doing the bare minimum and up.

title: Leasing Manager
pros: CBL is very involved in the community, and encourages a work-life balance for it's employees while providing opportunities to grow.
cons: Location. Chattanooga is not a convenient location for those who have to travel often to meet with clients. CBL is also too conservative at times when it comes to investing in change -such as with new computer software.

title: Good money--disrespectful management.
pros: nice office, good standard of living in Chattanooga, rewarded for results.
cons: Management is run like a frat, and they like to publicly humiliate employees that make mistakes.

title: Overworked underpaid
pros: Great learning environment Room for advancement Great single benefits One day of dress down a week Every couple months they pay for your lunch one day Flexible schedule HR is amazing
cons: Underpaid Management puts too much feelings in conversations Upper management pushes too fast to actually Implement anything Many jobs for little pay Benefits for family is way expensive

title: General Manager
pros: CBL has some very talented people working at their properties. Good benefits, health, vision and dental.
cons: Corporate Office disconnected with field staff. Demand unrealistic goals constantly pushing you to do more! Threatening tactics at times. Too many VPs, good old boys club!

title: Good 'Ol Boy Company

cons: Difficult to Promote. Pay is not good for Admin Personnel. Male employees get 95% of the Mall Mgr positions. The company needs a complete redo, they are behind the times. Lacks in Diversity.

title: A sinking ship
pros: Good people and work life balance. Chattanooga is a great city with lots to do.
cons: Retail industry is struggling although Company has made plans to change and redevelop, it all takes time. Several executives way past retirement age. Recent layoffs and wage freezes.

title: general manager
pros: great people, could set own schedule , pretty much ran the property

title: No title

pros: Some of the the people in mall environment were great.

cons: Large, publicly traded corporation still run by a small family and few decision makers. Top-down culture, very slow dinosaur-like growth & initiatives. Refuse to spend money and compensate employees accordingly.

pros: They have a great conference once a year for the Assistant General Managers, but other than that the communication within the company is terrible.
cons: There is no room for growth in the company. There is a lot of pressure to perform in your role, but the support is not there from upper management. Raises have not been given in over 4 years and commissions have been cut in half for 4 years.

pros: Nice company. Boss is awesome.
cons: There were no cons here.

title: Good people, old school mindset

cons: old school with limited flexibility for work life balance fully in office

title: Cog in the machine
pros: Steady work, easy to be efficient within couple months
cons: Poor work home balance, meetings upon meetings, lots of blackout days that they disapprove taking PTO

title: Decent Company
pros: Good team members, benefits are okay but nothing to brag about.
cons: Slow salary movement, cost of living adjustment not equivalent to actual inflation. Lots of turnover.

title: Stay away if you can...
pros: Great pay for salaried employees. Subpar pay for hourly admin folks.
cons: HR does not care about you at all. High end management doesn't care either. Everything is very USA political at the top...I have seen folks get fired for reporting harassment...like come on.

title: Good place to work.
pros: Learn a lot. Benefit package is very nice
cons: Micromanaging of lower employees. Management doesn’t always listen to employees

title: Great company
pros: I've been here 15 years, great company, great environment
cons: Long drive, wish it was closer to my house

title: Dream job but nightmare manager. Was never truly part of the team.
pros: The salary was good, but I had to play a lot of hardballs to get what I got. Looking back, I should have asked for more.
cons: Management is a roll of the dice, and I got snake eyes. My manager constantly criticized me and never gave me anything productive to help me meet their expectations. Super stressful work environment and depending on your department you will be treated like an outsider. HQ is not a place for BIPOC unless you are older and prepared to do a bunch of brown-nosing. You must keep your head down, smile, and dance for your teams/ managers. I had a controlling manager that hindered me instead of helping with workflow. What I was promised in a manager and in my job description was not what the actual position entailed. The CEO walks around the office to check on employees constantly throughout the day and will comment if someone is out of the office or working remotely. When you are new, be prepared to have no work/life balance. And it still may not be enough to keep you there.

title: Arrogant Manager's Misogynistic Attitude: Creating Toxic Work Environment
pros: One of the things I appreciated most about working for this company is the level of flexibility it offers. As long as we deliver our work on time and to the required standards, we are trusted to manage our time and work at our own pace.
cons: The Manager's behavior has been consistently displaying attributes of an individual who holds misogynistic views. Their arrogance and condescending behavior towards women in the workplace are not only unprofessional but also deeply problematic. Moreover, their management style appears to be unsustainable as it creates a toxic work environment that can lead to high turnover rates and low employee morale.

title: Strong company
pros: Good culture, and allows for growth
cons: Value is king, and family feel has faded over time.

title: Good company, pay was not the greatest
pros: Employee oriented and good environment
cons: Not so much money. Wish they’d offer more

title: Good Job
pros: Director of the site does a good job at letting Building Technicians do their jobs. Like most of the people that work for my company. Pay for position and clearance bonusis a lot lower than other companies offer around the area; but have vested 12 yrs and accrue vac/sick leave at large rate.
cons: Director of South regions mi ro manages the site I work on, very annoying. The Director of the site is very smart and sometimes over analyze things. Expectations of the small amount of technicians to get all the PMs done in time is unrealistic. No training. Shifts rotate every 4 weeks

title: Everyone from corporate to management is corrupt
pros: Low risk of losing your job because they are terrible at hiring new people.
cons: Everyone from corporate to management is corrupt. The compensation plan is changed at the drop of a hat to benefit the company and screw the employees. Some managers are incredibly inappropriate with employees. They care about their bottom line more than their employees and more than their customers. You work your butt off for pennies and are micromanaged by people who should not be in supervising roles. Overall, this is not the place to go if you are serious about just about anything long-term.

title: Work-Life Balance
pros: The people across departments are nice to work with.
cons: They talk about work-life balance but for some departments it is only talk. They prefer you to constantly work to keep caught up. Even if this means you work evenings or weekends.

title: solid job
pros: corporate, lots of comfort there
cons: truction manager

title: Stepping stone
pros: Company benefits, most employees are competent
cons: Communication from your management Career growth is non-existent unless you have connections

title: Sad to see what it became
pros: I made long term friendships with the other techs and tenants. Vacation policy was good.
cons: COPT was a unique employer when I started and heavily focused on customer service and providing to the tenant. Multiple CEOs later and it became a shell of itself on past reputation and instead become a paper company focused on hitting metrics and accounting at the expense of the tenant. Highly political company. Do more with less became the norm. No clear vision on moving forward and morale was at its lowest when I finally moved on. No defined training plan for the maintenance folks or opportunity for growth left at the mercy of your chief tech. Major disconnect between HQ and the field. Management operated in sillos.

title: Run away from COPT!
pros: They do have excellent benefits, time off, and events.
cons: They are NOT family friendly. Although they give you plenty of time off, they question every single time you take off and give you a hard time. The mentality is very "corporate squared" and they love to micro-manage. Specifically the marketing department is a ROYAL MESS. They lack project management, organizational strategies, they have 0 knowledge of what it takes to develop material for the company and the management hierarchy is completely off. It is a nest of gossip! They will rip apart a coworker for the stupidest things. If I would have known how awkward and unorganized, I would have never worked for them! They've had two people in a row walk out on them... that means something! Do yourself a favor and keep scrolling past their job postings.

title: Used to be a great company
pros: The long time employees who are still there are good people. Flexible work arrangements.
cons: 3 CEO's in 6 years and numerous reorganizations have caused this company to lose its family feel. The customer, which used to be the number 1 priority, has been pushed behind the shareholders and stock price. Cost cutting and doing more with less is the new norm. Many of the "old guard" leadership has been purged and new management don't share original values.

title: Terrible communication by the top management
pros: I would not like to lie here and mention anything here. The overall experience was pretty bad. You can stay away
cons: THE TOP MANAGEMENT WAS TERRIBLE AT COMMUNICATION. THEY DIDN'T COMMUNICATE IMPORTANT STUFF, AND HALF OF IT GOT LOST SOMEWHERE. IT CREATED CHAOS AND UNWANTED COMMUNICATION GAPS that could have been east to avoid. It was awful! THE SALARY AND GROWTH OPTIONS WEREN'T TOO GOOD EITHER. YOU CN TAKE TONS OF WORK STRESS, WORK TO THE POINT OF EXHAUSTION AND WORK BRUTAL HOURS FOR NOTHING. IT WAS RIDICULOUS!

title: Fantastic to work for
pros: Great work life balance! Clear paths for advancement, fantastic benefits, upper management is accessible and open to all employee opinions, criticism etc
cons: I don’t have many complaints. Working on property management means you have to be available to the tenant when they need it. However the company is very good at compensating time spent when that happens.

title: The constant fear and intimidation tactics used by them created a culture of mistrust
pros: The cleanliness and organization of the office contributed to a positive and productive atmosphere. The modern amenities and ergonomic furniture made it a pleasure to work in.
cons: This terrible company had a toxic work environment, where the well-being and job satisfaction of employees were not a priority for the CEO and management. The constant fear and intimidation tactics used by them created a culture of mistrust, and the constant lies, and deceit made it clear that they had no regard for their employees.

title: COPT
pros: COPT is truly a great company to work for. Professional and friendly atmosphere. Beautiful and clean working environment. The benefits are amazing and they are the best I've ever experienced. Flexible hours and ability to work remotely if needed. Quarterly Earning calls to keep you informed on the growth of the business and regular departmental meetings to keep you working together as a team and keep you engaged.
cons: There are no downsides to working with this company.

title: Most toxic culture I've ever beem a part of.
pros: If you get into the right department with the right bunch of people, then it's a great place to work.
cons: Without a doubt the most toxic culture I've ever been a part of Leadership is unhelpful, condescending and greedy. They promote people with big egos and presonality issues. Unless you are willing to play the games and pretend to buy into the BS you will quickly find you are boxed into a group or position with no chance of leaving. I feel bad for the kind and hard working people that are still there and suffering. Avoid this company at all costs.

title: Clerical Assistant
pros: Exceptional design and cleanliness to the Columbia office building. The CEO there at the time Mr. Griffin was very personable, smart and diligent.
cons: This was by far my worst job ever. I was offered a job as a low-level clerical assistant working with the two teams, the legal department and investments team. This was my first full time job straight out of college and I absolutely dreaded coming to work everyday. I would go weeks without seeing my manager for the investments team, so many worked and assisted the legal team. The assist I worked under was the executive assistant to the VP of Legal and she did nothing but all day but suck up to her boss while talking about her behind her back and boss me around. She treated me very awful, and would raise her voice to me over little things I did wrong to the point where I would go home crying every day. But, at the same time I felt bad for her because she would be treated twice as as worse by the VP, so most days I let it go. The remaining members of the legal team I worked under were extremely pretentious, rude and unprofessional. I left after only 6 months of being employed there and I decided to resign after I met with my two bosses VP of Legal and VP of Investments for my three month performance evaluation, which conveniently took place 5 months into my employment. At that time they decided to advise me that my performance was subpar and I was taking too much time off from work, mind you I had braces on at that time and needed to visit the Orthodontist pretty often. They explained I was negative and rude to my counterparts, and at that time they were probably right because I had had enough with my coworkers yelling at me and treating me that way. Needless to say I finally got out, six months too long. I’ve had several jobs since that one and no other job I’ve ever been in has ever come close to how bad this one was.

title: The daily struggles were real, and exhausting!

Working more than 12 hours a day doesn't seem enough for our manager and looks us as if we're lazy and lack dedication for our work! It's RIDICULOUS!

title: A Truly Exceptional Place to Work – Where Passion Meets Purpose
pros: - Supportive Leadership: Management genuinely cares about employee growth and well-being. Feedback is constructive, and leadership is approachable. - Collaborative Culture: Teamwork is at the heart of everything. Cross-functional collaboration feels natural and energizing. - Growth Opportunities: Clear career paths, regular upskilling sessions, and internal mobility make professional development exciting and achievable. - Innovation-Driven: The company encourages creativity and embraces new ideas. You’re empowered to experiment and contribute meaningfully. - Values That Matter: The mission and values aren’t just words—they’re lived daily. It’s inspiring to be part of something bigger.
cons: - Honestly, it’s hard to find any. If I had to nitpick, maybe the coffee could be stronger—but the energy from the team more than makes up for it!

title: Poor Senior Leadership and Lack of Strategic Direction
pros: Worked with a high-performing, mission-driven recruiting team that consistently delivered results in a high-volume environment. Gained valuable experience leading national initiatives and building programs that had real impact. Strong peer collaboration and camaraderie among frontline recruiters.
cons: Senior leadership within Talent Acquisition lacks trust in their team and consistently fails to lead with strategy or vision. Decisions are reactive, not proactive, and often made without transparency or input from those closest to the work. There is a clear and persistent favoritism toward corporate recruiting teams, despite the high-volume team being responsible for filling the vast majority of roles across the company. Recognition, advancement, and compensation are not aligned with performance. Employees are expected to take on strategic initiatives or larger projects and scope of work with no end date in sight and without formal acknowledgment or pay equity. Concerns raised through appropriate channels were either ignored or met with vague responses, and in some cases, were followed by restructuring decisions that created unnecessary competition and instability. The recent return-to-office policy is rigid and outdated, with little regard for employee well-being or modern workforce expectations.

title: WORST COMPANY EVER
pros: Payed me agreed upon salary.
cons: Told me to prepare for 80 hour work weeks, if I took a break I wasn’t “committed enough” I worked 65 hours during the week and demanded I come in Saturdays as well. But get ready for the busy season. Disorganized chaos. Antiquated WMS. Unhappy workers making 18hr to drive MHE who are punished for not coming in days they never agreed to work. In truth this place is a Logistical nightmare. RUN FAST! IT WONT GET BETTER! Your concerns are relegated to well it looks like HR “dropped the ball” No other answers to the fact you were told your working 40 hours a week and now are expected to double that. Slave culture!

title: Order selector
pros: Different learning experience for sure. Decent pay for staying local.Acknowledging that this offers a different learning experience is important. It is a great chance to build a career and learn the ropes. These factors might make this opportunity an interesting choice.
cons: Seems that alot think negatively of the employer. And they expect alot to be accomplished in less then 5weeks it seems. If you don't from experience they'll terminate you.It appears that many individuals harbor negative perceptions of the employer. The expectations for productivity seem quite high. The timeframe for completing tasks is perceived as unreasonably short. This may be a significant source of stress. It is important for the employer to consider these concerns.

Competitive Benefits - Health insurance, retirement plans, and employee assistance programs are solid compared to industry standards. Innovation & Technology - Automated facilities and advanced systems make work more efficient and future-focused.

title: Close to home
pros: Work is very close to home and my supervisor is probably the best supervisor I’ve ever had. He is very flexible with my hours being i and a single father who has split custody so some days I have to come in late or i am unable to stay late when it’s busy. But he also knows that I will come in in the middle of the night of on the weekends to finish repairs so we have enough truck to get the freight where it needs it to go on time.
cons: Being it it a publicly traded company it is much more difficult to order and stock parts me need to do our jobs. Also tools for the shop that the employer would normally provide either never get purchased or a technician has to refuse to repair a machine/ truck until they have the proper tools for safety reasons. This is not at fault of our shop supervisor but more of the hoops that they would Have to Jump Through to get such purchases approved. Since americold purchased halls warehouses over 2 years ago we still have yet to receive a parts washer so we are forced to use far more brake clean than would be normally used. Not only a waste of money but a hit to employee health and safety. Also understaffing is a huge problem. I have a few friends who I would have apply but the income offers are laughable sometimes. I feel like if you pay good wages you will Get the people who want to work and take pride in it. And you can easily weed out the people who don’t want the money. But It just in our department that is understaffed but everywhere it seems. I have tried numerous times to get my child support payments taken out of payroll before direct deposit with no luck. Even been arrested and released due to this issue. But I also understand that the HR rep that I have has a lot of other people she is responsible for and things slip through the cracks. I do love working here and the people i directly work with but we were promised apt when americold took over like all brand new tools and lunches every month and much more and we haven’t seen any of it. And might I add when corporate reps came around after the acquisition of halls they talked a good game they said we brought each of u a gift… it was hats and water bottles. But they didn’t bring enough for everyone… that right there kinda set the tone. I did receive a raise when they took over which was nice but it was nowhere near what I was offer at other companies 2 years prior coming out of technical school. Like $7-$10 less.

title: Run. Seriously, do not take a job from this employer
pros: Pay is good, with overtime and incentives.
cons: You'll be making that overtime all right. In theory, the deal with the union is that you need to be told before lunch whether you'll have to stay late for mandatory overtime. In practice, they'll tell you every day that they need you for twelve hours, then will "let you leave early" if they don't need you. Also in practice, expect ten to twelve hours a day every day, and mandatory work every weekend. There will be zero life/work balance: your life will be stacking boxes in a freezer.

title: A private equity company has big impact on Americold
pros: Americold has invested heavily in new systems during the last few years. The transition has been difficult and expensive. In the long run, Americold will have a well integrated and competitive operation. There are some good learning opportunities for many people along the way.
cons: A private equity company named Yucaipa calls the shots and Yucaipa is run by billionaire Ron Burkle. The strategy a few years ago was to invest, grow, and go public. The Versacold acquisition added a lot of debt and antiquated systems. The investment was made but the growth didn't follow, in part because of the economy. Going public turned out not to be an option. The management team that initiated and was executing the strategy has been fired or has quit and been replaced by a team that is charged with a strategy of cutting cost, leveraging the company with debt, and returning more profit to Yucaipa. This is why there have been layoffs the last couple of years and a difficult work environment for those that remain. Yucaipa certainly has a right to recoup their investment, but this will be difficult for the employees and customers to handle over the next few years.

title: Mediocrity At Its Best
pros: My co-workers were good people to be around. There was room for growth early on. Tuition reimbursement option is a plus for students.
cons: Leadership has no vision. Leadership cares not about the culture or morale of the employees. Workload is not equivalent to the pay unless you are VP or above, and then the paradigm shifts in the other direction. Appreciation is only communicated in a halfhearted verbal method, and never interprets into pay increases or other benefits. "Merit Increase" program is actually an annual across-the-board cost of living increase. No matter how much merit you bring to the table, you will often see the same increase as some of your lazier and less-motivated counterparts. The Human Resources team is a toxic group with multiple agendas and unchecked power. They are very intrusive, manipulative and controlling. I worked for Americold for more than 5 years, and built tons of good personal relationships - NO ONE LIKES THEIR JOB. I have never heard anyone brag on this company, or defend it when someone else bashes it. The shame of it all is that Americold has the resources and funds to be the absolute best company in the industry, but no one wants to take the time to creatively motivate, incentivize or appreciate the people doing the legwork.

title: Disorganized, poorly managed and behind the times
pros: -Decent pay -Relatively flat management structure -Free parking
cons: -Bare minimum amount of PTO that doesn't roll over if unused. Also only observes the bare minimum of holidays -Terrible health benefits. Expensive, extremely high deductible and very limited in coverage -Americold itself is an amalgamation of a bunch of warehouses and smaller storage firms which were acquired and mashed together by a private equity firm. This has led to understandable growing pains, confusion and inefficiency -The warehouses themselves only started keeping real records a few years ago, so there is NO reliable data available before 2013 or so -The data the company does get is both incomplete and unreliable, though management seems content to act based on bad information -Middle management is aloof and doesn't seem to care about the goings on among regular employees -An overly aggressive HR department makes an already conflict-rich environment even more contentious -Constant turnover among all levels of the hierarchy has left people uneasy. Most everyone has an "exit strategy" -Management is unreceptive to suggestions and complaints -People are fired seemingly at random

title: Average company with alot of transitional turnover
pros: Because of the high turnover rate there is always an oportunity to start on 3rd shift and move to first or second shift. Hourly employees have good benefits as far as paid time off and the ability to work over - time to compensate for the mediocre wage. Health care is good for what you contribute each month.
cons: As a supervisor you are salaried 50 hours a week, this equates to less than an houlry wage of the people you are supervising. Because the headquarters are in Atlanta, I don't feel the company values trickle down to the facilities. Alot of focus is given on customer service, which is great for job security, but the employees are not recognized for the sacrifice. Unless you have obtained a network of friends within the company, you are left on the outside looking in. It is hard to understand what direction the company is headed when people in upper management are coming and going.

title: Management sucks
pros: Supervisor only came once a week
cons: Could never get any help from higher ups wanted everything fixed but didn’t want to spend money on parts

title: Not so great
pros: Can be a lot of overtime
cons: Management is terrible. Treat hard working employees terribly.

pros: Not very many pros I guess
cons: It was just ok very unorganized

title: Good
pros: Good people, good benefits, good times
cons: No cons to really note

title: Stay far away from this company
pros: There are zero pros to working for this company.
cons: No leadership. No training, you have to try to figure it out. If you’re in any supervisor or manager position, they expect you to work from 5am to 10-11pm with no additional compensation. They have a revolving door of temporary workers so they don’t have to invest in hiring anyone. Absolutely terrible employee treatment. Upper management will yell at anyone in front of other staff. Front line employees are treated as expendable and replaceable. Sexual harassment investigations are not followed through with HR, they claim they investigate it but take no action when multiple people are filing claims against the same person. Women are treated as gophers and expected to cater to General Managers on any whim they may have. If you try to take a day off, you are harassed by management and told you are not a “team player”. Then they will call you multiple times on your day off and tell you that you have to come in, or you will get fired - even if you’ve stated that you have consumed alcohol and cannot drive. Personal and confidential employee information is easily accessible, often times it’s left in folders around the office or just thrown in the trash can with no shredding. There is no long term plan for anything. I could go on and on but this is the most toxic work environment I have encountered in 20+ years of working.

title: Disrespect
pros: Lots of OT. As a selector, its a physically challenging work place. Most employees loose 20-30lbs within a few months.
cons: There are too many cons to list, so here's my top three. One can easily hurt themselves in this environment. Slips, trips, and falls are common. The organization lacks the man power to keep the floors clean. Ice cubes are everywhere, and one single ice cube can take you out permanently. Broken open boxes of food are everywhere, and everything is frozen, adding to slipping hazards. The equipment (pallet jacks) operate poorly, forcing you to strain when steering. There incentive program allows employees to make $4.00 an hour more if they exceed the formulated performance level by 35%, in other words, working at a rate equal to 135% effective. Mathematically, the extra 35% effort is rewarded at less than the starting wage. The company benefits greatly by paying an incentive vs. OT Finally, after injuring my back, I found the company's HR department completely disregard all my emails, phone calls, and requests to further investigate my particular circumstances. Fairness and Openness are two of the company's core values. In my opinion, they completely disregarded these values.

title: Low pay
pros: No way. Need better pay
cons: Customer systems are always down

title: No headline is adequate
pros: I loved this job. The work was easy for me. The guys were great, my supervisors were cool, the pay was above average. Pro/Con-Definitely a "MacGyver" environment.
cons: Somewhere along the line before I signed on there was a decision to not allow mechanics to have tools to fix the machines, then after a few months of complaining we were handed 3 wrenches (no exaggeration). Also it could be months before parts would show up to fix a broken machine but you were expected to keep it running. The "inside" joke was the place was held together by chewing gum and band-aids. I have no idea how they stay in business but no lie, I would work for them again. I only left because they went to 12hr shifts. I signed on with them for the 8hr shifts.

pros: not many pros working here
cons: lots of cons working here

title: Very production oriented
pros: Occasionally got free product. Very independent work. Company provided freezer suit. Computer system worked well compared to similar systems I've seen.
cons: Did not train on forklift or equipment, pretty much threw us to the wolves after watching safety videos and about 4 hours of training. Not enough Pallet jacks for everyone so people that never got any training would end up picking with a reach truck. Half of the pallet jacks didn't work right which was a safety hazard Not anywhere near enough training for the job position Warehouse was very dirty lots of debris in the forklift lanes could pose a safety hazard. Was very hard to track down a supervisor if you had an emergency Very long shifts, typically 12 hours with 2 to 4 hours of forced overtime on top of that, normally got between 55 and 70 hours a week. Have to submit your time cards to two different systems to get paid. Work in a freezer from anywhere from -34 degrees up to 29 degrees I got hired on as a forklift driver and never even touched a forklift while I was there. Mostly stacking crates of yogurt.

title: It's a job
pros: Good hours, not consistent. It's better than being in the blazing heat of the summer.
cons: Management is rooted deeper than a Sequoia Tree, favoritism runs heavy, seniority is all they care about, but get paid the same after a year of working there as the guys 20+ They do some shady stuff regarding your schedules, not communicating with those new hires the actual policy they are informing, more of a "there are the rules cause I say so"

title: Very stressful and seniority rules in everything
pros: The hourly is good and they have ok health insurance
cons: Employed full time and work part time hours management changes rules every other day and low seniority employees get the worst work schedule and you can be kick out of your job position in a shift bid even if you are more skilled they don't care seniority rules the company if you are a LTO you will be stressed to the max they want you to load ,receive, and case pick all in one good stepping stone job

title: Americold Overview
pros: Americold is a BIG company. 10k+ employees, 140+ locations. Blue collar jobs, white collar jobs. The options are endless. As a corporate employee I enjoy the seemingly endless supply of new projects, frequent travel all over the country and occasionally overseas. The compensation is industry standard maybe a tad below. Flexibility is gaining popularity. The people who make up the company are overwhelmingly great people with very few bad apples. You only like your job as much as your current boss so if you are not happy it is pretty easy to change but it is up to you. Americold ultimately is what you make out of it for yourself. The options are endless and your level of effort goes a long way in determining your future.
cons: Workflow, decision making processes, direction can do a 180 quickly. The only constant at Americold is change! But as long as you know what you are getting into it should not be that shocking.

title: Corporate Employee
pros: Americold is a great company to work for. They value your input and welcome creativity and innovation. I've been here for almost a year and I love it! The pay is good, employees are friendly, and they believe in promoting from within. If you are looking for a company that offers career growth and a rewarding future, look no further! Don't believe the negative reviews, unfortunately Americold isn't exempt from disgruntled former employees.
cons: I wish we had more paid holidays like the day off after Thanksgiving and Christmas Eve. Other than that I really don't have any cons.

title: CA$H4GRASS program, contact your local water company for details.
pros: I had a lot of fun there Sups on the floor are cool and the checks are on time. It's close to home. That's all I got.
cons: The pay is not right for what is expected. The Union is very weak because of no participation by the members. A lot of butt kissers, back stabbers and job scared coworkers. Upper management is clueless and treat you like an inmate. It's cold but if you take a few Norco and Soma every couple hours it's doable. Smoking a bowl before work and at lunch makes it easier to put up with all the stupidshit. Got to keep a G-pen and wax handy to hit in the freezer for when they call OT. Favoritism is out of control.

title: Incompetence, rude. Painfully slow, horrible computer system
pros: Can't think of anything good to say about this facility. Especially since that horrible poor excuse for a computer system was installed
cons: As a truck driver, this is my shipping facility. I arrive, check in always one hour ahead of my dock appointment. NEVER is my load ready. Most of the time it's not even picked. On average, I will spend 6-8 hours here waiting to get loaded . It wasn't too terribly bad before his farce of a new computer system was installed. Now if you can actually get an employee who can work the computers, provided they're working, it can still take 20 minutes to check in, get told to go to driver waiting,EVENTUALLY you'll get a door in rail dock, wait another hour and half, finally get loaded, go park AGAIN, go wait in line AGAIN for another incompetent boob to figure out the paper work. The old c o computer system all you had to do was sign in the rail dock office, they'd print your papers and you were out.

title: Great People Horrible Management
pros: Hard working people that want to work. Overtime is always available. Pay is okay but it is a cold environment so it could be better.
cons: Upper management only cares about themselves. They blame supervisors for everything and force them to come in early and stay late and work on their days off. All of this while taking way the extra pay supervisor used to get for working when they were supposed to be off. Schedule is always over booked and management forces supervisors to mandate associates to work over almost every day because they can't manage the customer. Management never takes responsibility for their actions and always blames someone else. Management even tries to set up people to get them into trouble. Management tells supervisors one thing and then tells associates another thing and it is all a lie to save their jobs. This is one of the worst managed places I have ever worked!

title: A Growing company for motivated people
pros: As a Supervisor, you motivate people to do the work for you. 1st shift has a great team atmosphere. You get to work in a freezer all day long. The Operations Manager travels, so it leaves time to improvise on working conditions. You can advance in the company by attending outside company functions. I started as a lift truck operator and advanced from a second shift supervisor to first shift supervisor, by being a best man at my managers wedding.
cons: You work in a freezer all day. You ask your local Human Resources about employee benefits and you are told to call an 1-800 number. Health care is offered, at a great cost to employees. Small crew so when someone is gone you pick up extra work. A lot of turn over due to management at site level.

title: All for one
pros: None. Any skills and methods you meant here will be as outdated as the machines the need to constantly fix.
cons: -Poor management. "Management" does not mean "delegation". Be prepated to do your boss's work for her. -Poor communication. The staff is great at keeping details to themselves until they receive word from their superiors that this information needs to be shared. -Hostile work environment. The senior staff is only concerned about themselves. The females of the office will do little for their male coworkers, as the all female crew prefer to keep it that way. -Lack of training. Most of what I learned from was self taught. -Poor work/life balance. You will not have a personal life. -False propoganda. Management will try so hard to project a positive outward example. However that face should be the same behind closed doors. Never will you be treated as an equal.

title: Stressful but rewarding
pros: Advancement opportunities are there for those whom are willing to put in the extra effort to attain their goals. This is a recession-proof industry, we store and ship food product....people have to eat.
cons: Longevity within the company has too much pull. More focus should be placed on education and what a person brings to the table, rather than how long they have worked for the company.

title: Good Company, Poor Employer
pros: Paychecks don't bounce. Never have to worry about getting in hours.
cons: Company is not family friendly. Family problem? They just don't care. Poor management makes it difficult to have a life outside warehouse. The one I just resigned from is making their employees work 12-hour shifts, and often two extra shifts per week - around 65 + hours per week. The mandated overtime is relentless because their only plan is to make their employees work more and more hours. Have a horrible time retaining new employees. They have about a 90% turnover rate after new employees reach their 30-day mark and start getting all those mandated overtime hours.

title: Career driven, is not what its given.
pros: The pros that I take away from working at Americold is that you have alternating days off. For example, you have long weeks and short weeks. Long weeks you work 4 12-hour days and short weeks you work 3 12-hour days. You get 4 days off after your long week and you get 3 days off after your short week.
cons: It's a cold work environment, and the facility I work for hasn't provided me with a cold weather uniform or boots since I've started working there 3 months ago. It appears that no one there wants to do their job outside of the operations department because no one wants to work in the cold. High turnover for Supervisors because of low pay and long hours.

title: The cycle of work
pros: Pay can be competitive but it took a while for them to budge and increase...afterwards wage increase are on merit.
cons: Workload is overwhelming. They push you to do more which is good to a certain extent. It seems they never want to hire more because of budget and MOSTLY because of corporate. A person can only do so much in a day. Working OT all year around is exhausting. Yeah maybe you get week here and there where you dont work as much OT but its never enough. Its a hole that you cant dig yourself out of.

title: A lot of talk with little movement forward.
pros: Plenty of work (OT), Know the work enviorment everyday, Company is trying to move forward with current management. Making changes in the right direction. Is looking for new ways to grow the buisness, working international markets as well as domestic.
cons: They tend to give up on projects if they don't return the dollars fast enough. They need to let thngs mature more before giving up and changing gears.Most warehouse have the attitude that if you don't do what they want they will go away. Some GMs are afraid to speak up due to past management. Quite a few people are afraid of change both old timers and new employees.

title: Treating People Poorly is Bad Business
pros: Exercise. Most warehouse workers ("pickers") will perform hundreds to well over one thousand lifting motions per shift.
cons: Work/life balance? Hard to have work/life balance when you don't have a life. Be there every time the company says—your scheduled time off, Christmas Eve, whenever—or be fired. Who knew indentured-servitude was still a valid employment model for 21st century America? Americold has experienced multiple on-the-job fatalities in the last three years, yet working conditions still barely rise to the level of sweat shop . . . with personnel policies to match. All the company seems to know is blunt-force coercion: if treating people poorly doesn't work, we'll treat them worse.

title: There needs to be more balance, care and respect!
pros: Time off paid day 1
cons: Insurance cost is outrageous, no balance of family and work, last minute on the fly expect you to stay for overtime when you have prior obligations but if you do not stay you get wrote up and points. Cold work environment for not so much pay. Upper management doesn't seem to have as much heart as teammates and team leads and supervisors.

title: Bosses are cool but other employees aren't
pros: The money was ok for the type of work it is. And after awhile there is growth opportunities. Benefits are pretty good too
cons: My coworkers on graveyard were childish and they were grown men in their 40's or 50's. They would talk about you and make sure you heard it and pretend like they care about helping you while being very condescending. Shift lead wouldn't listen to anything i said and yelled at me because he didnt believe the equipment wasnt working and thought i was not using it right (next day got called in the office so i could get new equipment because the old one didnt work which is what i tried to tell the shift lead but it was making him angry). Shift lead would also make rude comments about me to other coworkers.

title: Old school leadership.
pros: Location okay, pay average, benefits average.
cons: Americold is currently undergoing an abrupt transition in customer service thus causing mass confusion within the customer support teams, customers, warehouses and management. To make matters even worse - the computer systems are slow and unresponsive at critical times causing low productivity. The mission statement discourages micromanagement however that is exactly what has happen. By creating a quality control team of ex-supervisors to monitor, critic phone and grade email messages to the ninth degree while under this transition. Account reps are under enormous stress to learn new accounts (50+ each), warehouses, SOP's, new computer systems - which are still in the roll out phase and mounting programming issues - thus causing extremely low morale and lack of trust in leadership. Lay-offs are frequent and turnover is high.

title: Single worst employer I have ever worked for
pros: The employees are great people. Everyone gets along well.
cons: Very harsh punnishments for simple things. The attendance policy is rediculous. (work in a freezer and can only miss or be one minute late 6 days in a year)The list of work rules is a mile long and the punnishments are not fitting. Performance expectations are way out of line. (three bad days in a year can get you fired) The Management runs amuck with favoritism. Every supervisor has their own set of rules making it impossible to know exactly what is expected. The eguipment is not maintained well at all. Employees are expected to use equipment that doesn't work right and has safety issues and still maintain their performance. In a nut shell, the employees are just a number to management.

title: Company in Transition
pros: Americold is an old company that has gone through many transformations. Most of those have been fraught with problems. However, today is a new Americold. The current management team has been in place for three years now and has made tremendous progress re-shapping the company. There is still work to do but Americold has reclaimed it's position overall as being the best provider in the industry.
cons: The recent transformation has been demanding. Lot's of hours and lot's of turnover. That said, it is important to find the right team in every functional area and the vast majority of turn has been good turn.

title: Full Time Employee
pros: Well, It is a job, ..a pay check , that is really about the only thing good to say about being here. So,If you need a job They will hire anyone with a heartbeat.
cons: They will hire anyone and throw them on a lift , work release is O.K. , but they don't tell you if violent offenders are working with you.( they say they run background checks but lots of felons have worked here for years). its a very old building, old equipment , worn out fork lifts and doors, angry " mean" Local management .. ridiculous goals and no rewards, favoritism of certain crew , and a severe shift rivalry . poor wages for this area ....... not sure how some of they guys have kept their job for 10 years ?" teachers pets " very very high turnover rate.

title: Worst place to work at
pros: Literally nothing good about working here, not even the paychecks bc they pay so little
cons: Everything, literally everything, from the terrible pay to the roaches to everything

title: Overall good!
pros: I initially received some negative feedback from a former Americold employee about the department that wanted to hire me. I'm glad I didn't listen. What I will say is be smart enough to assess the situation yourself. The team I work for has been great. There are plenty of learning opportunities and the company at the corp office really values investing in the team. I've taken on lots of work responsibilities. My director is great about making sure we celebrate during holidays and birthdays. The company has 1 or 2 corporate events at year.
cons: Work/life balance is tough. At corp in certain departments, it seems like the company keeps you at capacity. It takes a while for promotion opportunities and increases are pretty standard. The PTO isn't the best. No real wfh policy, it's left up to your direct manager.

title: So So company
pros: The Appleton facility has great management and the co-workers are awesome. All in all it is a great atmosphere to work in as the majority of the employees get along great. They also have a great vacation policy for their employees.
cons: As with any large corporation they seem to think that everyone is replaceable even if they have a great employee right there. You don't necessarily get paid what you are worth because of that and the corporate offices don't seem to get that. They also don't always put the customers needs or interests first. If a major customer is happy with the way things are and the systems you use, why change them and risk losing that major customer? Some decisions don't always make the most sense.

title: Great company!
pros: Americold is a great company to work for! There is much to be done and employees are given the right support and training to get work done. Work smarter and not harder is a very prevalent theme across the company, which makes life better for people with respect to work/life balance.
cons: Perhaps the only con to Americold is that it is still going through some growing pains and the focus on continuous improvement is making it less overwhelming.

title: I love it here
pros: Tom Stevens is an outstanding General Manager. He has taken the initiative to ensure our site is running efficiently and effectively. Tom has brought new ideas and innovations to our company, which have resulted in increased productivity and profitability. He is an excellent communicator and has excellent problem-solving skills. He is always available to answer any questions or address any issues in a timely manner. We could not be happier that Tom is our new General Manager. He is a refreshing change from our old General Manager and has far exceeded our expectations.
cons: Our site provides an extremely efficient operation and excellent service to our customers. This means that we are consistently at our storage capacity. Which can lead to occasionally working long hours.

title: Americold
pros: I can work a much overtime as I want, can't work past 12 hrs tho and I can come in at anytime on my off days. Most of the work is done on a High Reach so there's nothing physical about the work unless you get a case pick. Theres double time. No mandatory overtime till until you've worked 90 days.
cons: Its a freezer position so even with the gear you start with you will need to layer up. Its unionized so starting out you're at the bottom of the seniority totem pole witch means you will always be the first to get hit with mandatory ovt. You can only get double time after working 48 hrs and having 6 punch-ins or six days worked.

title: Tenured employee who has advanced in many roles. AWESOME Co-Workers!!
pros: Strong market presence. Leadership has shared vision. People in this industry are incredibly great. Advancement opportunities are there but you have to work for them. Great company for people with a strong work ethic.
cons: This industry historically has not necessarily been structured in a true corporate fashion. Growing in that process can be frustrating and make decisions or projects take longer than needed thus outdating important items for our customer or facility. That said, it is a needed change and in the long run is what will set Americold apart from everyone else. I am sure our executive team shares in this frustration.

title: Not sure where they’re going.
pros: Good hours and days. Flexible management. Love that management recognizes employees birthdays and anniversaries. Goodness cold weather gear and boots. Enjoy vacation time and holidays off.
cons: Hurry up and wait attitude at regional/corporate. Scared to take chances. Won’t spend much needed money to fix deteriorating buildings, ammonia refrigeration systems, and equipment (which could potentially lead to a major safety issue). Loss of several key corporate and regional higher-up employees. It shows they can’t keep talented people around due to the frustration of the company being poorly run. Also, stop keeping some of these terrible employees just because you’re scared of being sued! Focus on the talent and move them up.

title: Sanitation is okay but not great.
pros: Union representation Excellent coworkers Friendly and awesome supervisors Safety bonuses Safety Committee Security Gates w/cardkey
cons: Union - Seniority Based Union - four months to get in for Sanitation. Can be cold in winter months, very hot in summer months. Dress accordingly! If you're in the freezer area dress warm. And no steel toes! Composite toes only.

title: Great job/Great Atmosphere Unfortunate pay for employees
pros: The Edison location is a great place to work. The atmosphere is exemplary. The associates are great and the immediate management team is top tier. There’s freedom to do your work and not be micro managed.
cons: Unfortunately the biggest downside is the pay. It’s almost disheartening to know and feel that you aren’t being compensated well enough for the amount of work you out in on a daily basis. For such a large company it should be easy to pay their associates a competitive wage. You are almost required to work at least 10-12 hours of overtime a week just to see a decent check.

title: A Job that leaves you frozen
pros: Steady money with overtime seems to be the norm throught each location. If you're lucky to work with a good crew, it can go smoothly. Large company achieved through merger/aquisitions.
cons: New CEO every 3 yrs each bringing a new project, thus many projects never complete. Benefits seem to always decrease or become more expensive while you're given a "we care" speech. Maintenance on equipment is at the end of priority. OT is usually mandatory. somewhat aggresive productivity enforced in non-union plant morale is too low for this extreme environment

title: Hard, Frustrating, Dangerous, Isolating
pros: They pay on time. The work is great exercise! Don't need to worry about the AC in the summer.
cons: It's -10f all the time. Equipment breaks down at the worst time, every time. Lack of time for family. Poor management of people and time. Stressful micro management and performance tracking based on unrealistic timing. Problems are addressed too little too late. People die either on the job, or from heart attacks thinking about the job. Don't expect to live over 60.

title: Corporate is a Joke
pros: none none none none
cons: Human Resources at Corporate is a joke. They do nothing to help their employees, instead they work directly with management. In many cases management has no clue how to do their job or their employees. HR upholds this behavior and rewards this, while the employees who are managers or below get nothing. If you report something to HR, please know that it will get right back to your manager. Management runs the company not HR. Use Americold as a stepping stone, not to advance your career but to move on to a better "employee" based company. Managers and above get away with anything including holding back their employees.

title: Some Good Co-workers....that's about it
pros: Some of the people I worked with for the most part were decent.
cons: 2 "supervisors" were horrid, 2 of them were OK. Why should people have to deal with 4-5 different supervisors each week?
