Would never recommend Centerspace to anyone. Pay non-competitive and stingy with money even though goals were always highly surpassed.

title: Better Every Days
pros: Starting a new job can be a little nerve-wracking, but my experience with Centerspace has been nothing short of incredible. From day one, I've felt supported, valued, and genuinely welcomed. One of the biggest pros has been the flexibility in working style—there’s a strong sense of trust here, and you’re encouraged to work in a way that brings out your best. What truly sets this company apart is its leadership team. They're not only accessible but also incredibly open to new ideas and different ways of doing things. It’s refreshing to be part of an organization where innovation is encouraged and your voice matters. You’re empowered to think boldly and “Dare to Win”—an approach that creates a dynamic and energizing work environment. I’ve also had the chance to challenge myself and grow in ways that are both exciting and rewarding. The work is engaging, and I’ve already learned so much in just a short time. On top of that, my co-workers have been amazing—friendly, genuine, and eager to build connections. There’s a shared commitment to getting “Better Every Days,” and that mindset shows up in both individual efforts and team collaboration. The culture is warm and welcoming, and that starts from the top. Even our CEO, Anne, took the time to personally reach out to see how my first few weeks were going. It’s clear that people come first here. The leadership team checks in regularly and truly wants to hear from us—not just in group settings but on a personal level too. Overall, I’m incredibly grateful to be part of such a thoughtful, forward-thinking company. It’s a place where people and progress go hand in hand, and where we’re all encouraged to grow, innovate, and make every day better.
cons: As with any new role, there’s always a learning curve—and for me, the most significant one has been getting up to speed with the technology platforms used at Centerspace. While each system has its strengths, I’ve noticed that not all platforms fully integrate with one another, which can lead to some manual work to ensure consistency and alignment across different tools. This has been a great opportunity for me to better understand the current processes, and I appreciate the transparency and support from my team as I’ve navigated through it. At the same time, I see a real opportunity for process improvement, particularly in exploring how AI could be leveraged at a system level to streamline workflows, reduce manual tasks, and improve overall efficiency. I’m excited to see how technology can evolve here, and I’m confident that, given the company’s openness to innovation and continuous improvement, these enhancements are not only possible but well within reach.

title: Good Property Management Company
pros: Progressive company with great pay, good benefits.
cons: Lots of operational changes with little to no notice.

title: Great place to work
pros: I have loved working for Centerspace. Probably the best company I have worked for. I love the work I do and the people I work with.
cons: All other employees work until 5pm where I work until 6pm.

title: Life
pros: Great people and fun company
cons: It’s work but no notable downside

title: Decent company
pros: great properties and benefits with their 401k
cons: poor training and drama thriving enviorment

title: Great company
pros: Good culture, strong leadership, good growth
cons: Fast pace of change however that is common place in todays environment

title: Top Notch Support & Culture
pros: Great work/life balance that is respected by leaders. Benefits are tough to beat. Culturally, having worked for multiple Multi-Family Housing Companies, CenterSpace talks the talk, and walks the walk. Support is amazing & every employee I've reached out to has been happy to lend a hand whenever necessary. One of their keys, is "One Team", which means that although we all work at our individual properties, we're one company and we are all on the same team. It's not just a key, or a hashtag, it's actually true.
cons: Depending on the position, days can be heavy. We deal with the 4 most important things in peoples lives: their homes, pets, cars & money. That's not necessarily a con for the company but the industry. As managers, it's not a 24-hour job in reality, but it does feel like it. Only other item would be that due to the size of the teams, staffing is sometimes difficult without enough bodies to fill in. That is where the #oneteam comes in and help is recruited from other sites.

title: Messy
pros: Endless funds to spend on the residents and staff, there's apparently no max to the party budget
cons: Management doesn't care about Fair Housing or EEOC at all. There's a huge problem with fraternization. Lots of hooking up, drinking, and partying with the residents. Staff members get really cliquey with residents and are unable to impartially implement Fair Housing. One resident sexually harassed another resident at the pool, and when the victim complained, the manager said the victim was being sensitive and not understanding the perpetrator's humor (she was friends with perp). She refused to file an incident report. One teammate was regularly hooking up with a resident who was going through Eviction. It's unethical and convoluted. The exposure for a lawsuit is crazy high. It's like going back to high school in the worst way. If you don't go along with the status quo, you're told you're not a "culture fit" and your teammates will shun you like in The Crucible.

title: Supervisor
pros: Its a work environment that enables you to work independently.
cons: Advancement is slow to level up.

title: Great company
pros: I've loved working for Centerspace because of the company culture. The benefits are great, and my managers have wanted to watch me grow within the industry.
cons: There really aren't many downsides. One thing I will say is that Centerspace is not the best with pay, but the benefits & culture make up for it. There also aren't very many opportunities to move up the ladder.

title: Love it Here
pros: Great Benefits, Atmosphere and People work here
cons: None that I can think of

title: Stay Away
pros: Nothing at all, not even a little bit positive
cons: Fake people, toxic and gossip driven management

title: Bad Managers
pros: The benefits are unmatchable by most companies.
cons: Upper management doesn't care about the opinions of site staff. Everyone blames the Community Manager when something happens that isn't in their control. They care more about money than their employees.

title: Excellent place to work
pros: Excellent company with ideal structure, size and opportunities. Management is helpful and supportive!
cons: New system changes, but easily adapted to.

title: Great team
pros: Collaborative and adaptive. Great people and fun work environment.
cons: Problem employees are not dealt with and can tarnish the culture.

title: Great company, growing and people focused
pros: The people, teamwork, culture, growth
cons: Better development for team would be ideal

title: Industry Leader
pros: When I reflect on my time with Centerspace I can say with complete confidence that this company has helped me grow into a strong leader, mentor and really pathed my way to the successes I have experienced. They have a strong sense of their one team mantra and are adaptable to change laying the path to becoming a industry leader in property management. They took any obstacle over this last year and turned it into a learning experience, kept a positive outlook on every situation and really supported their employees through the ever changing times. I’m speaking out of first hand knowledge being at our Urban properties during COVID and the Civil Unrest in the communities my properties are in, they made the residents and employees safety and care a first priority. They made their appreciation known through listening to what we needed and what residents needed and acted on it instead of only thinking about the bottom line. The ability to work for such a excellent leadership team has shown me what working for a company should be, you should have work/life balance and time off, you should be heard and cared for and most importantly you should have the opportunity to grow and be given opportunities to show your passion, Centerspace gives you all of that and more.
cons: There are none I can point out.

title: Unvalued employee
pros: Some positives would be the good hours, stable` pay, and the insurance. I love my residents so much and they are the only reason that I have been able to last this long in such a toxic environment.
cons: It does not matter how hard you work, you will NEVER be recognized for it. They say they hire up within the company, however I have seen on numerous occasions, perfectly qualified, hard workers not even being considered with no good reason as to why. Corporate, upper management is completely untouchable, it does not matter what they do or how they treat people, nothing will ever change. I have seen employee turnover after turnover because of the regional manager and it doesn't seem to be looked at. It has been made very clear to everyone currently employed under them that nothing will change, and we have been told to go ahead and find a new job. IRET does NOT care about their employees in any way shape or form. They also do not offer a very high discount on rent, considering most property management companies offer free housing to employees. The pay is also considerably lower than competing properties. It has been empty promise, after promise.

title: Not stable
pros: The environment is good. If your full time the benefits are good too. I like that there is nothing after 6pm and nothing on sundays.
cons: The company is forever changing. They’ve implemented so many different things since I started. All which require online training. But they only give a week or two until something happens. You could be gone on vacation and come back and everything is different. They also claim to value costumer service, but between management being rude to residents all the time, the constant price hikes in amenities (garages going up 40% in one year), and only covering heat instead of any other utilities is obvious they are only interested in making money. Also, if you’re part time, your benefits suck. Only the discount of rent. Nothing else.

title: Best Job Ever!
pros: I started working for IRET last year, and I can honestly say I am working with the BEST team ever, and for one of the most positively focused companies I’ve ever seen. From the very day that I walked through the door, I have been treated with nothing but respect. I am surrounded by people who support me, believe in me, and who want me to succeed. Opportunities abound with this company, and they are always on the look out for people with a “can do” attitude. Everyone I’ve seen here works hard, and they believe in what they do, and why they do it. Even in the great state of North Dakota, one can find amazing opportunities.
cons: Haven't found a downside yet.

title: Poor Manager
pros: Some good, engaged people at corporate but much apathy and laziness exists within this company
cons: I guess I should have been more concerned during my interview when my future manager said "one thing this company doesn't do well is train people". I assumed she would train me but evidently she couldn't be bothered. I don't know if it is a regional problem in Billings or it is the culture throughout the company but IRET Properties does not treat its people well. My manager favored people that were lazy, tired and had no enthusiasm for their job. Characteristics that she exhibited.

title: Custodian, It has been a good experience working at IRET but it is a bit of a lonely job as you work by yourself.
pros: It is nice because you are able to chose your hours as long as you work between 5-9 and you also can move up with experience. Potentially a person can being working as a leasing agent or in maintenance.
cons: Sometimes it can be lonely as stated before but that is really a characteristic of the job in general and not a reflection of the company. I suggest getting some audio books and listening to them while you work. However, I can go through about 3 audio books a week which can make this practice expensive.

title: Mismanagement
pros: I will have to say that Pay is a factor to accepting a position with IRET.
cons: It may not be for each location, but mismanagement is a massive factor in my location. One thing is said to one employee, another is said to the next employee across the office; information essential to job performance is not given to be passed along to residents asking questions. Micro-managing is a culture practiced to full extent and there is an atmosphere of dictator, my-way-or-the-highway attitude. Training is null and I am lost in the realm of this money-hungry company. I could perform my duties much better if I had adequate training. With a lot of actions and miscommunication, there are a lot of Human Resource mal-practices going on.

title: I will always recommend IRET
pros: IRET genuinely cares about their employees and their families. They took every precaution when COVID 19 had started and continues to do so. They allowed their teams to work remotely. They've made their voice clear regarding justice and equality. I am so proud to be able to work for a company that is so passionate in standing for what is right. They also even give out quarterly bonuses + even random ones. The senior team is very involved and you feel like a work family. Their training is extremely thorough and hands on. You will feel very confident jumping in after training. There is plenty of room to grow within the company and even to transfer out of state. I cannot recommend IRET enough!
cons: You may have to work some nights or weekends. They do off set it by giving you a day off or time and a half.

title: My year at IRET.
pros: Benefits, Pay, Corporate structure, work life balance and training are just a few of the pros that IRET has to offer. I’m approaching a 1 year anniversary with this company and am extremely satisfied with my decision of employment.
cons: Dealing with angry tenants has its downside and in my opinion is the hardest part of the job. Some people just let the smallest thing turn into the end of the world. You have to have the right kind of temperament for this position. On a positive note the company offers training that can help you cope with this situation.

title: Dead End Job with Poor Management
pros: My coworkers are some of the best people around, but sadly are one of the only positive things about working for this company.
cons: There is little to no room for advancement within the company. At times when more advanced positions have been open they have tended to hire outside the company rather than giving opportunity to existing staff members. Benefits have been slashed and salary is below market. Work as hard as you like, but there is little chance you will be recognized for it. Your reward will be yet more work, but with no pay increase. Executive management consists of a tight knit group of people that is holding the company back from what it could be.

title: Community Manager
pros: This was a really great company prior to new upper management coming in.
cons: The new management team controls every aspect of your day, they micromanage and clearly do not communicate with each other because they all tell you something different. You don’t have the ability to provide your own input or feedback. There is no room for growth within the company because they fill all the positions with people from outside the company that know someone. Your hard work is never recognized, no matter how dedicated you are to the company. You get little to no say in your budget, even though you are on expected to run the property. They also continually pile more work on you and don’t offer adequate staffing. Regional managers are non existent, they “work from home” and are rarely available. A lot of sketchy things happen and heads are turned the other way, no one is held accountable.

title: Property Management
pros: I was lucky to get out when I did.
cons: This is —hands down— the worst job I’ve ever had in the property management industry. I was emotionally neglected by the boss that hired me, bulldozed by my on-site management, and was publicly humiliated by the head bosses that hired me. As a queer person, I figured this was the most progressive company I could work for in the area. I never anticipated that not only would I be shunned, but publicly humiliated by the team that hired me after I turned in my notice. I would hire an attorney if I had the time and energy to fight the lawsuit. Turns out? I wasn’t the only one with bad experience. There’s a clear pattern. If you’re looking for a #lgbtqia family — RUN. This ain’t it.

title: Family Friendly Company
pros: IRET Properties understands the importance of work/life balance and family. This company also offers fantastic benefits and growth opportunities. I really enjoy working for IRET because I feel supported by my manager and know that she not only cares about me as an employee, but also a person.
cons: This is a tough one to answer because the company has made so many significant strides in the last few years. While there are many areas for growth and advancement, the path to the next level can be unclear. If you have a good manager that cares about your personal growth then you'll be successful.

title: Great if you like being micromanaged
pros: Benefits are good. 5% 401k match. They help contribute to HSA. Healthcare covers most things. PTO is decent (14 days I believe), plus 8 or 9 paid holidays.
cons: Toxic work environment. Upper management doesn't care what feedback they get from site teams. If you say anything negative you "don't believe in the product". They don't trust site teams to do what needs to be done so they gatekeep everything and prolong any necessary process. Only cares about the money and bottom line. While that's important, customer relations needs to be more focused on. Never worked for a company that is so money-grubbing.

title: Solid company on the right path
pros: New senior management TRULY understands what it means to have a positive cultural environment. VERY pleased to be on board and work with others who are happy and engaged in what they do on a daily basis.
cons: It's always challenging have performance judged my metrics - this is no exception, but there is always support offered to help achieve objectives and management DOES listen to challenges we are experiencing in "the field", and at least have reachable occupancy and financial goals.

title: A company that listens
pros: Centerspace is a company that offers many opportunities for personal and employment growth. Always have the chance for one on one meetings, goal setting. They give us high and reasonable expectations with the tools to succeed. They ask for our feedback and listen to issues, problems and ways to improve.
cons: Day to day calls from prospects, residents, vendors can be overwhelming and create undo stress. Allowing time for us to complete day to day tasks versus setting expectation that we need to be touring every hour.

title: Toxic Culture
pros: They have great benefits and pto!
cons: Some of the worst management! The Regional above me was corrupt and a liar. I won't say who it was but it rhymes with Vulmer. She does not care about her employees and did anything she could to bully her employees. She is known in the company for being a gossiper and showing favortism. It was always her way or the highway. This is the kind of person Centerspace promotes. She got promoted last year and promoted the person that sucked up to her the most that had no idea what they were doing at their job. They have a bunch of fake, rude, bullying people in leadership. I was with this company for way too many years of my life. I put up with so much and am grateful that I made it out.

title: The best company I have ever worked for.
pros: Centerspace is the best organization I have been a part of. They genuinely empower you to be the best, and everyone from top to bottom is highly supportive. This is truly the best experience I have had with an organization. They care about their employees and the customer with a deep passion. It is truly a fantastic place to work.
cons: In all honesty, I do not have any cons of working at centerspace. I would recommend this company to anyone and everyone.

title: Happy with what I do/Confused with constant Policy changes
pros: Flexibility of my job, Regional Manager needs extensive training in policy, troubleshooting real problems instead of head in sand & playing as though the problem doesn’t exist. Profit sharing is very generous, benefits are better than most in Topeka, vacation, sick, volunteer, floating holiday.
cons: Policies change frequently. Upper Management doesn't realize or care about what goes on at the property level. They don’t listen, it seems as though they are all black & white & it's about the almighty $.

title: Always Striving for the Best
pros: Employees are treated with respect and contribute feedback to help change and grow the organization. Competitive salary, and compensation packages. Healthy and stable work environment.
cons: Stressful but all jobs are. It's a good tool for growth and motivation.

title: Things Are Changing
pros: IRET is a company in transition, and it's for the better. They are refocusing on their employees and their residents, to become a more people first organization. Teamwork and doing the right thing are highlighted values at all levels, and employees are being empowered to make good business decisions. I truly feel like the best days of this organization are ahead and I'm glad to be along for the ride.
cons: Property management as a whole can be stressful. The pay also could be more competitive.

title: Made the switch, Totally worth it!
pros: Great work-life balance, upper management and leadership really care about employees, training and development, opportunities to grow, and communication is fantastic.
cons: Not really a con - they are constantly changing at a rapid rate, sometimes it can be difficult to keep up, they do a good job at keeping you informed.

title: Good Place to Get Started
pros: Learn a lot of skills quickly. Many scenarios when it comes to working in housing and people
cons: Lack of growth. This is more of a place to get your feet wet and gain some experience. Moving up in the company is extremely difficult

title: Great Employer!
pros: Fantastic work/life balance. Lots of opportunity for growth and advancement. Leadership is very invested in employees and want to see you succeed. Great company values and outlook for the future. Great communication and relationship with direct supervisor.
cons: None at the present time.

title: I enjoyed coming to work every day.
pros: Great benefits, work/life balance, and coworkers. There is support for community involvement, and holidays are fun! Birthdays are also celebrated monthly, and achievements are recognized. Training and advancement are encouraged.
cons: Like every place, workplace politics plays some part - be careful who you choose to be friendly with.

title: Greedy company
pros: PTO is great best part of the company
cons: Not a place you want to be for long they don't value their employees time. If you aren't doing exactly what they want the way they want you will not get the respect or credit you deserve for putting up with all the bs that goes on within this company or the great work you have actually done. Inflation is at 7.9% gas prices are through the roof and Centerspace is justifying 1 & 2 percent raises when the company has grew 120%.

title: Best Company I've Worked For
pros: Has the benefits of working for a small company as well as a corporation. Small company benefits - personable management, laid back environment, flexibility, substantial raises. Corporation benefits - bonuses, paid vacation, retirement, paid volunteer hours.
cons: When I first started, there were a lot more employee gatherings for morale. That has significantly decreased.

title: More slumlords from the midwest
pros: It's is a job to go to.
cons: They are from the dark ages of labor and maintenance. Upper management to lower exceeds unreasonable thought process on even the most minute task. They will go back on deals during acquisition for your pay and job. Absolutely no transparency. Zero qualified employees in almost every position. I'm really not sure it's possible to get away with outright discrimination and hippa violations not to mention Osha. Don't apply. I didn't get a choice.

title: Excited to see Change
pros: IRET has been a fantastic employer to work for. In my prior years I have never had so many benefits. They really know how to treat an employee and are continuously making changes for the better.
cons: Nothing at this time and don't see anything in the future but great change.

title: Great Company!
pros: Pay is on the higher end of the industry. Work life balance is great! It's a growing company so there are many growth opportunities.
cons: They are not in every state.

title: Decent transitional role
pros: The team sets you up for successful learning for promotions and transferable skills
cons: Not sustainable income if you’re living in a city with higher cost of living

title: Company used to care....
pros: Comprehensive benefits and better than average paid time off.
cons: It's all about the shareholders at IRET. If you work for this company be prepared for cuts every year and a management team that only cares about the bottom line.

title: Amazing company to work for
pros: Great training, amazing support, management will listen, great pay and benefits. Just a really great environment and culture. I am happy and lucky to be a part of!
cons: I do not have any complaints.

title: Great Company - Awful Residential Department
pros: Great benefits, for most of the office there was amazing work life balance, and CEO made great efforts to at least acknowledge everyone.
cons: Residential department is poorly run at corporate office

title: Many wonderful and needed changes in the last 2-3 years.
pros: Flexibility, pay, training, corporate support, benefits, employee discount.
cons: Certain markets do not offer many growth opportunities.

pros: Great position! Great department! Plenty of opportunity for advancement.
cons: Outside of department senior leadership is resistant to change. They are working on it and this would not stop me from gladly working there again.

title: Amazing place to work
pros: There is a one team mentality.
cons: I don't have any cons for the company

title: Maintenance Technician
pros: Great independent work environment with some autonomy to complete necessary projects.
cons: Poor management at onsite locations. Competitive unnecessary game playing and poor ethics.

title: Great Place to work
pros: Management and benefits and team members
cons: New way to enter time, UKG is not a good program

title: Great company and still trying to improve
pros: The leaders care about excellence, diversity & inclusion, and people
cons: The Real Estate industry tends to move slow compared to smaller companies in other sectores.

title: Lack of leadership from the top
pros: Decent pay compared to the Denver average for leasing agents
cons: upper management had lack of vision and refused to listen to the on site staff

title: housekeeper
pros: insurance, 401k, monday-friday, 7:30- 4:00pm
cons: had to do work duties not in my job description. only get a pay raise every year of .15 to .33 a hour

title: Could be better
pros: Covid pay, high dollar pay, friendly staff.
cons: No life to work ratio you just work constantly, low staffed, don't get paid right if you work here.

title: Good company so far
pros: Small company feel with enough capital to run their properties well
cons: Still working out the kinks with their new processes and software

title: Best company I have ever worked for
pros: Great pay and benefits, amazing culture, meaningful work, all one team
cons: No cons to speak of

title: Good job, not enough pay
pros: Good company values, coworkers, days go by fast
cons: Hours aren’t great, the commission isn’t high enough

title: Communicartions & Room for Growth
pros: Top to bottom, excellent communciations channels and repeated opportunities for growth
cons: Plenty of training opportunities but training can be boring.

title: Amazing Opportunity
pros: Great team centered workday! Goals are clear as a team and supported from all levels.
cons: Less opportunities in warmer climates.

title: Assistant Community Manager
pros: Great live work balance and room for growth
cons: nothing that I have experienced so far

title: Good Company
pros: Flexability, Co-Workers, Daily Essential Duties
cons: Pay, Hours, Management, Large Work Load

title: Good Company
pros: The staff and management is great.
cons: None that I can think of.

title: Great Empoyer
pros: Employee rental discounts, commission, amazing staff
cons: Being owned by a corporation. Not a fan of most corporations.

title: Enjoy working with great colleagues.
pros: Enjoy working with great colleagues.
cons: Endless meetings and no ability to get work done.

title: Work and life balance
pros: Co-workers, management, hours, benefits are good
cons: Pay, work resources, software could be better

title: Great company
pros: Great company to work at, friendly environment.
cons: No enough room to grow not enough training

title: Salary
pros: Good commission, meet new people
cons: Low wages, long hours, dealing with rude residents

pros: Its an ok place to work for
cons: None that I can think og

title: Great company
pros: Work life balance is great!
cons: Don’t have any cons, great company

title: Easy job
pros: Easy job. Low stress. Freedom.
cons: Low pay, disorganized structure at corporate level

title: Great management!
pros:
Very supportive management 
Healthy culture
cons: Low end of competitive salary

pros: Job stability, Decent pay, Nice coworkers
cons: Difficult residents and upper management

title: Bad employer
pros: None. They expect everything and give nothing
cons: Everything. Hyper controlling CEO is detached from day to day operations

title: Property Manager - great company to learn from
pros: Cousins is incredible. They teach you anything and everything you need to know to be successful.
cons: None. They really are exceptional

title: I like Cousins!
pros: The culture is great - the people who work at Cousins are so supportive and want to invest in your career and see you succeed.
cons: Pay and benefits could be better!

title: Culture
pros: Culturally nice with descent management
cons: No room for growth devotional

title: decent pay
pros: pros are the people there you work with are great and it feels like a family once you get to know everyone
cons: pay increases aren't that great

title: Cousins is great!
pros: The Austin team is great and everyone is very welcoming!
cons: Benefits could be a bit better (medical insurance, PTo, etc).

pros: Very stable company. Leadership seems to care about everyone.
cons: No present growth opportunities at the upper level of engineering

title: Great Employer
pros: They care about their people, the buildings they own are top tier, they host many employee events
cons: most of their positions are in-office 100% of time

title: Great job
pros: Work at your own pase
cons: Can get a little slow at times

title: Lack of Communication
pros: Competitive salary, good accounting dept. and opportunities to volunteer
cons: Poor benefits, minimal PTO, lack of communication and guidance

title: Great Place to Work
pros: Family oriented company. It didn't feel like you were just a number.
cons: Pay need to go up with the market.

title: Best Life Work Balance culture
pros: Very flexible with Employees, good benefits, good pay.
cons: I do not have any

title: Accounting
pros: environmental is very important and working for this company is a good fit for anyone in Accounting
cons: remote is only 1 day per week

title: Exciting company for anyone in finance and development but accounting positions were not so great.
pros: Its an exciting company to work for if you're involved on the finance or development side of things. They show great promise and continued growth. They totally dominate most of the markets that they are in.
cons: Located in Buckhead, where traffic is a nightmare but they're right on the buckhead marta station. The employee review process was broken. Your bonus was not based on how well you performed. It was tied directly to the company's overall performance, which actually wasn't the worst thing since the company had done well while I was there. But the issue was that your performance review literally did not matter. We had the ability to work from home but were rarely allowed. I don't know if this has changed since I've left. Most people on the accounting side were unhappy and starting to look for other jobs by the time I had left. Lots of people spent their entire careers at the company and were overlooked for senior positions, which were given to outside hires. This had a large effect on the employee morale for people in accounting.

title: Company and culture have changed - not in a positive way
pros: Nice buildings with free soda and coffee.
cons: For the past three years - the company has become very political and a very cold environment. Everyone from the CEO to HR has become harsh and it appears that they have forgotten what previously made them a good company- their people. Benefits cost are becoming a burden on employees, employees seem to be set-up and fired, their is a lack of employee voices being heard, employees are treated harshly and expected to work more than 10 hours per day and weekends.

title: Horrible Culture-Unprofessional, Back-stabbing, Not inclusive
pros: Nice properties and nice offices
cons: The worst upper management I've ever seen. They may be a great company in Atlanta but Austin is a nightmare. There is so much turnover, favoritism, back-stabbing, verbal abuse and an overall lack of consistency or standards. The culture is non-existent, no meaningful interaction within or between offices. Maintenance, Admin and Customer Service have suffered as a result of constant turnover, no traction possible. HR doesn't care or get involved to solve any issues. Don't damage your career or reputation by being associated with this company. The worst place I have ever worked. Don't believe the positive reviews, they must be written by upper management or HR. Note-No hybrid or work from home, 100% on site, outdated paradigm. Benefits are just ok, high deductible.

Atlanta is the HQ and they do an awful job of communicating with the other markets. Management seems to have it's head in the sand!

title: 3 Year Analyst Program - Great foundation
pros: I went through DRH's 3 year analyst program after graduating from undergrad. It was a great place to start my career and build a foundation of knowledge in the hospitality / real estate industry. Upper management took an active interest in my development and got me involved in multiple facets of the company. Loved the team environment. Exit opportunities were solid and the C-level execs were very helpful with advice and recommendations when my analyst program was coming to an end.
cons: Nothing major comes to mind. They let me travel a solid amount but would've loved to travel even more.

title: Diamond Rocks!
pros: DiamondRock is a real estate company focused on the hospitality industry. The basic function of the company, to own hotels, is an exciting premise. I mean, who wouldn’t want an occupation that is the real-life equivalent of the Monopoly Man? The hotel business is an industry that is rooted in taking care of hotels that, in turn, take care of employees and travelers. It is an industry that has a meaningful impact on the daily lives of many people. The company is very well organized and operations run smoothly. The team is talented and motivated, with employees working hard to continue to help grow the company. DiamondRock is also a responsible corporate citizen and a great member of the Bethesda community by offering opportunities for employees to participate in local community service initiatives (also, read on to discover my notes about Bethesda later). The executives of the company are very approachable. The company prides itself on good communication, and it is easy to speak with the company’s key leaders. The executives make it a priority to ensure that all employees are aware of major directives, projects and goals. Also, the executives have an open door policy for questions, which is pretty cool. Now on to the important stuff. There is a snack room with unlimited, bottomless, snacks and soda (at least three types of pretzels at all times)! If you want to set a new personal best for afternoon soda consumption, there will be nothing stopping you. There’s even a really high-tech coffee machine that I’m convinced you can only operate if your previous employer was NASA. Also, there are a variety of entertaining informal and formal social events that help employees get to know each other in a more informal setting. And now to address a slightly controversial topic, the office’s location in Bethesda. Since the good folks at Glassdoor.com do not have a category for items that have both positive and negative attributes (NOTE TO GLASSDOOR: create a category for things that are boths pro's and con's), I’m placing this squarely into the positive attribute category. Pro because there are many hospitality industry companies in Bethesda, which creates a lot of networking opportunities. Pro because DiamondRock’s office occupies the best location in Bethesda, right on top of the Bethesda Metro Station (Red Line), and within three blocks of about 100 shops and restaurants (note, this is an approximate count and probably cannot be relied upon as an official statistic). Con because you are not in city-center Washington, DC. Bethesda is a small city where the majority of the workforce departs the area after the workday has concluded. However, Bethesda does have its perks if you need to finish up some last minute holiday shopping, replace an I-phone that you recently dropped while swimming in a lake, or find a tailor to mend your suit because your best friend decided to elope and only provided you with three days’ notice (it happened).
cons: Although DiamondRock is a mid-cap public company traded on the NYSE, the workforce does not consist of that many people. Choosing to work at a small versus a large company is a lot like choosing to attend a liberal arts college or venture to State U. At a small college, everybody knows your name while at a large school you have the benefit of complete anonymity until a professor finally inquires where you have been all semester. Just note that at DiamondRock you won’t find an internal intranet with postings for 500 open positions, but you also won’t be required to attend a two-month training program at some spooky Upstate New York corporate campus.

title: Three Year Analyst Program
pros: Amazing leadership and professional development in the three year analyst program! The group embraced a strong sense of teamwork while producing meaningful material for the company. The program developed a broad set of skills and set a firm foundation in hotel real estate while the role had exposure to C-Level management and all departments within the company. The company and analyst team culture created an fun and comfortable workplace while the work was dynamic and challenging.
cons: None really. Since it's a small company there aren't very many mid-management roles, but senior management was still invested in career development.

title: Regarding Aug 13 post clearly someone in marketing.
pros: None really, sorry. Unless your and executive with a contract that will pay you for years after they lay you off.
cons: Trust is their last name, but it is the last thing you will get as an employee and the last thing you should do as an employee. So the facts, in the last year people who have spent a career of 20 plus years building the company have been let go. Then they start out-sourcing everything from leasing, architecture, and recently even management. Only the Executives with their golden parachutes are the priority at this company, read the SEC documents and if interviewing ask how many people have been laid off / let go in the last few years due to a new strategy! Soon all that will be left are a few executives with sweet compensation packages and third party service providers. Look at the quarterly reports, after dropping dividend they are still paying out more than they take in, not a winning formula! No growth in stock, stuck with perdominatly older office space that is struggling and can't compete agains all the new buildings, and selling off of divisions. Yeah ask questions and tread lightly.

title: Positive & Energetic Work Environment w/ Endless Career Potential
pros: Washington REIT provides a fast paced work environment for motivated individuals who are passionate and excited about their work. I’ve found the leadership to be inspiring and I would consider the company to have a collaborative open door policy. As the oldest publicly traded REIT in the country, the firm had a reputation for taking on that persona - until recently. That being said, I firmly believe that both the new CEO and new COO have done an excellent job at reversing the firm’s reputation in the industry and delivering bottom line results to investors that are attributable to the firm’s strategic direction and growth.
cons: None – it remains to be seen.

title: Best career choice I've ever made
pros: I've been at WashREIT for nearly a year. Everything from the interview process to the culture, to the teamwork and community have been outstanding. Even in this short time, I have learned so much and gained such incredible value from working with this dedicated team. WashREIT actually lives its core values - you have a voice, you're encouraged to lead, and you are motivated to excel. I am very blessed to be part of such an outstanding organization.
cons: With the complexity of the industry, there are many applications and services to learn about when coming on board. I think expanding the onboarding experience to educate people about these various systems would be beneficial in the long term.

title: Outstanding leadership
pros: The folks on the executive team are very thoughtful about the vision they have for the company and how they implement it. Transparent environment / lots of integrity from leadership. They're focused on doing what's right for the people. No hierarchy or bureaucracy, just a place where everyone collaborates and feels valued, and all ideas are welcomed and respected. HR dept. is incredible and unlike any I've seen, at other companies you'd need to spend $$$ externally to get the same level of professional coaching. Another huge plus is that the IT department is top notch and they constantly strive to make everyone's job easier and faster.
cons: None that I've encountered so far.

title: Smoke and Mirrors... be careful
pros: There weren't too many things I liked about the organization other than meeting some cool people. The bright minds tended to be younger and most often would leave eventually. The salary was competitive... but benefits were pretty meh.
cons: Probably the most bizarre place I've ever worked. The constant stress of project deadlines that were deemed urgent, micro-managers and directors, executives being extremely toxic and overall just a weird sense of everyone being on edge at all times. They say they care about employee well being, but in the end most of the people that stay for more than a few years are just 'yes' people who play the corporate game. Most of the bright young minds leave after a few years (rightfully so) I often had to bite my tongue in response to how my manager and director would speak to me when something wasn't working as expected. The WFH is a joke.. they say 6 days a month but that comes with caveats... no 2 days in a row, has to have manager approval, can't come before a holiday or after a weekend... it wasn't flexible at all. Additionally, every team is extremely under-staffed... the amount of project requests that would come in.. the team I worked within never had enough time to complete anything with real quality, as it was a mad rush to get it out the door. The firm was extremely wary of hiring more people, yet executive level salaries were insane... just food for thought. Unless you are unemployed or have no other job prospects, I'd carefully consider other opportunities. Obviously everyone's experience is different.. but in a nutshell this was the worst place I ever worked at (my perspective)

title: Good Entry Level Job
pros: Benefits are (were) the best I've experienced in the industry. Plus it's cool to say you work for the company that owns the "world's most famous building".
cons: So, I've had the privilege of working at a worse company and a company on par with (or a little better than) ESRT. If you're right out of college, looking for an entry level property management job to spend a couple of years at to get your resume going (because you will not get promoted, not matter how good you are. Rewarding good work or hiring from within is not their jam) you could do worse. The benefits are really good, actually. Although, they changed their bonus structure in order to deny or lower bonuses arbitrarily and they switched their insurance to a lower quality one right as I left, so I can't speak to how the benefits are now. Bottom line--you have to remember that this is a corporation in AMERICA, of all places. They don't care about you beyond if you're losing or making them money, no matter how many free bagel days or lunches they give you. At the end of the day, they will sell your building to make a buck and kick you to the curb with a backdated termination letter (so that they don't have to pay for your insurance, of course), a callous denial of severance (even though they gave all other buildings severance before you), and not even a thank you or goodbye meal (upper management didn't even email the people whose lives they were upending despite knowing them for 10+ years), whether you've worked there for 2 years or 20. In fact, you're probably treated better if you've only been there for 2 years because the CEO or whatever his nepo baby title is has some kind of obsession with Gen Z and doesn't respect lifers. And everyone is TERRIFIED of him so no one will fight on your behalf if they risk going against him. So, yeah. It's a fine place to work if you don't expect to get a lot out of it. You get good experience and meet good people but you'll most likely get stuck in your position with no hope of upward mobility.

title: Employee Review
pros: Landmark building. Great for a resume.
cons: No boundaries, no work/life balance, time is not respected, hard work is not appreciated, lots of blaming/finger pointing, zero support. Some teams have a big turnover for these reasons. You may have events and work 14+ days in a row. They do not give any additional time off in return. They offer a work from home policy, but working from home is frowned upon and not allowed on all teams.

title: Great Team, Great Leadership, Great Company
pros: The top level executives here listen to the employees and their concerns. Since joining the company about 4 years ago, I have watched our culture continuously improve. We are getting better and better and headed for great things. The core team here has some of the best individuals I have met over the course of my entire career- kind, loyal, dedicated and hard-working. We genuinely care about one another and help each other succeed.
cons: The environment can be fast- paced and stressful but this is not particular to the company- this is the real estate industry in general. We have many policies and protocols in place which can sometimes bog us down but overtime, I have watched us streamline our processes and consistently look for ways to improve. This is merely part of being a relatively new company establishing its best practices. The pro here is that management constantly seeks feedback and we all have a voice in shaping these policies.

title: Onward and Upward and Right Off The Top of the Rock
pros: Beautiful Historical Building Awesome part of Manhattan to spend the pre and post work hours Close numerous happy hours that help forget the mickey mouse operation that is ESRT (If they even let you out on time)
cons: Working here is like riding a bicycle. Except the bicycle is on fire, and you're on fire, and you're in hell. If you should be so fortunate to prove your worth on the job, prepare for the higher ups to serve you a buffet of inefficiency, incompetence, and ineffective management skills. If you can handle that, management may further ask you to unhinge your jaw and swallow a heaping plateful of responsibilities that you will get 0 credit for (but 100% of the blame if failed) and an all day special of empty promises. If I knew what I was getting myself into, I would've just thrown my body into traffic knowing that NYPD and the DoT would be able to take care of my corpse better than ESRT with my career.

title: Not worth the space on my resume.
pros: Basically, it sounds great to colleagues and ex-coworkers when you mention you work at the Empire State Building. There are tons of great retail stores and places to eat in the area.
cons: They have unrealistic expectations of the work to be performed. Management sets double standards for certain employees. All the executives do what they want when they want and you may get two different conflicting orders from two different executives. Even as a salary based paid employee, we are required to be tracked using a fingerprint scanner. Some departments are no help and you are blamed for work not completing on time or incorrectly done. The benefits are the worst I have ever had the "pleasure" of using. Asking for time off, you may be talked down to as if you are a 2 year old child be scolded for not going to the potty. When you mention this to someone in HR that you thought would help, nothing happens. Management and HR seems to ignore the problem because to them the issue is always with the lower level employees. No wonder a lot of people come and go through my department.

title: The Worst of the Worst
pros: It's almost over and I am finally moving on after 7 long years...
cons: Everything! Senior Management is horrible. They treat employees like pawns in a chess game, play favorites, if you are not a part of the inner circle, good luck getting a fair and decent pay increase or bonus. Stock options are not give to all employees but rather only those deemed by senior management to be "worth the investment". When employees ask “who qualifies for stock options?”, no one can give a straight answer. The HR department is the most unprofessional I have experienced in my 10+ career in real-estate industry. Incompetent, incapable, and completely useless. The HR department experienced nearly 100% turnover since 2015. Everyone with talent in that department left. Pay increases, bonuses and payroll is horrendous and run by an incompetent manager. There is a huge lack of union and employee knowledge within the HR department. As for the Operations and Finance Departments, they will work you 90+ hours a week and it’s still never good enough. Increases and bonuses are laughable in comparison to the hours worked. This has to be the worst REIT to work for. If I could rate them negative stars I would.

title: ESRT
pros: - Annual bonus (probably will be done away with for a while due to COVID - Each employee gets a free pass to the Observatory - Nice office space - Some really great people
cons: - Toxic environment - CEO runs the place like a dictator - It's a old boys club so women are not treated fairly. - Preferential treatment across the board - ESRT does not value talent and they have lost some really good people because the CEO doesn't care about anyone - They also do not pay fairly. The reward upper management handsomely but those who really do the work are not paid their worth - Inflated leadership team - Employees are fearful of the CEO and his arbitrary moods - Located in a bad area of Herald SQ. Extremely congested normally and a large homeless population.

title: King Kong with an Ego to match
pros: Agree that the company's talent at the mid and entry level is a huge asset.
cons: Thought IPO would transform the company into new thought leadership and direction. Not so. Guiding principles are more dictatorship than motivational. Cliche phrases used by top management have the opposite effect. Stop hiring friends as consultants to "expose" what's wrong with the company, instead ask for anonymous internal feedback and then don't retaliate if its not positive. Fear instilled in every employee with Jekyll and Hyde tactics. No ethics to speak of, the difference between what is right and wrong does not exist. Good hard working new employees burn out quick and start to be brainwashed into puppets and nobody can speak their minds on business concepts or direction that defies the leadership.

title: It’s the Tower of Terror
pros: The union pay and benefits
cons: Cynical, tyrannical, malevolent. I used to like this job. But now...? Everyone is miserable. Top to bottom. You’ve got a New York City land lord who behaves like Stalin but thinks he’s Walt Disney. Maybe he realizes he spent WAY too much money on “improvements “ and needs a scapegoat. Hospitality? If you’re interested in a career in hospitality avoid the Empire State Building. It isn’t about hospitality. It’s a real estate company. This is an awful place. I’m doing everything I can to get out. Everyone I know there is looking for a different job. I’ve never seen anything like it. I wouldn’t let a friend work here. It is a truly unhealthy horrible environment to work in. They believe that a frightened and unhappy staff is more easily managed. Their contempt for the staff isnt even concealed. To them I’m just an overpaid Neanderthal. It’s a mean spirited place. Avoid.

title: Awesome Company
pros: In my own experience I have found ESRT to be an under standing and enjoyable place to work. Almost all the employees enjoy their jobs and it shows in the work that is produced. It's rare that you have to work long hours and when you do it is generally recognized. I would say this is definitely a company that you can achieve a healthy work life balance at without sacrificing your career.
cons: Occasionally there is a disconnect between what would be best for the company and employees and what the actual company policies are. More flexibility for employees (work from home, no time clock, etc.) would result in higher productivity.

title: Needs work
pros: Great coworkers and decent pay and bonus.
cons: Senior leadership is reactive rather than proactive and have created an echo chamber of negativity. Be prepared to hear about the things you do wrong and none of the things you do right. This is an oppressive work atmosphere with a top down management style. Senior leadership generally does not interact with front line teams and does not understand that this is a hospitality organization that needs to run on kindness. You need to reap what you sow.

title: Depends on what you're looking for.....
pros: If you prefer a monotonous repetitive work environment this is the place for you. However, there are some great hardworking people here in various departments who have a lot to offer.
cons: If you are looking for an innovative company with opportunity for advancement LOOK ELSEWHERE. The egos of micro managers stifle performance and overall employee happiness. There has been high turnover here especially during the IPO transition. The merging of management styles between portfolio properties created an imbalance in company culture, clash of egos, and an overall mess.

title: Focused and growing company with great people
pros: Great people, location, prestige and learning experience. There's been a lot of internal growth in all departments, especially this year. Excellent benefits and compensation package. High energy and very talented coworkers, and managers are genuinely interested in their employees' growth.
cons: The 401k match is low, somewhat big egos from senior leaders, no stock options for employees, no rollover vacation, NO FLEXIBILITY

title: Happy to be here
pros: I began my journey with ESRT during COVID-19. The company has done a remarkable job with my onboarding and engagement during an impossible time. I am appreciative of how welcoming colleagues were - even while I was meeting them virtually. The company is full of hard working individuals who are very passionate about their work. We have been on partial in-office and remote work and the company has gone above and beyond to make employees feel safe while back in the office. I am happy to be a part of this team and continue to learn more about the industry daily.
cons: I do not have any to currently share.

title: Image but no substance
pros: Great people work here....but not in high positions
cons: See below (you'll see what I mean)

title: Once right, Keep It Moving, Onward and Upward.
pros: If you want to hear "once right" and "onward and upward" 600 times a day while being verbally assaulted by senior management then look no further than ESRT. Generous severance packages depending on if you're liked or if the company is afraid you will sue when you leave.
cons: Zero growth, horrible management, verbal assaults by the CEO in front of peers. Females are under represented among senior management and are disrespected and mistreated. Requirements to succeed - Age 50+, Caucasian, willing to play puppet, and lack of common sense with a scent of entitlement.

title: IT Security Manager
pros: Company is on the move and seem to care about their employees. Great social activities and expect to have a good time with ESRT employees. If your looking to move along in a fast paced company this may be your calling. If you are lucky enough you might even have a chance to work with the great people in accounting, or with such leaders as Christopher Blackman, Ryan Klass, Keith Cody, Shanae Urisini, Rodney Gomes, or the amazing Tom Keltner. Tom, had to be one of the most amazing people I have ever worked with. You will work hard at ESRT, but your day will go fast.
cons: Retirement allocations / options / company match is below what most companies contribute today, or at least what ESRT competitors match. The ESRT Retirement program desperately needs a revamp which will help the avg paid employee. However, a bonus might make up the difference if (underline if) you happen to be in the right level position. So keep that in mind if you are not a manager/director. Use of personal credit card No Remote access / Work from home policy

title: Growth In the Right Direction
pros: I've been with ESRT for about a year now, serving in a variety of different capacities that have allowed me to witness multiple facets of what it's like to be an employee here. In my experience, there are two pros that stand out the most that have made it a great place to work for me: 1. A Challenging Environment - As mentioned in some of the other reviews here, when you put yourself out there at ESRT, you are rewarded with increasing professional and educational opportunities. I have found that management has consistently challenged me to go above and beyond and learn new things in my professional life. I've been given the opportunity to take great initiative on projects despite not being here for that long, simply because I've spoken up about wanting to be more involved. There are many opportunities for growth here at ESRT and professional improvement is actively encouraged by management. I have yet to be bored here. Obviously, this can vary by department, but I can say that I have been met with overwhelming support and encouragement from management in my department to grow professionally since I started here. 2. Increasingly Receptive Management - I have played witness to a good amount of institutional change here over the last year, all of which has ultimately been very encouraging to see as an employee. Management has been making an increasing effort to listen and respond to the concerns and desires of employees, which has manifested in a steadily growing number of "office perks" and the founding of a Culture Committee, as well as a general feeling of an overall culture shift within the organization as management learns to be a bit more relaxed and open to trying new things. Within the span of a year, I feel like management has gone from being very stuffy, close-minded, and out-of-touch to really being in touch with employees and actively engaged in finding new ways to improve the experience of working here at ESRT, which has been great to see and very reassuring. Aside from the aforementioned, I have also had a very positive experience with the work environment itself, and the people who work here. The job respects a work-life balance, the people are incredibly friendly and passionate about what they do, and the office itself is very upscale and conducive to collaboration and interaction among employees. I really do enjoy coming here every day!
cons: Despite its recent progress, the organization is still very reliant on a top-down style of management which has allowed a very bureaucratic environment to thrive. My main frustrations with working here stem from: 1. A Heavy Dependence on Email - My inbox is inundated around the clock thanks to a culture of reliance on email as a primary mode of communication. Slack is not a universally-used application in our office, nor do we use any other sort of IM service for communication. I think this is definitely something that could be improved on in order to reduce inbox clutter and increase efficiency. 2. Lengthy Approval Processes - As I said above, the bureaucracy of the organization is most apparent when trying to accomplish tasks that require several levels of approval. It is understandable to have procedures in place to reduce the company's liability, however there is a such thing as too much. It is not uncommon to spend a great amount of time on a project only for it to be stymied by lengthy approval processes.

title: Good Pay / Bad Vibes
pros: Great pay and benefits package
cons: Hosts are undervalued and treated as replaceable. There aren’t any options for progression. All supervisors are sourced out - meaning most don’t have the knowledge that a lot of the staff have. The building is frustrating and inefficient. There are no women in supervisor positions. There is a “boys club” atmosphere where men frequently talk about the attractiveness of the female guests and employees. They’ve used derogatory terms to refer to female guests and employees.

title: Senior level employee
pros: Excellent working environment, employees are motivated, senior level employees are very competent and provide excellent guidance to their subordinates. Company is very considerate of its employees' needs and is responsive. Very good company to work for.
cons: It may take a little time to get used to our our open office space (for those who have previously not worked in that type of office). However, the ease of interaction with colleagues and our modern office space including conference rooms far outweighs any period of acclimatization.

title: The worst company you’ll ever work for
pros: Great colleagues that are some of the best in the industry
cons: Insane top down management style. Does not treat employees like people and spends more time trying to punish employees rather than help them succeed in their positions. You can do hundreds of good things and be excellent at your job, but one slip up could cost you your job without any other considerations. A constant feeling of walking on eggshells, 11th hour decisions from upper management, and a serious lack of direction.

title: Great place to work
pros: Loved working at ESRT, it’s a great place to learn. Everyone is always willing and happy to teach/mentor if you’re willing to learn. Senior management has done a lot to improve the culture and seems to truly care about their employees through the implementation of various programs like flex work, flex fridays, enhanced benefits.. etc Had a great experience here and would recommend the company to all.
cons: Difficult to grow quickly must be willing to be patient

title: Sucks the life out of you
pros: It's really cool to work for the owners of the Empire State Building. Great networking opportunities. Great name for resume.
cons: Sucks the life out of you. Expected to work 'round the clock. Overworked and underpaid. Increased workload every year and have to beg for a decent raise. Low company morale. High turnover.

title: Good people but bad management!
pros: Really nice people! The people you work with are the best thing about being employed at ESRT.
cons: Management is not really flexible. Moving up is a rare thing at ESRT if you do you must be a favorite or a money maker but it takes everyone to make a company run not just a select few.

title: Onward and Upward
pros: Over the past few years, I've seen a shift in management for the better. They are implementing changes to display their appreciation for their employees. While no company is perfect, ESRT is aiming to provide a welcoming and more productive workplace. -Mgmt challenges you to become more well rounded and build upon your skills by taking courses and joining committees. -Newly implemented initiatives have brought up company morale: Casual Days, Gratitude Fridays, and Flex/Summer Fridays.
cons: -No work-from-home program -Lengthy Approval Processes

title: Great Place to Learn from the Best and Contribute!
pros: A forward-thinking, highly-successful company comprised of the industry's leading experts and foremost professionals. Passionate, caring and hard-working staff who strive for excellence. Collaborative, creative work environment.
cons: Requires high-level skill set and strong work ethic to succeed--which is not a negative if you are willing to work hard and contribute unique value.

title: Tyrannical Totalitarianism at its Best!
pros: Culture, what culture? If tyrannical totalitarianism is the culture you are striving for, this is the company to work for! The individuals working at the Empire State Building and its Observatory are some of the most talented professionals in the industry. Their other properties... not so much.
cons: HR, like most professions, values ethical principles. People are the most important asset of an organization but also its biggest potential liability. One would assume that HR is ethically responsible for promoting and fostering fairness and justice for all employees throughout the organization; however, ESRT’s disparate, discriminatory, and retaliatory practices make HR’s position within the organization obsolete. The greatest liabilities in the organization are the individuals in charge of running it. The top-heavy tyrannical executive office is compiled of “bosses” not “leaders” (all of whom hate each other and refuse to communicate with each other). As Human Capital professionals and culture champions, you know something is deeply wrong with an organization when 80% of the HR department leaves in 6 months to go work for the company’s biggest competitors. The executive office chalks employee resignations up to those resigning as being “bad employees”. If resignations were coming from “bad employees”, I doubt your competitors would be hiring them at double their salaries. When resigning, expect to get shunned from senior management. It is pointless to put in 2 weeks’ notice. During the notice period, not a single person on the senior management team acknowledges your existence. My advice to existing staff is – Get out while you still have what’s left of your morals and dignity. Competitors are looking for your talent and are willing to equitability compensate you for it. My advice to prospective employees is – Unless you’re taking a position making $300K+ a year, its best to keep it moving. Even at $300K a year, employees are dropping like flies.

title: Hypocritical management that creates a borderline toxic environment
pros: Environmentally
cons: cious, the OBS is cool, there are some decent projects if you're lucky

title: Happy To have left
pros: You will gain a lot of experience here as they throw many projects and assignments at their staff. You will also develop tough skin.
cons: Management places unrealistic expectations on staff with limited or no direction. They are constantly under staffed which leads to a tense work environment.

title: Tenant Services Coordinator
pros: Reality of this workplace? Better off playing in traffic if you don't have a family to feed.
cons: No one has your back, office morale...nil. Hopefully their investors get wind of the brutal dictatorship & horrible management skills because it's all a farse & a sham bunch of cover-up activity to make this once respected family business a modern day slavery ship full of brown nosers.

title: Great Company
pros: Empire State Realty Trust (ESRT) is a great company. I am thankful to be a part of a company that supports me, guides me, and allows me to implement my charitable ideas through our ESRT Volunteer Committee.
cons: No cons at this time.

title: "Great Company"

I was able to work on a variety of interesting projects throughout my time at ESRT and learned from some of the most knowledgeable professionals in the industry. I would highly recommend working here.
cons: Not applicable to my experience.

title: Must be extremely hard working
pros: Some of the smartest and hardest working people work here, great new office, lots of additional perks if you work in certain departments, great pay

title: Stay
pros: The guests; Majority of them are very nice and it feels good to share the Experience with them. The Pay is decent to good depends on the person.
cons: Almost EVERYTHING THERE IS A CON. POOR MANAGEMENT ( some needs training and some would be better off elsewhere in the Fast Food Industry) LACK OF COMMUNICATION, MEDIEVAL RULES ( make you feel less human, there is a write up for almost everything: Adults wearing pants with no pockets, and they told you is because staff tends to put their hands inside meanwhile a supervisor walking by with a baby Mohawk hair cut. Some of the female supervisors need to be dressed more appropriate to the company standard no sneakers or Huggs boots (maybe on a snow day) and show the guests that they CARE because they are asking us but they are not doing it. BASICALLY ALL THE COMPANY CARES ABOUT IS TAKING THE GUESTS MONEY. UNDER-STAFF you have a 120 mins waiting time and you expect one host to do 3 hosts jobs in return your TRIP ADVISOR reviews will not be what you expected it to be but then again you surprised with the results and Blamed the Hosts when you should have hired or scheduled more people. One more thing is sometime you have a host spending the entire day there from early on until closing 2 AM after when scientifically proven after 12 hours the human brain is totally disconnected and is just on ROBOTIC MODE. Then you have the nerve to tell the hosts not to sound like a robot. The Employee are not set up to SUCCEED, they are set up to fail. January weather forecast 9 degrees windshield in minus you have a guard out in front with all face covered totally ridiculous. FAMILY MEMBER WORKING IN MANAGEMENT AND COVERING FOR EACH OTHER.

title: Fantastic Year to Be an ESRT Employee
