title: Meaningful Work That Makes a Difference
pros: Working at Howard Hughes is rewarding because the company is deeply committed to making a positive impact in the communities it develops. There’s a strong emphasis on thoughtful, sustainable growth and giving back through philanthropic efforts, which makes the work feel purposeful. It’s inspiring to be part of projects that don’t just build properties but create lasting value for residents and businesses. The company takes stewardship seriously, investing in green space, cultural initiatives, and community programs. If you want to be part of a team that prioritizes impact over just development, this is a great place to be.
cons: While the work itself is meaningful, there’s room for improvement when it comes to leadership and internal communication. At times, the company’s specific business objectives can feel unclear, and more transparency from leadership would help employees feel more aligned with long-term goals. Strengthening internal communications could also help reinforce the company culture, ensuring that employees across all teams feel connected and engaged in the bigger picture.

title: Great Company!
pros: A fantastic company to work for, offering competitive salaries and excellent benefits.
cons: I don’t know of any cons.

title: Terrible and disappointing experience
pros: Beautiful office space and free lunch.
cons: Executive level leadership over the team I worked on was oblivious, This particular leader of my team was demanding and flat out rude and had zero leadership skills. They talk about their BRICK values with R standing for RESPECT. Yet, this particular person only had respect for herself using foul language and bully tactics. Had a lot to say but not a clue on how to run a successful and thriving team. C-Suite doesn't seem to care and just enables the behavior. There is a deep dysfunction in the workplace. I am impressed at how well they do financially when the actual work environment l worked in was extremely toxic. Most people are unhappy. A lot of broken promises and you will be over worked and underpaid. Don't bother giving feedback because the powers that be think they know everything even though their department is a revolving door and continues to crumble. A LOT of gossiping in HR amongst one another - no confidentiality. The list goes on and on. Such a toxic and disappointing experience.

pros: The benefits and pay are good.
cons: Work-life balance in some departments is hard due to the workload.

title: Bad company - needs change in leadership
pros: Nice office space and location
cons: The CFO displayed unprofessional behavior and made commitments during the interview process that were not fulfilled after joining. Leadership style tends to be overly aggressive, which affects team morale. The business struggles with direction and overall employee experience is below expectations.

title: Salary
pros: new york location is good.
cons: low pay - horrible management

title: Great company
pros: Good pay and health insurance.
cons: No cons that I'm aware of.

title: Great Company
pros: Great culture, and good involvement in deals and projects.
cons: They need a better compensation package.

title: Culture inclusion company
pros: Great benefits, with culture inclusion
cons: Health insurance can be cheaper, work from home more often

title: Freelance
pros: Friendly-ish team at least to face, mellow atmosphere at office
cons: No support, no assistance, poor communication, lack of direction and vision to reach goals

title: Bad managers
pros: Pay great pay, great perks
cons: VP management and up does not care about the employees

title: Not great
pros: Co-workers were good, HR was accessible
cons: Managers were awful, supervisors were not great as well. Pay was not competitive for as much as you are required to cowtow to the guests.

title: run away!!
pros: free lunch when the office staff is in the office.
cons: Very hostile place to work, can't trust the human resource team, new managers are making things worse.

title: grest
pros: good place to work for beginner
cons: fast pace place for work

title: Room for improvement
pros: Hybrid schedule, pay, benefits, flexibility
cons: Poor management, inclusivity of others thoughts and ideas, favoritism amongst the employees

title: Good environment
pros: Great company culture and they have a lot of room for growth within the company (if you wait). Good work life balance typically. Motivated management/employees.
cons: It can be difficult to secure a promotion. They seem to undervalue some skills and even if you fit a job description well they may try to hold you to your position for another year or two (unless you move into a completely new position/department). Also some managers and departments have different standards and will allow different luxuries. Such as working from home 2 days a week vs some departments only in office every other week. Some people are remote altogether while their colleagues are required to be onsite 3 days a week.

title: Great company to work for~
pros: Paid lunches, great management team, flexible work hours
cons: None so far that I can think of

title: HH is Great!
pros: Amazing benefits, co-workers, and office.
cons: Depending on your role/manager there can be challenges,

title: Good company
pros: Good benefits and work life balance
cons: None that i can think of

title: Great company!
pros: Great benefits , great people, great atmosphere, all around a great place to work!
cons: Currently no cons to report

title: Great Place to Grow
pros: Working here has been an absolute pleasure. The executive team and management I have worked with all want the best for their employees and see the bigger picture outside of being a real estate developer. They offer incredible employee benefits, perks that make coming to work much better, a hybrid schedule to support work/life, a fun atmosphere, and challenging but all the more rewarding work. They put a lot of emphasis on highlighting that each role at HH plays an important part in the company's success, which makes employees feel appreciated and valued.
cons: None in particular; very happy with my role and the support from my management.

title: Great Company Overall
pros: Company Culture and people. Amazing executive staff (very down to earth) Opportunities for growth.
cons: Not to many cons I can think of... Just a lack of communication within my team at times.

title: Frequent Upper Management Changes
pros: Hybrid, nice office, lunches provided
cons: Frequent changes in upper management and direction of IT department

title: Good place to work
pros: Flexible, upper management is great.
cons: No cons working here for long.

title: Lots of opportunity
pros: Progressive management who are open to feedback and ideas.
cons: None that I've identified so far.

title: Incompetence Lives at Home
pros: The pay was alright. The ambition was fine.,
cons: Too many cooks that weren't in the kitchen but nonetheless felt as though they should be.

title: Changes
pros:
Lunches paid by company every day
Hybrid schedule
cons:
Work life balance
Company-wide communication

title: Great Company
pros: Cares about employees, great benefits
cons: I’m certain there are some, but can’t come up with anything

title: Good until it wasn't
pros: Great support when starting off.
cons: The Seaport and especially the Tin Building team are a bunch amateurs. HR was like a typical mean girls club. No respect for confidentiality and only there to protect leadership.

title: Mediocre at best.
pros: They pay every two weeks.
cons: Zero work life balance, heavy politics within, minimal promotion or room for growth, lack of HR involvement to what’s appropriate or not in the work place.

title: Good Foundation
pros: Hughes invested time providing a good skills foundation.
cons: Wasn't competitive paying their employees.

title: HHC for the Long Term
pros: Exciting atmosphere, employee focused company, focus on internal promotions, ability to transfer to other departments/regions, great benefits
cons: High intensity, fast paced environment, many rules and regulations due to being a public company, many employees have been at the company a long time which limits upward movement

title: Lots of Learning Opportunities
pros: Diverse opportunities to learn and grow professionally
cons: Limited salary potential at this company

title: Great place to work!
pros: Howard Hughes offers incredible benefits for employees and employee programs!
cons: I do not have any cons at this time.

title: The best company I have ever worked for!
pros: Amazing company and culture, interesting work, great people.
cons: Long hours, small windows where my tile can actually take PTO.

title: Great Company
pros: Great people, great organization. Well positioned for growth
cons: I really can't think of any

title: Toxic with High Turnover - Stay Away
pros: Attractive Galleria location. Frequent "Ordering-In" of dinner (explained below), and jean fridays.
cons: Extremely high turnover in the Accounting / Finance area (especially Corporate office). No work life balance. Unfortunately, accomplishment is measured on how many hours you put in (not the actual work performed). Dinner is ordered in just about every night and it's a big deal if you leave before 7pm (this is considered early). Employee morale is as low as I've witnessed at any organization of this size. Most people who are still hanging around are just waiting for their share grants to vest before they bolt. The joke of the place is that it's akin to Shawshank Prison (yes the movie). Existing employees actually joke when they see new hires join the team as they take bets on how many weeks the new person will last. **Last note - the financial systems are disjointed relics of the past. Running legacy software that is over 15 years old. It's really nothing short of a circus. If you are a candidate thinking of joining HHC, join at your own risk. My advice would be to make sure you ask them very detailed questions during the interview (and don't accept an offer until they let you interview with a couple peer level employees). Ask them pointed questions about the high rate of turnover (i.e.make them explain and defend it). Hope I can save some bright candidates from making a career move they'll soon regret.

title: Great Potential, Needs to Improve on Execution
pros: There are plenty of smart, talented people working for the company with a great pipeline of projects to work on. It is clear that the company is making strides to build a true company culture with the incredible effort put into Brand Marketing and People & Culture in the last two years. Shows that they are constantly looking to improve employee engagement with initiatives such as Hello Day and Discovery Tour.
cons: In many ways, the company is still being run like a start up. The lack of processes (or illogical ones with 15 hoops to jump through) has crippled execution. When you are new, or even have been there for several years, and ask what certain processes are, you just get shoved around to several different departments with no definitive answer. Senior leadership needs to step up and set these in place. There is also no unified platform for employees to effectively communicate or share files (not even Slack), something they keep saying they're working on. Depending on your boss and dept, there can be a serious lack of work life balance in New York office.

title: A- Culture and B+ Management and Business Process
pros: On one hand this company tries to embrace a forward thinking culture and for the most part they do. On the other hand, some of the executives are stuck in the past with old ways of thinking. The executive team in Dallas seems to be open to hearing your ideas. There are great benefits, some of the best I have seen. If you do you work, there is not much to complain about. There is a new monthly huddle for the whole office where everyone is updated on projects. Beer on Fridays is nice.
cons: Many of the issues that I have encountered are no different from every other company I have worked for. The office decor needs improvement and is cramped. Not very inspiring - specially for the corporate office of "most creatively driven real estate company".

title: It’s okay, it’s a good for a step to use to in your career
pros: Fast money, fast environment. Good for students to work at.
cons: No chance to grow, unequal work environment, micromanaging and bad management

title: Don't take the bait.
pros: Several very talented, dedicated people work here and those relationships are the biggest value. There is some creative freedom but that is mostly because of lack of direction from internal stakeholders. Good snacks, free drinks and all the other usual comforts but that is pretty standard these days.
cons: Totally chaotic with very little synergy between departments. Any ideas are the bare minimum of creative with a "throw it over the fence" mentality and ambition is heavily discouraged. It's been described as a "start-up environment" but that is just a way to dress up lack of strategy and low standards. Any attempt at departmental leadership comes off as clearly feigned and people are set up to fail constantly. Tonally it feels like you're working in finance and any perks of the office being pretty is clearly for clients, not employees. HHC tries in New York to be culturally relevant but often fails because there is very little creativity in its DNA. Across their other national locations (Dallas, Hawaii, Summerlin) HHC doesn't try to be something they're not and they do much better.

title: A company doing things right - understanding the "why" and innovatively executing their goals and dreams
pros: The culture of the company is just outstanding in that there IS one, and that this culture is one that says "hello". I joined BECAUSE of the promise of such a culture, and they certainly delivered. Everyone here cares deeply and passionately about the work that they do, the people that they work with, and it's amazing that they understand the importance of collaboration, innovation and having the know-how that it takes to succeed. The company focuses on its people - nurturing growth and empowering individuals to learn and do more.
cons: So far, the only downside I can speak of is that there are no current plans for a major master plan community development in Dallas yet! Other than that, Howard Hughes Corporation is a great place to work at and I look forward to learning and doing more myself.

title: Stay Away
pros: The salary. They will offer you a higher than average salary, but the hours worked are not worth it. You will be exposed to everything encompassing accounting to be able to put on your resume to help you get a new job. I’m not sure why we have other departments when it’s apparently Property Accountings responsibility.
cons: The hours. The amount of hours you will work will have your hourly rate close to or less than minimum wage. There is no work/life balance. Management says to bring concerns to them, but nothing will change for the good. The changes made only create more work and add stress. Constant changes that are not communicated. No one does everything the same. One person can be told to do it this way because that’s what they want, but it is not communicated to the group. Managers that don’t know what they’re doing. Everything falls on Property Accounting so be ready to take the blame. No one has answers for the proper way to complete tasks which leads to things being done incorrectly and management doesn’t seem to care. If you’re smart enough to be reading this then be smart enough to not even apply.

title: Great Place to Work!
pros: I've been at HHC for almost 2 years and the opportunities are endless. With our new leadership, the CEO and Chief People Officer have created an environment of inclusivity and the culture has shifted in a positive way under this new leadership and direction. My direct manager has always been open and receptive to my ideas and initiatives and welcomed me to spearhead projects and take ownership. I am empowered to speak my mind and voice my ideas to others in senior leadership. There is a part of accountability here that every employee should exercise, if you have an idea, or passion project, speak up, bring statistics/ facts, and leadership will give you the opportunity to execute. Do not wait to be called on!
cons: The organization is a little over 10 years old. In the past 10 years, the company has shifted to keep up with the real estate development market. Under the newest leadership the company is in a more stable place than ever.

title: Lip Service
pros: Space to learn and grow. Flexible with schedule. Friendly people and environment.
cons: Treated employees terribly when it mattered most. The Chairman and the two CEOs that were running the company while I was there spoke incessantly about how important the people of the company are. But when Covid hit, they used whatever means that were available to them to not take care of the people they laid off. The corporation likes to boast about how much cash it has on hand. It would've been nice to be paid a severance for the years of service we all gave to the company, especially during such a difficult time. Moving forward, they should stop telling their employees how important they are because it's a lie. There was also an issue with nepotism at the company.

title: A Great Company All Around
pros: The Howard Hughes Corporation has a small company feel but operates on a larger scale. The team leaders are open to your feedback and ideas. Its very fast paced and there is always something to do. Its a great place to flex your wings and really show what you are capable of and in turn get to learn from your coworkers. The majority of the people who work in my office are extremely hardworking but easy going and there is always something exciting going on around the office. The benefit package is amazing. We have tuition reimbursement, great discounts. Its definitely a great place to come to everyday.
cons: The company is growing exponentially and space is becoming an issue. It may be time for a new office.

title: Cheers to all my good memories!
pros: ros people culture employee cohesion and work ethic, company vision and direction.
cons: It's not what you know, it's who you know. For 4 years I thought I found my dream job and I was working for the best company ever . So I always went above and beyond and I always went the extra mile. Coworker became like family and I thought I will retired in this company. Until we got a new manager. From day one, the person had so much hate against me. Turning his face when he sees me . first time in my life I felt different and I saw how some people discriminate. And yes one wrong person can make you hate your job and just give up the relationship that you built for years with the company and all your dreams.well I moved on, one door closed and another opened.

title: Unprofessional and morally bad executives
pros: The only benefit to working here is the good name, which conceals how unprofessional this company is. But quickly, the industry is picking up on how bad Howard Hughes is in NYC, and it's getting a bad reputation.
cons: The executives at this company are running it into the ground. They are extremely young kids, with zero communication skills, zero knowledge, zero expertise, and zero teamwork skills. They just order all the lower people around, spinning them in circles with contradictory or not enough information. Then, when everything goes wrong (which it always does) they just blame the lower people. They have no clue how to run a company. The New York office is NOT profitable. The company just doesn't go under because OTHER cities make a profit and generate revenue. My boss is the worst person I've ever worked for in life.

title: Insane workloads, big egos and bad company culture. Do not recommend!
pros: A good place if you're looking for a fast-paced job and not a long-term career. Opportunities to get thrown into the fire and manage/learn a lot.
cons: Awful company culture, despite some failed internal effort to change it. Most employees here are openly miserable and desperately job searching. Egos galore!!! Major disconnect between cross-functioning teams. Insane workloads. Bad office vibes. All about who you know and not what you know. A lot of smoke and mirrors. Bad leadership. Terrible management, uninterested in helping their employees grow. ZERO process throughout the organization. No logic in the way things work, and no real openness to implement process. Insane deadlines. Bad work-life-balance. Old-school company with old mentalities-- Men often talk-over women in meetings, women struggle to gain respect or climbing the ladder. Employees don't respect each other or their leaders, a lot of drama and bad-talking. Unbelievable amount of turn-over!

title: Beware of Significant Uncertainty
pros: Decent work environment, pay/benefits and it’s a big publicly traded company
cons: Company has been exploring strategies to increase shareholder value, including a sale of company. Very high risk to take a job right now or stick around because the jobs could be gone very soon. Still, this “strategic review” likely was only done to get shareholders off the backs of management and to briefly pump the stock price. It’s been nearly 3 months since they announced the review and haven’t said a peep. After 3 months employees and shareholders deserve an update.

title: Depends on where you work/who you work for
pros: - A small and growing company so depending on your position and which office you work out of, there’s a lot of room for growth and autonomy - Really stepped up the benefits package in the past year - Smart and genuinely good people
cons: -The closer you are (personally) to top leadership, the better for you (in some cases to the point of nepotism). Makes it hard for emerging employees to make a difference -Top leadership is involved in everything so it can make small projects and processes drag on -Business and creative teams are often at odds which also slows things down -Can be superficial in some of their endeavors; a lot of talk and not much action - “unsexy” projects will get much less attention even if they are the moneymakers

title: Just meh.
pros: Compensation was good. They finally got stand-up desks and they go over the top on their town halls. There are a lot of initiatives they promote. They started a monthly stand-up for employees. It seems ok. A good way to get updates and ask questions of leadership.
cons: They don't have outside of the office get-togethers. Only "family" event is the holiday party in December, and that's where you have your +1. Leadership keeps trying to champion change, but it only seems to be marketed to new hires. No real action. They have their favorites employees, and everyone knows who they are. Leaders (Director level and above) talk badly about each other in front of lower-level employees.

title: Great place, worked there for 4 years!
pros: I started at the company right out of high school and stayed until covid hit. The woodlands resort as well as the Westin in the woodlands are wonderful Howard Hughes properties that offer great opportunity. The work place is very professional where you're treated as family. If you show dedication there's a lot of opportunity to move up as well. Management has always been lovely to work with and the benefits are really good too.
cons: The only con I felt was that upper management got switched up every couple of years and brought on significant change that was at times at the expense of certain parties and took some time to adapt to, but that's really anywhere. Can't think of any other cons!

pros: You receive discount on some amenities, but other than that small tidbit there isn't much to brag about.
cons: Toxic HR department as well as most of management. I gave my two weeks notice, showed up for the entire 14 days and did my work as usual and then I was marked as a no show for my last day. I didn't find out until the next summer when I applied to come back I was marked as unhireable. Not a fan of most of the management there, they don't really care about their employees.

title: Started Good, Ended Poorly
pros: Overall I would say I am grateful for the time and learning experiences I had at Howard Hughes. I was able to work on some pretty extensive projects and collaborate with people all across the company. I am grateful for my manager, they made working at HHC fun and always did their best to advocate for our team. Before the pandemic, I was able to travel quite a lot both for work and training. During my time there I also connected with a handful of pretty amazing people who genuinely wanted to make a difference in the world.
cons: When I first started at Howard Hughes I was over the moon excited. I was experiencing that "honeymoon phase" at a new job where everything is just amazing. However, that started to fade out as I soon realized that actions spoke louder than words. The main reason why I left was that I was looking for career growth. My current role was not providing me the room to expand my experience or push my skill set to the max. Another reason I left was I essentially lived in fear of losing my job for over a year and a half for many reasons and to no fault of my own. – In June 2019 the company wanted to be purchased which meant looming potential layoffs if we merged with another company. – When no one wanted to buy the company they did a round of layoffs just before Thanksgiving and another just before the Holidays. – In March 2020 mainly due to COVID-19 they did another round of layoffs. I was fortunate to survive 3 rounds of layoffs, but it was scary waking up every day not knowing if I was next. Lastly, the culture is not what it is promised to be. Politics and Cliques run deep on every level in almost every region, and not just with senior leadership. Anything embarrassing, goofy, or silly you say or do can and will be used against you even months after it happened.

title: Nice benefits, nice working environment, good people
pros: The benefits are really good and most of the individuals are knowledgeable and helpful. Lots of Corporate "bonding" events. Work/life balance is good. Pay is excellent.
cons: Lack of communication between departments. Lots of politics. Letting people go suddenly and not letting other employees know what is happening, i.e., restructuring of department, change in vision, lack of profits or general layoff. Sometimes uneasy feeling and fear of unknown.

title: "Leadership" that doesn't Lead.
pros: Young, dynamic, fast growing company with many benefits and perks...if you're lucky enough to have the time to enjoy them.
cons: The "vibe" of any company trickles down from the top. Insecure, narcissistic leadership cannot be the foundation for a happy and productive staff. They talk a good talk when it comes to recruiting and retention, but the proof is in the pudding: High turnover, Negative undertones throughout.

title: Toxic
pros: Lots of opportunity to learn; most people are a pleasure to work with; throws good parties
cons: Unhealthy culture; cronyism running rampant; executive management has entrepreneurial mindset - lacks clear direction/structure (Good for a start up but not a 5+ year old public company. Is this mindset hindering their ability to be more successful long-term in Corporate America? Time will tell.)

title: Mediocre, but with potential
pros: Great people, wonderful benefits, they have a really great appreciation of employees. They also spend freely on the latest business tools, education and training.
cons: There is a culture of passing the buck so that there is always one crisis after the other because nobody wants to be responsible for making a decision. Also, you would think with the Howard Hughes branding you would have Class A assets.... Like I said, mediocre at best.

title: Fast Pace : Awesome Place
pros: Many opportunities to succeed. Training is available if you want it. Benefits are incredible.
cons: Very demanding environment and lots of stress Directions can be vague and hard to understand the goals. You are responsible for many activities which can stretch you pretty thin.

title: Fun Perks, Bad Work Enviornment
pros: -Fun work events and out of office opportunities -Free snacks and beautiful office views -Certain amount of creative freedom
cons: Toxic work environment. Most employees are openly miserable, place blame and are rude to one another. Terrible management structure with little to no support or project management. The company has gone through mass layoffs leaving employees with a constant fear of losing their jobs.

title: Sr. Desktop & System Engineer
pros: Fair wages and decent benefits, and a few friendly people.
cons: The company is still young and growing, so there is some turnover as they try to get there footing. The different groups (creative vs executive) in the NY location and the management in Dallas are at times at odds and it can lead to pressure situations that are unnecessary with better communication.

title: This job has been a big disappointment.
pros: I love the location in the waterway in the Woodlands. I enjoy most of my co-workers and my immediate supervisors are cool.
cons: Upper management is a joke and don't know how to run an upscale hotel. They don't value employees. Many have quit and things still don't change. Money is very bad.

title: Great Company / No Employee Loyalty
pros: Howard Hughes is overall a great company. They are growing rapidly and the CEO is a very smart man.
cons: There is no loyalty to employees that have been with the company for several years. Rather than promote from within, they'd rather lay off and change the title to hire someone new.

title: Personal thoughts
pros: Employees are treated with respect, based on my observations they are considered to be a very important asset. Senior Management is approachable. There are lots of opportunities to learn and grow within the organization.
cons: There is too much food... So hard to stay true to a diet.. :)..

title: Great Benefits but....
pros: Benefits offered by the company are great
cons: Absolutely no flexibility for remote work options

title: Management lacking "leadership" skills.
pros: A few great coworkers, some decent perks, not too much overtime.
cons: Leadership simply waiting for retirement, thus no interest in developing staff into future leaders. Minimal communication between staff and management.

title: Rewards Performance
pros: HHC provides upward mobility to people who perform. Regardless of experience level or qualifications if you perform well there's potential for career advancement. If you are able to get in and show your value you will be rewarded.
cons: The work environment can be demanding. Be prepared to be "on" most all the time with an expectation to be available at home or on vacation. This ebbs and flows based on projects and work flow, but if having uninterrupted time is important you be wary.

title: Accounting
pros: Hard working group that works hard to get the job done. Intuitive and always looking for new ways to get things done.
cons: Top executives have no concern for the hard working employees that keep the company running. Lots of egos from all levels. Management does not manage titles appropriate to skill level.

title: Figuring out what it wants to be
pros: A sustainable model for long-term revenue with its MPC's. Strives for employee satisfaction. Secure financial standing and not over leveraged.
cons: Struggles to inspire employees with the work outside of the visions of grandeur regarding South Street Seaport which the majority of the employees of the company will never get to see.

title: Actions speak louder than words
pros: The company has some lofty ideals about what it could one day be - if only it tried to embody those words. Compensation and benefits are on par for the industry. The New York office has a beautiful view.
cons: We can learn a lot about a company from the way it has handled the COVID-19 crisis. HHC chose to let go of most of its employees, and then send them an email bragging about a "generous donation" made to a charity that "is prepared to provide financial assistance with rent, mortgage, utility and food" while acknowledging that this charity provides no individual grants and this donation is functionally useless to the jobless employees fearful for their families' futures. To add insult to injury, attached to the email was instructions on how to apply for food stamps. This is typical of operations of this company. The white, male leadership makes unilateral, ill-advised decisions without regard for the advice of those hired to help them steer the company in the right direction. Middle management acts as a barrier between the employees and leadership. Communication is a failure at every level: meetings are held to distribute old, contradictory, or useless information, while useful information is kept secret and employees are challenged to prove why they need critical details to do their jobs. Meanwhile, the nepotistic patriarchy is kept alive and well by creating special positions for the sons of white leadership. Well-designed lip service is paid to social causes on social media (when the lawyers and financial projections have determined it’s safe) but take a look at the leadership – that will speak louder than any pretty, convenient words. If you end up on an interview here, don’t let them read their values off a poster. Ask them how they demonstrate those values. For me, they couldn’t.

title: Good Opportunity yet occasional challenges
pros: Intelligent hard working teams. There's a ton of opportunity if you can focus on your goals and get linked up with the right people.
cons: Slightly disorganized, mildly chaotic. Lack of communication among the masses is the biggest fault. High turnover rate at times, disgruntled staff depending on the team.

title: Acounting
pros: Great Benefits and leadership. The people at the company make this one of the best places I have ever worked. I enjoy coming in everyday. The company prides themselves with a culture that is beyond anything I have seen at other places.
cons: The only con is in the accounting department is Quarter close is a beast and makes for a rough week for close.

title: Great Opportunities
pros: I've been working at HHC for a few years and have found it to always be a place where hard work is rewarded and opportunities plentiful. If you're entrepreneurial and driven you'll appreciate working here. Recent leadership changes have bolstered this mindset and there are many exciting projects in the pipeline.
cons: Nothing aside from the usual gripes of any corporate environment - too many meetings!

title: Much change going on, new management direction
pros: High end real estate and development work, good funding, great set of assets, energetic employees
cons: Major change of business plans from year to year, focus on growth. Recent upper executive changes fractured company, sold off some assets, moved headquarters from Dallas to Houston.

title: Medical BEnefits
pros: there are absolutely no pros
cons: Howard Hughes has sunk to a new low. They have made separating with the company due to COVID the most horrible experience at a time when people are at their most vulnerable. After not providing severance to hundreds of people, they have now , in the last week of December, terminated COBRA medical benefits. THE LAST WEEK OF DECEMBER AND THEY CUT PEOPLE AND THEIR FAMILY's MEDICAL BENEFITS.

title: Entrepreneurial Vibe with Organized Chaos
pros: Seasoned professionals (+25 years experience), young company with awesome spirit, innovative and creative, passion for excellence, invest in their people, opportunity for growth.
cons: Young company that has its issues, data validation, lots of senior people, long hours, political.

title: Great Culture
pros: The Howard Hughes Corp. has a great culture and really tries to nurture it's employees goals and interests. Everything moves at a very fast pace, so you have to willing to jump in when necessary and work as a team to get the job done. I believe you're rewarded well for your hard work.
cons: No cons to mention at this time

title: Would not reccomend
pros: They offer some easy summer jobs
cons: Terrible management, multiple waves of firing and hiring after every quarterly earnings statement. They would rather buy a 100,000 Mercedes sprinter van that they didn’t even use than keep on a tenured employee with 15 years with the company (not me). No job security at all.

pros: The Howard Hughes Corporation was one of the best environments that I have ever worked in. Everyone at the company is friendly, driven, and an overall joy to work with. I was part of the first full internship program with 15 other college interns and had one of the best summers ever. Great company.
cons: I had no problems with working here.

title: Great Place to work but...
pros: Amazing Culture! Great People
cons: Poor or non-existent training. Frustrating glacial pace of the contract approval process. Tedious and Ineffective internal controls and processes which cripple productivity and delivery of projects. Reactive rather than Proactive environment. High turnover of great talent due to frustrating illogical processes.

title: Amazing Company
pros: Excellent company with dynamic leadership. Highly entrepreneurial culture that challenges all employees to continually push through plateaus. Great portfolio of assets - working on large, meaningful projects. Hard work is rewarded.
cons: Depending upon personality type - not a good environment for those that prefer significant structure and predictability in their work/schedule.

title: Empty
pros: conveniently located in a beautiful area
cons: Corporate cultural push for the 24/7 work commitment. Lack of internal opportunties. Lack of communication and direction at all levels...very much a figure out as you go environment.

title: Poor Middle Management
pros: Decent paying job in Hawaii - not many of those.
cons: Highly tiered org. Current lower level employees have to deal with poor middle management at the sales, marketing, and PR. HR is more or less useless and works for middle management. The whistleblower line is a political play.

title: HOW TO ENGAGE EMPLOYEES IN 2019
pros: No one company in my many years in the industry can engage and inspire people like our team at The Howard Hughes Corporation. From the new employee orientation, aka "HELLO" to ongoing interactions with corporate peeps....are truly an inspirational experience.
cons: none to mention...all very positive thoughts!

title: Incredible Opportunities
pros: Howard Hughes truly rewards employees for work well done and provides several opportunities for growth and learning to those who take initiative. Leadership is very accessible.
cons: Sometimes there is lack of communication and clarity on overall company vision/strategy from corporate management.

title: Finding its Footing
pros: HHC is a new company so it naturally has some hiccups to work through. However, these hiccups are tackled head-on and solved in a sustainable manner that sets teams up for success.
cons: Processes can be slow and some properties have yet to adjust to new approaches.

title: Overall good, but leadership could be improved!
pros: Benefits are great. Bonuses every year.
cons: Local leadership could be better. Certain people getting promoted versus others who do not when they appear to be working just as hard or for longer period of time.

title: Disappointed.
pros: Upscale, good clientele. Coworkers are nice, and just as disgruntled as I am. Good benefits and provided outfits. Always smells good.
cons: Demanding, unfair, upper management. Payment is screwy. They have no faith in lower level management, and is too corporate to get anything done quickly.

title: Good Family Atmosphere, but NO Work/Life Balance

title: This Company is Not What it Used to Be
pros: Although there are some great people working here, others not so much and these are in the leadership/c-suite area. Overall benefit package is good with matching 401-K; $.75 per dollar on your first 6% invested. FSA on heath/child care/elder care. HSA and traditional health, dental, and vision programs. ESPP at discount, LTD and STD. Catastrophic health plans as well. The elephant in the room is that salary lags behind, especially if you've been there for some time. New hires will come in at higher salary amounts. Field personnel will receive an iPhone that can be used personally, and some receive laptops. Three weeks of vacation plus two personal holidays in addition to traditional holidays. Sick time is liberal right now.
cons: Several years ago there was a fantastic CEO who was a servant leader. He knew everyone in the company, and worked his way up from just cutting the grass. Unfortunately now there is a different CEO who is more ego-centric. He has never held a position in operations having come out of the financial sector. The others in the c-suite are a mixed lot with some attempting to communicate with those outside of the c-suite while others are focused on their own country club life. This company has fully embraced DEI and ESG to the point of ignoring just why they are even in business. Navigating around this is like picking your way through a minefield! Too many of the great, seasoned employees have left due to the low pay, c-suite attitude, DEI and ESG b.s. and poor leadership in some of the divisions. One division had approximately 10 vacancies at the same time. Of course this affects the morale of others as they are forced to pick up the slack. The hiring process can be lengthy. Advancement can be non-existent depending on what position you hold.

cons: - work/life balance may come array as you move up the leadership change - leadership has a hard time wanting to pivot, and get adjusted to new times within employee culture and work/life balance culture. - no incentives like our competitors to retain employees

title: Total Circus
pros: Worked with many great individuals, made life-long friends and connections.
cons: While I'm confident that many people have had and will continue to have a great experience at Highwoods, I did not. This was mostly due to intradepartmental chaos. In my particular situation, my leader seemed unequipped for the position and unable to properly lead our team - resulting in poorly managed projects, lack of time management and disregard for employees' time/work/needs. Perhaps not with intention, but through his/her actions, the head of our department showed more interest in pleasing his/her superior than trusting the expertise of his/her team. This, in conjunction with the arbitrary system of promotions/probation/lack of promotions within our department, often left me scratching my head.

title: Wonderful people to work; however, a very strong "good-old-boy" approach to leadership
pros: The benefits are excellent, the salary a little bit higher than competitive. For those who like hard work and challenge, it's there. Highwoods is a great "people place" with some of the best in the business on staff.
cons: Question whether Highwoods' future is as rosy and bright as Management would convey. Massive layoffs (with a large percentage of older employees with tenure benefits) strongly suggest that this company may be in trouble. Be aware that there is risk involved with hitching your star to this company -- not all things are truly the way they are told..

title: Great place to work with lots of flexibility!
pros: Awesome group of people to work with! Everyone is very pleasant and knowledgeable on accounting functions and processes pertaining to the job. Very open streams of communications are present which makes asking questions on unfamiliar tasks and assignments easier to grasp. Great compensation and benefits for the work required. Not a very stressful environment at all but you do have certain times where you might feel overwhelmed with assignments that are quarterly and annually outside the month to month tasks at hand.
cons: Not much room for growth unless senior positions become available due to employees leaving. Work becomes a little redundant as you go along.

title: Growth, Fun and Work/Life Balance all in one.
pros: Work/life balance is easy to achieve. This is a company that cares about their employees and it shows with the generous benefits and the amount of trust they show their staff. Plenty of room to grow and learn from some of the best. Employees are trusted and allowed to be creative. Ideas from all employees are encouraged.
cons: Getting your foot in the door may be a challenge, but once you're in give it your all and make yourself valuable.

title: Strong Financials
pros: Great benefits (company pays your portion of health insurance), solid company performance, strong financials. Good group of diverse individuals from all age ranges so it's easy to find people you can relate to. Executive management has very nice, approachable, intelligent people which helps you feel confident and integrated.
cons: Corporate headquarters are not in a particularly exciting location. Only location to step away and take a break from work is downstairs in the cafe. Difficult to transition to a different position as the company is relatively small, have to wait for someone to leave to have the opportunity to move.

title: Company Management
pros: Executives are very kind and some office staff as well. Benefits are good.
cons: Management in the Orlando office is lacking in many areas. Too many managers managing the assets and no central control. Micro managing seems to be the narrative where all of the managers are looking out for themselves and ready and willing to throw coworkers and subordinates under the bus. Not a fun work environment when you expect to get fired everyday you go to work. Assets are not looked over very well by management. Pay is very low.

title: A shame it's not what it used to be! :(
pros: The staff (fellow employees) are for the most part great to work with!
cons: The upper management is a stodgy group of men that have a warped perception of what its like from the worker's perspective. They don't have a clue as to what workers really think of the company and the toxic culture that is the norm. Very sad as we used to all be so proud and felt respected.

title: Sugarcoated opportunity
pros: Most days easy laid back work, opportunity to meet new people, opportunities to learn new things, make coworker friends, work mostly in the air conditioned space.
cons: Pay raises only comes with extra work. Weird and unconventional job position titles. Salaries numbers throughout the company are all over the place. One manager will make 45k the other 100k for the same position. Employee handbook does not match verbal rules from management. Miscommunication among managers.

title: High Turnover

title: Amazing Company!
pros: I've been working here at Hudson for about 2 years now and it's been a great experience. What i love most are the people that work here. The people that you work with is what sets the tone for the work environment. To me that's very important because you spend most of your day with these people right? Employees here work hard but we still know how to have fun from time to time. Another great thing about the company is that we're not as stiff as most corporate offices, the office is quite lax and i think it'll continue being this way as long as people get their work done. As far as my department, i feel like i got pretty lucky. I enjoy working in my teammates and I appreciate their patience with teaching me and showing me new things. I continue to learn something new every day here. And I definitely cannot forget to mention how AWESOME the CEO is. He is extremely generous and really cares about the employees at Hudson. I've heard some amazing stories about him from people that's been with him since the Arden days. It shows a great deal when people have continued to follow him even after he sold Arden and started Hudson.
cons: There's not a lot of cons i can think of. But one thing that does come to mind is the communication here at the company can be better.

title: Good salary. Bad leadership
pros: Compensation Modern office Fun events
cons: Cliques Talk about culture, but no ac

title: Steer clear of any and all employment opportunities at the predatory company
pros: Growth orientated and acquisition centric
cons: The shear lack of a true management team at this company is outstanding. The corporate structure here is a boys club of buddies from the CEO's former company, where advancement is based on relationships and politics and not merit. No middle management to speak of, with the executive team covering their behinds vs mentoring their teams. The key executives are making bank and everyone else is overworked, underpaid and unappreciated. Rather than paying deserving employees what is market, they waste money on lunches and private jets. HR is dispised across the board and the admin EA's are self important and have undue influence and run rough shot over even managerial level staff. Rather than value skilled work, they value face time! To be recognized you have to seem to be putting in 24/7 hours. The corporate culture is about working late nights and weekends even when not necessarily. No work/life balance!

title: Terrible cliques and politics-law of the jungle
pros: Business is growing, and there's lots of talented people on staff. They're willing to spend money on the things they want.
cons: If you didn't work for the CEO's last company you will never get promoted. There's an inner circle from that place and if you're on the outside there are no prospects for advancement. They talk a good game about valuing employees but with the cliques and politics they frequently throw good people away just to satisfy the whims of the CEO and his cronies.

title: Work With the Best People, Higher-Ups Overwork You
pros: Everyone says it, but it's true: the people here are the reason why everyone likes to work here. The office environment is friendly, informal, everyone can be themselves. When there's a larger company event, you can talk to the C-Suite just like you would anyone else.
cons: truction administrator

title: Great Company Culture and Work Life Balance
pros: The company culture is great. Team events, flexible when they need to be, listen to employee concerns, DEI training, and very organized. The accounting department is by far the best one I've worked with in the last 15 years in this business. They have a very robust and well put together training program and SOP's. If you don't know how to do something, they have an SOP on literally everything or someone who can help guide you.
cons: Salaries and benefits need to be adjusted to industry standard. They are a little lower than other companies on the salary in my area. Also, benefits could be better. Other PM companies pay 100% of the insurance premium, but they cover a good portion. Also, 401k... need to match more. However, I believe this might be a temporary con as the CEO heard what employees had to say and some of these items are going to be adjusted in 2022.

title: Mismanaged, Toxic Environment!
pros: No micromanagement! Lunch and snacks provided!
cons: By far the most mismanaged company I have ever encountered. Executive management team is all legacy employees from CEO’s previous companies. They recently bought all the tv/film transportation companies and then had to cut employees that actually provided money saving services. They are top heavy in management with overpaid mid managers that don’t have any idea on how to run tv/film studios. They promote playing favorites and don’t recognize the employees who work hard at their jobs. Management doesn’t promote based on true merit, they seem to only promote those who will just stay quite and fall inline. They will continue to make cuts so they can pay their overpaid managers and executives, all while cutting key money saving and revenue generating services they could provide if they knew how to use them.

title: Great place to work if you're looking for an employer that cares about you!
pros: This is the first company I've ever worked at where they truly take care of their employees in all aspects. From professional development, to catered lunches, great co-workers, to amazing facilities - they CONSISTENTLY go above and beyond for their team.
cons: I live in Fullerton, CA (Orange County), and my daily commute ranges from 4-4.5 hours or more (to and from work). I have little kids that are involved in multiple extracurricular activities and I choose to be active in what they do (coaching, attending events, etc.). The commute hindered my ability to stay as active as I would like and I needed to find something closer to home (Orange County, CA). I would rank the Work/Life Balance higher but PLEASE NOTE this is my choice to make the move closer to home and eliminate my lengthy commute.

title: Unnecessarily risking employee health during the pandemic
pros: Many smart, nice colleagues. Some roles offer good pay and career paths. Innovative leader in commercial real estate.
cons: Leadership requires all 300+ employees to risk their health to go into the office unnecessarily 2x per week during the pandemic even though many employees have demonstrated they can do their work well from home. They repeatedly doubled down on this policy even after employees were exposed to numerous confirmed COVID cases at company offices. Very disappointing for a company that supposedly prides itself on how it takes care of employees.

title: Great company to work for with amazing benefits
pros: I worked with an awesome team and an awesome boss. Everyone was very supportive. HPP is very busy with lots going on all the time so any role will be very fulfilling. Upper management listens and values feedback (even from the way down). They're still growing so thoughtful input is always appreciated. Lots of positive changes made in terms of benefits and offerings so I was grateful for that.
cons: I know they're working on this but diversity in the upper management is still a factor. Plenty of awesome women to work for but besides that, diversity is definitely lacking.

title: I'm So Thankful for This Job!
pros: Great coworkers, availability to move up in the company, generous and involved executive team, catered meals several days a week, beautiful and well thought out office space, top notch employee benefits, collaborative and spread out team.
cons: Be prepared to work harder than you have ever worked. This company does NOT cater to the slacker or the laid back types. If you don't want to put in some OT every now and then and can't be a part of a "team" environment, this company is NOT for you. Also, if you don't have designer clothes, you should go buy some before working here.

title: Great company!
pros: I love the people who I work with. Everyone is great, and we work as a team from ground level employees, all the way up to the CEO. Not to mention the company functions are super fun!
cons: There is never a dull moment. If you don't have something you are supposed to be working on, or 5 somethings, you are not doing your job right. That is not always a con, not for me anyway, but some people may not like that kind of work style.

title: Counterpoint to the other reviews...
pros: Hudson knows how to treat their employees. Generous perks, benefits, etc. Contrary to other reviews listed here, the company provides ample opportunities for advancement and treats it's employees well. I have found the HR team to be responsive and fair. Overall, the executive team is top-notch and very skilled at what they do.
cons: As with most growing companies, the expectation can lean towards long hours at times. In general, this is acknowledged by immediate supervisors as well as executive team.

title: A start-up tech feel in a modern corporate culture
pros: The crux with sites like this is that everyone who is disgruntled or out for revenge is so quick to take to the “interweb” and air their grievances. Like Festivus is actually a real thing and they are so cleaver to pull the wool over everyone’s eyes and show how they were made a victim. In my lifetime of work experience, there’s always a valid reason why people are listed as “former” employees. A valid reason. Meanwhile, back at the ranch, perfectly happy, content employees are too busy doing their jobs to feel the need to broadcast to the world of how great they truly have it. Perhaps that’s a mistake on our part. One I intend to correct immediately. Hudson is not perfect. I have never met anyone here who has claimed otherwise. But, I have known that this company was special from the moment I stepped foot onto their property. Contrary to urban myth, there has never been a table of Kool-Aid set up for all new employees to drink. They don’t need to. The Kool-Aid is in the way the company is run, from the top-down. Open door policy? Check. Work-life balance? Check. Recognizing an employee’s commitment to go above and beyond? Check. Collaborative work force? Check. Perks? Check. Ability to grow? Check. I could go on and on here, but I think you get the picture. Hudson also has a very progressive mentality regarding change. They are not afraid to embrace it. Knowing that the past trends of the urban workforce may not be the most productive will never be set in stone with this company. The CEO is open to new things and excited to implement them. Like any job, I have my good days and my bad days. But, overall, they are mostly good and I’m incredibly fortunate and happy to be employed at Hudson.
cons: It’s always a slippery slope when this subject is brought up, but there’s definitely a discrepancy in the XX to XY chromosome ratio in the senior management team. But let me clarify my, ahem, "criticism" for a moment. The current senior management team is comprised of amazing people with incredible talent who are truly shining stars in their respective roles. I don’t want to see more women in senior management to just fill a void. I also don’t want to see Hudson labeled as a “Boys Club” because it’s so much more than that. I want strong, intelligent and capable women to take more senior leadership roles alongside the current male heads of state.

title: No Growth Opportunities, Constant team changes
pros: - Free lunches - Growth Opportunities for the Operations Team.
cons: tant team changes

title: Nice perks, bad management & HR
pros: Free lunches, free breakfast, good benefits, half day Fridays.
cons: Hiring new people is a mess. They hire friends of management and executives, who don't actually want to work there, but get ridiculously high salaries. People who have been there for 10+ years have the job because they were there from the beginning, not because they are amazing employees. All of the interns that were hired were family or friends of executives, making it a nightmare to manage. TOTAL Boys club. Not many women can work there way to the top at HPP. HR is a disaster. Terrible, terrible HR staff. I've seen better HR management at small start-ups. There is no 'Open door policy' here, even though they want you to think there is. If you tell HR any concerns, they'll use it against you. If you're having any other issues, they will simply ignore you and not deal with situations. If there are any employees that are not meeting company standards, they simple demote them, and move them around the office, making the morale and work flow even worse. They do not know how to handle any problems or sticky situations, they'd rather ignore and cover it up with bandaids. Employee retention not great. A lot of turn over due to the extremely slow promotion rate. Again, you can get a promotion here easily if you know someone, if you are a "random" hire , hire based on skills and resume, most likely you will stay in your position for a very long time. Management is a mess, very toxic environment. If you're not a manager, it is VERY well known you're not. ie: "retreats", lots of closed door meetings, lots of management outings, and the lower level employees are not appreciated.

title: Great place, incredible people
pros: The people here are the best part about Hudson. It's a group of smart, engaged and down-to-earth people who create an environment that's both fun and meaningful. Hudson is a place where they care about people ... not just the people who work here, but also our clients, and the community around us.
cons: I can't think of many! The leadership team is super busy, but surprisingly accessible given the fast pace. If you're not into a fast paced, roll-up-your sleeves environment, this may not be the place for you.

title: Great Company!
pros: This is a wonderful mid-scale company that retains a close knit community culture. It has a work hard play hard mentality and at times can be extremely rewarding. This company tends to draw amazing talent and quality of people who are not only about business but who are genuine and fun to be around. Salary tends to be at market rate (pretty average) but I would consider all other benefits as above average.
cons: A little too much drama for my liking although manageable. Vacations are only two weeks, which may be the national average, but certainly nothing to boast about.

title: Good Company
pros: Growing company with some truly intelligent and nice people. Easily ask questions or get feedback between departments. They are a growing company with a big impact in the market. They offer great perks in the summer time, such as Friday half days!
cons: Slow promotion rate and more of a learn as you go mentality. Asked to fill multiple roles without being compensated for it. There is a decent amount of turn over, I believe they hire for cost instead of value.

title: Overall a Great Company to Work For
pros: Engaged leadership, an organization that cares about its employees, teams that love what they do and enjoy coming to work every day. The company has a strong market position with a diversified asset class and cares about being a leader in sustainability. In terms of life at Hudson Pacific, there are a lot of 'work perks' that come with the job. Beautiful office spaces, catered lunches, a charitable giving policy, and a leadership team that is committed to DEI initiatives and leadership development with things like employee resource groups and other programs.
cons: None that I can think of at the moment!

title: Best in Class
pros: I've been with this company for a few years and watched it grow from having fewer than 50 employees in LA to a team of 250+ across a portfolio in major cities up and down the West Coast. Leadership has managed to keep priorities consistent over time -- they stress teamwork, collaboration and hard work, all while underscoring the importance of having fun together, and, of course, delivering best in class product and client service. Which, if you ask me, is about the most satisfying combination of goals for a company to tout. And they don't just talk the talk; the perqs of working at Hudson include state of the art work spaces, company outings, summer half day Fridays, stocked kitchens, catered lunches, and just about any other amenity you could want. All of it, of course, is designed to make the average employee feel as happy at work as possible, because Hudson gets it: happy employees = productive employees. I honestly can't speak to the experiences some have had regarding cliques and power, but I would not be the least bit surprised if the folks writing those reviews had some of their own issues going on. There will always be naysayers, but if you ask the average Hudson employee to give you a candid assessment of working here, I'd be surprised if you didn't get a completely positive, hopeful report. Not to mention that because there is such a premium on corporate culture and vision, recruiting is careful to select individuals who clearly embody the qualities mentioned above. No workplace is perfect, but as far as I can tell, this one comes about as close as you can get.
cons: No drawbacks to report -- it is an honor to work (and play) here!

title: A wonderful place to work
pros: They pay you well, offer ample opportunities to grow, they have a killer xmas party, there are also a lot of opportunities to social impact work. In fact they give you paid time off to do volunteer work. Many of my colleagues have become my good friends and people are always willing to provide feedback and help you get to the next level. There is always a ton of food in the office.
cons: There aren't always a lot of job openings outside of property management but they are always hiring which is positive.

title: Assistant Property Manager
pros: Casual dress on Friday, team building, volunteer opportunities, mostly good coworkers, office snacks are good (high quality). Beautiful buildings to work out off. Creativity was welcome. Initiative was rewarded. Good benefits. Opportunities to learn as you go.
cons: Lack of competive pay. This is a problem but perhaps they are recogizing that. Lack of accountablity with certain employees allows others to get burnt out.

title: Good from far, far from good
pros: The corporate office space is brand new and really nice. They have a kitchen with free food and drinks. On the surface it's a pretty cool place to work.
cons: 1) The vast majority of the most important people at Hudson either worked with the CEO at his previous company or had some other pre-existing relationship. The board is an old boys' club and so is most of the executive team. As such, the culture at the top is very insular and that has negative effects for new employees and people at the bottom. 2) Company-wide communication is pretty much non-existent; there were at least a half dozen instances in which they bought a new building or sold an existing building but never bothered to tell any of the people who weren't directly involved with the transaction. Most employees didn't find out until reading the press releases. 3) If you run into any kind of HR issue that negatively affects your work and you don't have any "friends at the top" then my sincere advice is this: skip the HR department and start looking for an escape route. I watched multiple people try to make formal complaints about harassment, retaliation, etc and not only was there no action taken, the HR department didn't even bother to write anything down or pretend to investigate. I'm actually being pretty diplomatic - the reality is that there are some unprofessional, toxic people working at various levels of the company and HR actively enables them through some combination of malice and incompetence. I imagine it's only a matter of time before the company gets hit with a harassment or discrimination lawsuit, if it hasn't already.

title: Great Place To Work
pros: Everyone who works at Hudson are overall great people and the company offers great perks. Company Christmas party was insane before COVID. The company gifted to $100 upon arrival and they really go all out. Very non toxic environment.
cons: Didn’t have the best manager but she also wasn’t the worst. I think Hudson should offer maybe a month long intensive for anyone in management that emphasizes transparency and expectations of subordinates.

title: Has its ups and downs
pros: Great CEO, and the vision he wants for his company would make an amazing company
cons: If you want to move up, It’s literally about who you know and not what you have to offer. Development is not their priority, neither is the voice of the employees

title: Run away - Highly Toxic Environment!!
pros: Free parking, lunches, and breakfast. Quick promotions if you have friends or family in high positions.
cons: Lots and lots of backstabbing. Lots and Lots of Micro Managing!!! Very high turnover. Someone is fired/quits almost every week - but they don't want anyone to know this information so they don't send staff update emails. If you do not know a top executive you will be overworked and underpaid.

title: Great Place to Work Your Butt Off
pros: incredible benefits and perks like lunches, holidays and summer half-day fridays. The executive team seems to care about employees quality of life.
cons: When you take time off, even PTO, people seem to look down on you so you never actually get out. Lots of politics.

title: Would not recommend
pros: High profile projects Free lunch Beautiful offices
cons: Limited growth opportunities Demanding senior management Constant leadership changes Diversity= promoting white women No work life balance

title: Groundbreaking Company
pros: Overall an amazing and successful company to work for. Proud to represent HPP!
cons: None! I love this company.

title: Reputable Company
pros: Decent company very reputable in their Industry. Generally everyone is very nice a decent group of people to work with.
cons: Many employees have been with the firm awhile. Very old school "clique" type vibe. Technology is very dated and management and employees are not very open to change.

title: Toxic Work Environment
pros: Free lunches, decent pay & beautiful office.
cons: Very little work training, toxic work environment, borderline verbal & emotional abuse from management, insulting gossip, employees fraternizing (sometimes sexual), patronizing behavior, combative communication, management was unapproachable and unwelcoming.

title: Great work environment
pros: Company really looks for ways to provide excellent customer service (outside and inside). Overall company cares about employees well being.
cons: Depending on the department the career opportunity can take years if any.

title: Tense Work Environment
pros: Work itself is not difficult, there's lots of free food, and interacting with tenants is satisfying
cons: The property management director is a micromanager

title: Buyer beware (Toxic Environment)......unless you are Arden/GE legacy
pros: Lots of perks, amazing facility, free lunches and breakfast on Fridays.
cons: Advancement is based on who you know, not merit based. Toxic environment, where back-stabbing is the norm (mostly from middle-management). Lack of accountability, and throwing people under the bus .....is too common.

title: Awesome!
pros: Everyone is kind and pleasant, free breakfast and lunch, well-stocked kitchen, generous raffle prizes on Christmas Party,
cons: lots of reports that sometimes you can't even get out to your property

title: Strong, Rapidly Growing Company
pros: Great people, strong market niche, rapid business platform growth
cons: Limited career growth opportunities; existing business platform, while growing, is limited in size which in turn limits opportunities for advancement

title: Review
pros: Great culture and great advancement opportunities for entry level applicants.
cons: Limited advancement past Senior Manager. Communication can be limited vertically and between departments.

title: Assistant
pros: Good benefits. Free lunch/snacks. Most people treated you nicely and worked hard.
cons: Corporate culture, make sure it's the right vibe for you.

title: Good company
pros: Free lunch, snazzy buildings, opportunities for growth
cons: Management is a struggle, I’ve watched a lot of bullying go down as a result of their high standards

title: You're Family
pros: You are treated as family, you have s great team of people you work with, management takes very good care of their employees, and great benefits.
cons: None that I can think of.

title: Great place to start CRE
pros: A lot of emphasis on networking and company initiatives.
cons: Management sometimes goes by the book on certain initiatives and it sometimes results in less flexibility in the workplace.

title: Cool Company
pros: Good pay, daily catered lunch and breakfast on Fridays, Summer Fridays early dismissal, impressive office space, good group of people
cons: Lack of schedule flexibility, no real structure and ever-changing guidelines

title: Nice place to work with some corks
pros: Pays well, Good benefits, Corporate office offers nice meals and snacks.
cons: Tense environment, boys club feel, good to know upper management

title: Good culture, long hours
pros: Great company culture, recognize hard work and promote from within
cons: Long hours, expected to be available in off hours

title: Wonderful leadership team
pros: Lots of employee perks, leadership really cares about their employees
cons: Typical office politics among peers but nothing extraordinary

title: Great company
pros: One of the best companies I have ever worked for!
cons: No cons! Such a great company.

title: Humpty Dumpty Fell Off a wall
pros: Eccentric and motivational insight on business future
cons: This is reality get your mind out of the gutter

title: Best in the business
pros: great company culture, corporate values
cons: I wish I could have stayed, but I had to relocate out of the area.

title: Tenant Coordinator Review
pros: Collaborative, learning opportunities, fast paced
cons: Team was not staffed to the level that it needed to be

title: Great company & people!
pros: The company offers great incentives and clearly cares about the employees.
cons: None that I can think of.

title: Great Company and People
pros: Supportive upper management, great coworkers, opportunity for growth and advancement, excellent benefits.
cons: Cannot think of any cons.

title: Great place to collaborate
pros: Beautiful work spaces. Great culture of public service. Collaborative environment
cons: Can't think of any Cons.

title: Great Company
pros: The company is full of really smart and collaborative people.
cons: None to share so far.

title: Work
pros: Great company culture and one of the best places to work.
cons: No negative things to say.

title: Great!
pros: Best people. Great place to work.
cons: Competitive pay for the area.

title: Unfriendly Work Environment
pros: Great starting salary. Great perks of working there.
cons: Very hostile work environment. Lots of gossip.

title: Horrible
pros: There were no positives to the job.
cons: It was a very negative environment to work in.

title: Difficult to Work for
pros: Lunch is included and training is available.
cons: Manager was ineffective and would micromanage.

title: Good company with a lack of camaraderie
pros: Good benefits and perks Nice office with views, central location Generous CEO
cons: Terrible, clueless managers who only look out for themselves Favoritism, office politics, cliquey atmosphere- creating a toxic environment

title: Overall great company
pros: Fair compensation Good bonus structure Company cares about staff well being Kitchen is never short of food and snacks Free lunch etc
cons: Politics, gossiping in the office but this is more due to the personality of the people hired HR needs to be more careful with hiring and make sure every person hired is PERSONABLE and a good fit culturally

title: Great place to work
pros: Very great benefits and perks great people
cons: truction administrator

title: Great place to work
pros: Very friendly staff! The company is a REIT with many departments so you learn a lot about the ownership and renovation of assets from various perspectives.
cons: Very traditional workplace. This isn't so bad but it's the least exciting environment I have worked in as a designer.

title: Manager
pros: Good work space tu et al
cons: There is very little interaction between departments.

title: Not Great
pros: meet a lot of people outside of the design field.
cons: poor distribution of workload. coworkers will get special treatment.

title: Good benefits, structured work setting
pros: Good benefits and salaries. Multiple departments create a good office camaraderie. Company gives back often to non profits.
cons: Not a creative environment. Many workstations and private offices create a feeling of a financial institution.

title: Lack of structure, lack of leadership, and not much of a company culture.
pros: I had a very good boss, who is trying too hard to make right of things out of our control.
cons: Executives can do whatever they want, rules are irrelevant; employees on the other hand have to follow all the rules, written or unspoken, known or unknown. Extremely expensive health insurance, and a CEO who likes to watch when everyone gets in and leaves the office.

title: Great Group of People
pros: A sincerely great group of people who are all very talented and excellent at what they do. Going to work was a pleasure for me each and every single day.
cons: Diversity seemed limited. Selected groups of people seemed to be promoted, invested in, and valued more than others.

title: Experienced one of the highest customer service at Summit Hotel Properties.
pros: It is for the management's influence of interrelationship and work ethics that have prompted me to be part of the team if I had an opportunity to work for Summit Hotel Properties.
cons: I have not yet seen any negative outcome.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: - hybrid role - no timesheets - hospitality design
cons: - difficult to get approvals to move forward with design process - budgets for FF&E are very tight which leaves little room for using better products

title: Great Company and Workplace
pros: Good leaders who care about quality over glamour. Good benefits.
cons: Unfortunately laid off due to COVID in 2020, but I will always appreciate my time and the experience I gained with them.

title: Excellent Company
pros: Pay, Benefits, Life Support, Caring executives and team members
cons: can be long hours but always rewarded/acknowledged

title: Good Salary
pros: They pay very well. Nice office environment.
cons: Very corporate, make sure that you keep a good paper trail on your work.

title: Wonderful Company
pros: Positive atmosphere, very nice co-workers
cons: A certain co-worker had a very negative attitude - but from what I hear - that person is gone.

title: VP Construction
pros: Top company in hotel field
cons: truction

title: Accountant
pros: Good Company,Working environment is good.
cons: Looking for better option for further future.

title: Entry Level Position
pros: Wonderful company to work for, Great work life balance and great coworkers.
cons: Benefits are average for market.

title: Mostly Great Experience
pros: Amazing culture of honest kind people who are willing to help even if it's not within their scope.
cons: Because of "awkward" company size of over 100, upward mobility doesn't happen quite as frequently as mega-corporations.

title: Great company
pros: Great culture and work life balance
cons: No negatives to report on Inventrust

title: Not all that they make it out to be
pros: I'll admit, the pay is awesome. They have great benefits too!
cons: My two supervisors are extremely condescending and don't seem to let your voice be heard. EVERY LITTLE THING you do has to be approved by corporate. There is no creative freedom because all of their marketing is the same company wide (which is stupid because all markets are different). Instead of sending someone to the property to help with leasing efforts when they decide to have the highest prices in the market when they aren't the newest property around, they look for ways to blame the staff for the property not succeeding.

title: "Eh" is really the only way to describe it.
