pros: Flexibility and trustworthiness (at least at our properties location). Employees are allowed to use their best judgement in decision making, time and request off are usually approved. Co-workers are easy to get along with (at least at our location).
cons: Characteristics of the company vary across all properties. It is often times hard for rectify situations at the property site when having to deal with corporate for approval. Corporate overseers are less likely to trust property management, and thus, makes it hard for the individual properties to operate. Pay is similar to a fast food restaurant unless you are higher up in the company (management level and up). Also, t-shirts and uniforms are absolutely terrible, especially at student the housing properties. It is clear that there is a 40 year-old woman with a strict budget designing them who is also out of touch with what college students might actually want to wear. I've seen residents use them as rags to clean their houses personally….

title: Working at InvenTrust Properties
pros: One of the best parts of working at InvenTrust is the people! Everyone is so nice and fun and always willing to help! Another great part is the flexibility, IVT offers permanent half day Fridays and a hybrid work schedule! IVT has great company culture, they love to plan fun events and are always making efforts to donate to charities or give back to the community. Lastly, a great perk is the yearly bonus employees receive!
cons: I think PTO could be slightly improved at InvenTrust. I also think the pay is a little low and it seems like it can take a little bit of time to get promoted.

title: Not worth it
pros: Convenient location if you live in the western suburbs.
cons: Bad pay, rigid structure, more or less use a punch card for hours, no casual days (unless you want to pay for it), no bonuses, no internal advancement opportunity, everyone wants to leave/is pessimistic about being there, inconvenient location for majority of employees, no leeway on time off or shortened days (MUST work atleast 40 hrs/week, no incentive to go over that or put in extra effort), very fast employee turnover, no young people want to work there

title: Review from a former real estate asset manager.
pros: Inland American has a wide variety of sophisticated real estate assets on which to work. The company is reasonably accomplished in its approach to the real estate business. In particular, it is willing to advance people within the organization with non-traditional real estate backgrounds.
cons: The company has struggled to adjust to more developed ways of performing real estate investment analysis to match its strength in property management and operations. It is reluctant to change.

title: Assistant Community Manager
pros: Great company to work for! Lots of fun and corporate really knows how to make things a blast. Paid company training, support for any issues or help you may need and great incentives.
cons: Extreme micro-management and lower salary than average property management companies. Very low incentives for leasing and they tax the crap out of your pay! Commission checks are very low due to the high taxes collected from each amount and not the overal amount.

title: High expectations with a unique culture
pros: I have felt incredibly comfortable around coworkers. I feel that thoughts and ideas can be shared and recognized at all levels. I feel appreciated by the company, and that we are working as a team towards the same goal.
cons: Because of high expectations, and a desire to do well, it is a struggle to establish a work/life balance. I had to train myself to not work outside my hours, and still find myself working extra to feel a sense of completion/accomplishment.

title: Love my job, the CEO, and it only gets better.
pros: The executives actually care about their employees, know their names and a lot about them. Work life balance is promoted. The benefits keep rolling in and they are growing with the best of them in the industry.
cons: Old fashioned vacation / sick pay policy as compared to newer companies.

title: Great place to work & grow!
pros: The people! Some of the best people you will ever work with & for. The benefits including amazing 401k match, great medical & dental, Summer Hours, Work from home opportunities , work/life balance, family-friendly company, and continuing to improve!
cons: Vacation Time/Sick time could be improved a bit just to keep up with the current trends of newer companies but by no means are they bad

title: Average Experience
pros: Management has brought on new hires and new visions to renovate Inland's image. Ability to interact in social gatherings within the company.
cons: Disorganized company structure, lower level employees sometimes get lost in the shuffle. Location: need to have a car to get to the office which Inland doesn't fairly compensate you for.

title: Do not work for this company!
pros: The pros are you will meet a lot of really great people. The culture of the employees is much different from the culture of management and executives.
cons: Executives create an unstable employment opportunity through their decisions to make money available for investment purposes. They are inconsistent and make annual, random job cuts. The company is unorganized and technology/processes are dated. Your loyalty as an employee will not be reciprocated even when you are a good employee, if they see a need to save money, you will be on the list. So don't plan on long-term employment or anything innovative that would even bolster your experience. If you don't want to be back in this boat, looking for employment, do NOT waste your resume space here. It will only give you a short term experience that will leave recruiters questioning why, later.

title: Positive Working Experience
pros: A very positive and encouraging work environment | generous salary | training and support | hybrid - work from home/office split | helpful and collaborative co-workers |respectful and even encouraging of work - life balance | opportunities for giving back to the community as a team
cons: Some of the computer programs seem a little redundant - however, there is fantastic IT support

title: Assistant Property Manager At University House
pros: Amazing! Loved the work environment, very doable job, great room for moving up if you are willing to move around. Simple and fun 9-5 with little sales pressure.
cons: No room for moving up within your state but definitely is if you are willing to move.

title: Future Unclear
pros: Potential for corporate growth is strong. PTO requests are respected, recent efforts are strong with a focus on technology, and inter-department communication.
cons: No clear future of the company has been presented to the employees. Highly politicized, depending on the department you work in. On the low end of compensation across the board.

title: A Company That Truly Cares About Its Employees
pros: The best place that I have ever worked * Excellent Corporate Culture * Numerous Company Events * Challenging Work * Highly Supportive Management and Co-workers * Generous Salary and Benefits * Ability to advance within the Company
cons: None- It is wonderful working at IVT

title: Good company, okay for growth
pros: Paid very well, great bonuses, is essentially a start-up company you can make a name for yourself in.
cons: Growth is limited to property level operations, and you have to be willing to relocate.

title: Great Company to Work For
pros: - Highly experienced upper management - Community (not family) environment. Co-workers are really great people. Company has upmost respect for your personal time. - Very clear promotion trajectory
cons: None that I can think of at this time

title: Meh....
pros: Flexible summer work schedule, and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and????
cons: Direction of the company seems to change as frequently as the wind shifts. Lack of consistency and clear direction with high turnover.

title: Lots of Change
pros: Shed a lot of bulk/dead weight in recent years, still reconstructing but the focus is there with some people who truly believe in what they are saying
cons: Processes can be slow, lots of employee turnover the past 18-24mos

title: Good Company
pros: InvenTrust definitely offers great benefits. They host fun employee gatherings and are terrific at creating and participating in charity events.
cons: Each department could use a structured steppingstone for growth for those who are interested.

title: Interesting company
pros: Invested in people, interesting line of work, Friday summer hours year round.
cons: Lack of email communication after interviews

title: Okay to work for
pros: Great people to work for and with
cons: low pay, little opportunity for advancement

title: Fantastic Company
pros: - Great work/life balance, - Great benefits - Work from home opportunity
cons: Don't have anything negative to say about the company

title: Excellent College Job
pros: Meet new people. Pay was sufficient. Flexible hours.
cons: Limited role. Little advancement.

title: Great college job - University House
pros: Organized Clear management structure Clean facilities Renewal Incentives Good pay
cons: Not a lot of room for advancement - - - -

title: Awesome Company
pros: Great Perks and friendly environment.
cons: I can't think of any cons at this moment!

title: Great Bonuses Low salary
pros: Good to their employees, promote within
cons: Required to Work every other Saturday

title: Good
pros: Inventrust is considered trust worthy
cons: I believe they need more collaboration department wide.

title: Most Rewarding Job!
pros: Thoughtful, trusting, educational, great manager.
cons: I can't think of any!

title: Asset Manager
pros: Middle management and below work well together in order to benefit the shareholders.
cons: The management team is too green, their qualifications are not aligned with their respective roles.

title: Micro Management
pros: Ample parking spaces for employees. Plenty of opportunities to "date" coworkers.
cons: Micromanagement, harassment, low wages.

title: Caution
pros: Not much good to say
cons: Beware beware beware beware beware

title: Nice
pros: Nice company to work with
cons: I can't find any cons

title: Great place to work
pros: Great place to work. Highly recommend
cons: No complaints- this is a great job.

title: Great place to work
pros: benefits, work life balance, culture
cons: strict deadlines given it's a public company; limited growth potential without CPA.

title: Great place to learn!
pros: Institutional real estate shop with storied DC roots.
cons: Underpaid for many positions, particularly in finance / investing roles.

title: Professional and Employee Oriented
pros: Great company with a positive work environment. I learned a lot during my time as a maintenance tech and really enjoyed the team I worked with. I was able to develop my skills and take on new challenges, which ultimately led to a promotion at another company. I'm grateful for the experience I gained at JBG Smith and look forward to potentially returning in the future.
cons: While my overall experience at JBG Smith was positive, I did encounter a challenging situation with a new manager. Their behavior towards both myself and other employees was unprofessional and often disrespectful. Despite this, I appreciate that HR took action after I raised my concerns, even though it was during my departure. It's encouraging to hear that the situation improved for the remaining team members.

title: Great benefits but..
pros: Benefits are unmatched and management is usually friendly
cons: Opportunity for growth pretty much doesn't exist. Management would rather promote someone from outside your portfolio than those that work in the same office

title: Accountant
pros: Opportunities for collaboration between departments.
cons: Lots of office politics that are hard to navigate.

title: Strong Leader in DC Real Estate
pros: Very intelligent and talented employees/leadership, well-respected firm in DC/MD/VA and throughout the region, fantastic corporate office, high-quality and high-profile buildings/projects.
cons: Along with many other real estate firms nationally and in the region, firm has struggled financially since COVID.

title: Decent Company
pros:
Regionally focused company
Opportunity for advancement
cons:
Slow promotion
Power being taken away from onsite staff

title: Best Company to Work For
pros: I absolutely loved how work/life balance was huge part of the company. Pay was great, commission was good, they gave back to their employees with nice events.
cons: Didn’t experience any…well other than they sold one of their properties & that can be a risk.

title: Good benefits, horrible management
pros: Loved employee benefits like our health insurance. Summer Fridays. Once you move up, you get work from home days, and flexibility with that.
cons: The upper management hates the little guy. Common, but it's depressing and unnecessary, as well as my reason for quitting. Lots of shuffling as well. I had 3 managers in 18 months.

title: Good company, Great benefits
pros: health insurance benefits and premiums were low. Lots of properties to choose from. Up to date on technology.
cons: in 2015 I was making $100 per commission. Hopefully it is more now.

title: Fine Company, Supportive Team, Difficult Job
pros: The SVP who leads is talented and extremely smart. I enjoyed working with her and thought that she led the team in a professional manner.
cons: I did not have the experience to do this job properly and it showed as this is an extremely specialized area of tax. I can't blame JBG Smith, this was mostly on me. I'm glad I ended up leaving and finding a job that was more compatible with my skills.

title: Good
pros: Good place to work and nice environment
cons: no formal training to develop new hires

title: Admin
pros: Great people, cool office, good benefits
cons: Diversity, work culture in some departments

title: Love the company
pros: Great benefits, leave accrual, and sense of community.
cons: Difficult to move up without the right internal connections.

title: Great Place to Learn
pros: You will be challenged. Lots of very smart, motivated people in the department. Great learning experience as you advance in your career.
cons: A bit stressful at times. Even with efficiencies gained in automating processes, there's always more work to do,

title: Good Place To Work
pros: JBG Smith was a great social environment to work in - people were friendly. The office is beautiful.
cons: The open office setup of the main office is tough for daily desk work. When I joined there was a lot of work from home flexibility which they started to roll back in 2023. Commuting was tough. They made employees pay for parking in a building that they owned and managed.

title: Just OK
pros: Pay is Ok and free bagels
cons: No upward communications. Managers arent trained at all. Some lack people skills

title: Great place to work
pros: Benefits, culture, pay, work life balance (unlimited PTO, Summer Fridays)
cons: Company is going through a tough time due to office market. I’m sure it will be rebound.

title: great culture
pros: it's a good place to work and offers great benefits and connections
cons: can be a limiting place

title: Good place to start
pros: JBG Smith is a great place to build your skillset as an analyst
cons: Comp could be better and there seems to be some concerns about job security.

title: No Interaction with Corporate
pros: The compensation and benefits offered are strong.
cons: The turnover is very very high. In my short time at a JBG property, there have been six firings on a staff of nine.

title: Great place to develop your career
pros: Great learning experience and given a lot of autonomy
cons: Very faced paced and need to be able to multitask

title: Safe Place
pros: Great benefits, pay, and flexibility
cons: Not totally sure where the company is headed

title: Worst company I ever worked for
pros: Absolutely none. Nothing positive about this company to share!
cons: I left a 10 year carrier job, competed with over 500 qualified candidates for the position. Got the job, only to get laid off 6 months later. Very toxic work environment. Leadership is a disaster. HR is a disgrace.

title: Would not recommend
pros: Nice office with amenities and benefits are decent.
cons: Poor management, micromanaging, underpaid for the work expected of you in the position.

title: Overall good place to work
pros: The physical office has excellent perks and HR tries to make employees feel appreciated often.
cons: The "streamlined" approaches to some of the work are actually more cumbersome and can lead to an increased work load or the need to double check things.

title: Its ok
pros: nice office and nice people
cons: commute, poor communication, too many meetings

title: Great place to work
pros: Great culture and the best company I have worked at.
cons: Inclusiveness within the departments. It could get clicky

title: cool
pros: Decent hours, good time off, benefits
cons: bad management, no accountability, low bonus pay

title: It was great... until it wasn't
pros: Fun environment for the employees, young executives with open minds, diverse inclusive culture, breakfast, snacks and drinks provided daily.
cons: Employees laid off or leaving and not replaced which leaves more work and stress on those left. Very worrisome for remaining staff, "will I be the next one cut?"

title: A place to work
pros: Large portfolio of commercial buildings.
cons: Impacted by commercial office vacancy due to hybrid and work from home policies brought on by Covid-19.

title: JBG SMITH
pros: Jbg is a diverse, open and welcoming company. I hit the ground running with a team in place to help every step of the way.
cons: knowledge before delegating . but that's most management companies.

title: Great Employer
pros: Great flexible schedule. Independent work.
cons: More internal communication would be nice.

title: Property Manager
pros: Benefits, paid leave, support from corporate.
cons: Location of assets, work life balance

title: Great team and great benefits
pros: A lot of support, great team and training opportunities
cons: Compensation was low but fair was commission

title: JBG Smith
pros: Nice office space in Bethesda.
cons: Executive heavy real estate company.

title: Hmmmm
pros: Property was walking distance from my place.
cons: I turned in my 2 week notice before leaving, and recently found out when a new employer called to verify my employment that I am ineligible for rehire due to not having given a 2 week notice. Called and emailed for clarification, still awaiting a response.

title: JBG SMITH
pros: Intelligent people and great projects
cons: Lots of turnover and few employees in office

title: Great place to learn
pros: Great place to learn with opportunities for advancement Collaborative environment with strong teams
cons: Must enjoy working for a public company

title: ASSULT
pros: Great residential property with great views
cons: I was let go from jbg after being Assaulted with a deadly weapon in hand by the front desk. Which they have footage of. I was told that they don’t support assault of any kind but they have to let me go. Last time I checked my life was at risk and instead of protecting me they fired me! Insane!!!

title: Great Company for stability if you keep your head down
pros: - Stable - Opportunities for Growth - Bonuses and incentives - Wide range of properties
cons: - Culture of favoritism among portfolios - Pay raises limited - High turnover results on overwork and burnout

title: Great Company
pros: I learned a lot and promoted working within this company (formerly The JBG Companies).
cons: My commute was 70 miles one way

title: Great buildings and vision
pros: Jbg is a well oiled machine. The company is full of support and great mentors.
cons: Once old employees leave it’s hard to return.

title: Pay estimate
pros: Growth opportunities, job security, training
cons: High turnover, low pay, tight deadlines

title: Okay
pros: Good benefits, nice team members
cons: Poor communication from leadership, corporate staff treated better than on-site staff with separate events, nicer office perks

title: Great company
pros: Excellent company to work for!
cons: Communication from upper management isn't always transparent

title: Great Place to Work
pros: Hard working people. Lots of growth to come. Relatively flat structure.
cons: None that I can think of.

title: Great place to work for a few months if you're unemployed and hate yourself
pros: The salary and benefits are average for the market. They are not allowed to keep you against your will. Given the high turnover rate, you'll always have new co-workers to help you through the misery.
cons: Highly toxic environment. The accounting and tax departments struggle to retain people, with turnover greater than what is typically seen in the Big 4. People staying longer than a year is rare. Given the company's poor reputation in the employment marketplace, they cannot attract the level of talent necessary to function so dysfunction continues unabated. Long hours (more than what is typically seen in public accounting) with no end in sight given the poor management of people, process, and information systems from the merger in mid-2017 (more than 2 years later, it's still a mess).

title: Poor Department Management
pros: There is a lot to learn, employees at lower levels are generally are a very nice hard-working group of people, compensation is fair, stock-option program, lots of company perks/initiatives when you are allowed to participate
cons: Accounting department head is controlling and makes staffing decisions for employees at all levels. If you want to move up you must brown nose and show face in the office after hours and on weekends. Quantity of hours is more important than quality of work. Environment is competitive and toxic, resulting in high turnover of staff. Employees at the next level down avoid making decisions and prefer to throw their own team under the bus than to stick up for them. They create an environment that discourages teamwork and encourages unhealthy competition. With 30%+ staff turnover in 6 months there’s clearly a problem with upper management that is not being addressed.

title: Not terrible, not great
pros: JBGS offers good corporate benefits and was great about COVID response (for corporate employees). If your managers value you, you'll go far. The work was varied, but not challenging. My co-workers were lovely people, who I formed great relationships with, and who would go out of their way to help out.
cons: There is a huge disparity between the treatment, benefits, salaries, diversity, etc. of corporate vs. site level staff, and a good amount of eye rolls when site level staff ask for better. It's very transparent what teams and departments are valued (i.e. asset management is a priority, accounting is not, etc.) and if you're not in one of the favored departments you won't have any room for growth. The only way to get your value recognized is to a) be a favorite of the executive over your department or b) threaten to leave. Communication between departments is abysmal. You'll be overworked and severely underpaid. Your work life balance depends on your manager; some are better than others. If you get a bad manager, emails came in at all hours and there were times where I saw people get reprimanded for not responding to something at 12 AM.

title: I Want To Believe This Is A Great Company
pros: Well known company. Mention JBG to anyone in this industry and they'll know exactly who we are and will probably be impressed. -Plenty room for growth, flexibility, and variety. -Great benefits.
cons: -Commission structure can use some vast improvement. -Immediate managers will purposefully give you low evaluation scores to keep you under the radar. -Favoritism is definitely shown and your hard work will go unnoticed if you are not in the fold with the right ppl. -Being creative, residing in the grey areas, and thinking outside of the box in your approach to Leasing and/or Management are frowned upon. If you're more edgy and not as "cookie cutter" as everyone else, don't hope to make many connections here.

title: Poor culture/practices
pros: Resident experience is a high priority. PTO is good but high turnover and being short staffed means you never get to use it.
cons: Our office was acquired by JBG and everyone’s offer to stay with the community contained flat out lies; there were huge pay cuts, the job itself got far more difficult and unorganized, and 45-50 hour work weeks with no lunch breaks became the norm. Borderline Fair Housing violations were common in bad practices that allowed opportunities for some residents and not others in obscure “customer service gestures”. Over time, management implemented a cycle of requiring lower staff to enforce policies that they would then waive entirely when speaking to residents themselves, as if to deliberately make subordinate staff appear incompetent, uncaring, and mean in the eyes of residents. This created an environment in which constant negative reviews for leasing staff diminished any possibility of upward mobility no matter how strong their work ethic or sales skills.

title: Great potential to be and do better
pros: Learning a lot, great onsite team, knowledgeable co-workers
cons: Way too much work. Since the merger, PM office staff has been given a lot more tasks, with little direction and/or support. Although the workload has increased significantly, there is no additional support offered. It is impossible to keep up. Working from home off hours to just stay afloat. Also, Glassdoor keeps sending me emails telling me how underpaid I am. That stings for how hard I work. I would like to mention that these are not legacy VNO legacy changes, as another person said. This is a completely different structures for both legacy teams. It was not like this before.

title: Work life balance, caring management
pros: The regional managers/VPs are always willing to assist with questions and they keep an open dialogue with their managers. JBG Smith genuinely cares about work-life balance, they lead the charge in Diversity + Inclusion, and they sincerely want every one of their team members to succeed. The vacation time is substantial (and they love it when you take it!), we received free Calm subscriptions to help us relax, and they have departments of every kind to assist with tasks so you can focus on working with your team and improving the customer experience. They're constantly developing and acquiring new communities and the future of a career trajectory is limitless. It was hard for me to leave my old company, but I didn't realize how much better my work life could be with a new company until I came on board with JBG Smith.
cons: I wouldn't change a thing!

title: Not terrible but not transparent
pros: offers covid sick pay, pretty good health insurance,
cons: the benefits provided to corporate staff are excellent and very holistic while the same benefits are not available to residential staff. also this is not made very clear when being offered employment. corporate staff get "rest & recharge" time which allows them to take sick/personal time as needed while all other staff must accrue time which forces staff to come to work when sick (unless it's actually covid) and does not support staff wellness especially mental wellness during the most stressful time in recent human history.

title: Excellent employer!
pros: I joined almost ten years ago and have been able to grow my career with this company. They foster an environment that grows employee skillsets from within for future career growth, and I've seen colleague after colleague be able to move up here over the past few years. We're experiencing rapid growth, so there seem to be new opportunities to advance regularly. Very optimistic about the future here! Great benefits, great time off package, very low insurance copays, competitive pay (above average, in my opinion), diverse culture, and a company that seems to truly value each employee. Extremely supportive upper management. Probably the best company culture I have ever worked in.
cons: - Short staffing can be a challenge when we have to operate with less than a full staff. Rapid growth has created a lot of openings that don't seem to get filled fast enough in this economy.

title: Leasing Consultant
pros: Every person I’ve met and worked with is great. The environment is great. I had no prior experience in this industry, and I believe this has been a great way to get my foot in the door.
cons: ultant

title: Project accountant
pros: Generous PTO. Friendly coworkers. Leader in the dc metro RE industry.
cons: Very stressful and competitive in accounting department. This competition is unnecessary in my opinion and leads to drama sometimes. But CAO seems to promote this trend. Very high turnover since the merger. Basically farewell happy hour every two weeks. And no award for the hardworking. Lack a growing space in the company. Management rather pay 10k more to use a consultant than promoting someone from inside. one day a week working from home policy is a jk. Very stingy on compensation.

title: Hostile Work environment
pros: good benefits. COVID regulations are ok. Bonuses are nice.
cons: High turnover meaning job responsibilities overlap. favoritism is real, meaning that management won't take you serious when you are being treated badly by other employers. You will see that HR may respond to this review stating that employers are encouraged to contact when in fact we are actually shushed away by "warnings" so if you speak up against abuse you will be reprimanded instead. Pay is not worth it for the treatment you get here. The job itself is very overwhelming because they expect you to do your job while doing the job of others (in this case management) In my time here, I had seen two employers had breakdowns and walk out the job. When you mention this to management all they say is "okay" and then side with the abuser. It's important to build paper-trail if you want to work for this company.

title: High Recommend!
pros: JBGS promotes a high level of work/life balance. They encourage their employees to take much needed time off while still meeting goals and deadlines. JBGS is one of the few or maybe even the only property management company to offer unlimited PTO to their corporate employees as well as a flexible schedule of 3 days in the office and 2 days of telework each week. I feel like JBGS leadership really listens to your feedback and takes it seriously. I really enjoying knowing that I am contributing to the overall great good of the organization.
cons: Don't have any serious cons in my overall personal experience in my 2.5 years with the company.

title: Fantastic Entry-Level Job
pros: Corporate has an awesome atmosphere, everyone is motivated, energetic, and ambitious. Great learning opportunities, and obvious room for growth/promotion since the company is rapidly growing/expanding. Coming from a company with a weak HR department, it's also refreshing to see that HR is responsive/actively reaches out to ensure that your transition is going well (for example, they have sent everyone 2 gift-baskets in the last 2 months during WFH!) Benefits/pay are also wonderful. Stock discount/401K matching is competitive, and healthcare/dental/vision is very affordable. Tuition reimbursement is also one of the highest in DC, plus the new office is unbelievable. Note to individuals considering JBG Smith: please remember that many of these reviews are from property staff, not from corporate staff. Not to discount property staff's experiences working for JBG Smith, but the corporate work experience is obviously going to be different than the property staff work experience. I almost didn't accept my position because of some of the comments posted on Glassdoor, but a few months in, I'm so glad I accepted my offer.
cons: So far there hasn't been a lot of company social events, but of course, we're in the middle of COVID-19. Supposedly there's an annual booze cruise in October, but I'm guessing that is cancelled due to the pandemic. Either way, it could be nice if the company offered smaller virtual social events to get to know fellow co-workers/individuals in different departments since we aren't returning to the office until Spring. The only real "con" is that unlike other major REITS in the DC area (Avalon Bay Communities, etc.), JBG Smith does not offer an employee rent discount on company owned properties (but I can also see why so this isn't a real con and more of a wish). That said, with DC housing prices skyrocketing, I could easily see myself jumping to a REIT that offers such a program in the future if such an opportunity arose (just since rent is so expensive/huge part of any person living in DC's budget)

title: Great Company!
pros: Innovation and expansion are the name of the game with JBGS! Lots of opportunity for growth if you are successful in your role because of this. The company focuses heavily on customer service excellence to be an industry leader. They are also very generous with paid time off.
cons: Recruiting for all of the opportunities has been challenging the past few years. Much of this is likely pandemic-related, but not sure what efforts have been made internally to alter recruitment strategies in the new climate. This has lead to some properties being short-staffed for extended periods. With much more in the pipeline hopefully there is focus on this.

title: Major Upset After JBG/Vornado Merge
pros: Keeping the same benefits as JBG
cons: Vornado upper management making unnecessary policy changes that make the job more difficult and frustrating. As a former JBG employee we were once independent and self sufficient, now we're being controlled as well as confused by the lack of communication and plain ignorance for what we were once and still are capable of achieving.

title: Great company to work for!
pros: This is my first full-time job out of college and I love working here! The employees are friendly, approachable, and always willing to help and be a resource. The company culture here is incredible! They really value your work/life balance, training, and growth.
cons: Not a company con, but Covid-19 has affected all workplaces. JBG Smith has taken numerous measures to ensure the health and well-being of its staff. With work from home days, on-site company testing, free access to the Calm app, and constant email updates on the ever-changing Covid-19 mandates, I can tell that the company really cares about its employees physical and mental health.

title: Company
pros: JBG is lax about their standards so you have an opportunity to make the community your own and they are willing to spend the money on their employees.
cons: There doesn't seem to be a concrete level of organization. The Regional Manager is not the best person in her position an the side of empathy, building employees and doesn't know how to handle people effectively. She is amazing when it comes to processes and procedures. Teachers have to teach students differently, and so do managers. They need to adapt to their employees.

title: Favoritism and politics infested company.
pros: Good company to get your experience level up to par then move on to a more reputable source.
cons: Too many suck ups that don't deserve to be promoted are all over the company, not to mention terrible regional managers with stuck up attitudes and a portfolio manager that likes to argue and be rude to people below her.

title: Good people in general, good benefits
pros: Clearly defined job responsibilities (this IS important). Leasing bonuses are paid on time and are fairly generous. Little contact with senior management, so the local manager is the manager you get for good or ill.
cons: Companies of this size must necessarily have set policies, but this can lead to a rather robotic "check these boxes" experience, especially when it comes to disciplinary measures.

title: Best In The Biz
pros: I started with JBG Companies as a concierge and after 4 years I left JBG Smith as an Assistant Community Manager. I have been given the opportunity to work at some of the most beautiful Class A multifamily assets in the DMV area, and the experience/skills I've gained has made me a highly sought after candidate in the PM job market. There is PLENTY of room for advancement, the benefits are great, the company is structured and professional, and for the most part they seek out the best talent.
cons: The pay is not so great. Everything else was trivial...

title: Great Experience, Great People, Lots of Work
pros: - The people and community are great. There are plenty of fun personalities in and outside of the corporate office, of all different ages and stripes. It is a very welcoming place. - The work is challenging but fulfilling. There is a lot of opportunity to learn on unique properties, and you are encouraged to take projects and run with them. You will get a ton of good experience in the industry. - The office is beautiful and its amenities are amazing. Brand new in late 2019. - Senior Management did a fantastic job steering the company through COVID. Matt Kelly is a great leader. - The company is growing which has both pros and cons. A major pro is that it is a very interesting company on an exciting trajectory (Amazon/VT, etc).
cons: - JBGS is still emerging from the IPO/merger in 2017, so there are growing pains in terms of some of the processes. Things have gotten a lot better over the last few years but there are still some things that need work. Within accounting, they are implementing new software that should make close more efficient and free up some time, however: - Regardless of how efficient they get, it seems expected that you will still have to work a ton to meet your deadlines. Throughout busy season, you'll have at least a couple of late nights per week on average, and will have to work on some weekends in order to meet close deadlines. - The accounting department has grown so much that advancement is becoming a bit more difficult. However that could change if there is any major post-COVID turnover.

title: Great Company, Brilliant Minds, Great Intentions!!
pros: Great minds, highly motivated, genuine leaders/people with great intentions. Head and shoulders above the competition in terms of a dedicated approach to diversity and inclusion. There is a lot of commitment to giving back to our extended communities, and opportunities for associates to volunteer on the clock.
cons: New technology is taken on at a pace that the average person finds difficult to absorb and implement.

title: I love working for JBG SMITH
pros: In my experience, JBG is an honest company and my morals align closely with their Core Values. I love that they are actively working to make housing affordable for those in need and they support other groups through JBG Cares. As a Residential employee, I really enjoy working with my direct supervisor and believe they would go to bat for me in just about any situation. I want to perform at a higher level because of them. JBG SMITH put a lot of thought and effort info how they operated through the pandemic. They took a conservative approach to re-opening which was difficult at times, but was ultimately for the health and wellbeing of its employees and customers. JBG paid team members that worked on site "Hazard Pay" in relation to COVID for about a year. All JBG employees working at the property level were eligible and we were automatically paid $3.50/hr in addition to their hourly wage. This was almost a 20% raise for many front line employees in a very uncertain time. The benefits package is very solid. JBG contributes 50% of what I contribute toward my 401k -- up to 3%. I feel that my PTO and mental health are prioritized at JBG SMITH. We now have a Cultural Reflection day each year that can be used as an additional personal day with no questions asked. JBG was on top of Juneteenth becoming a Federal Holiday and within hours of the presidential announcement, we were notified that offices would be closed the following Monday in observance of this Holiday. JBG Residential gave site team members two extra personal days to use between 1/1/22 and 2/28/22 citing that the teams working on site had been resilient through the pandemic and they wanted us to take time to mentally prepare for the upcoming season. JBG SMITH sent employees multiple care packages throughout the pandemic with food/snacks, board games, and a notes from the executive team. Matt Kelly (CEO) created weekly videos and sent them to the entire company to talk to us about new things happening at JBG to keep the entire company clued into how things were going. He often encouraged team members to stay healthy and stay home as our health was most important. Health/Dental takes care of practically wherever I want to go (including Georgetown MedStar). I cannot say enough about how great JBG SMITH has been as an employer.
cons: Residential Property Management is an industry that I personally believe should see some salary increases across the board.

title: Understaffed. Corporate culture. Good benefits
pros: Pay and benefits are competitive. In 2015, JBG offered CareFirst Blue Cross Blue Shield.
cons: Understaffed and chaotic office with overlapping job responsibilities. High turnover. Inadequate company procedure to address bedbugs and other pests, meaning angry residents and helpless staff. Many corporate platitudes, but little genuine responsiveness to employee frustrations.

title: An interesting introduction into Property Management
pros: You will receive all of your benefits after the first full month working with the company. There is great health insurance and flexible leave. There is a wide variety of opportunities within the company if you don't necessarily like where you are currently.
cons: Every property operates differently and you have to be quick to adapt to those specific differences. Essentially a residential management position as you are expected to fill many hats with an average starting pay.

title: All talk and no change
pros: They have good benefits, different departments are better than others.
cons: I’ve stayed because I’ve been there for a few years. Things haven’t always been bad sadly since the merger there is little valve put on individuals. They will say there is but they don’t actually deliver. The environment is very cliquey and they seem to be hiring more young people and weeding out tenured staff.

title: Good company
pros: -benefits are great -coworker atmosphere is good -several employee events througout year -major holidays off and extra days off for working holidays -upper management gets to know everyone -training available
cons: -compensation is not always the greatest -sometimes they try to save money too much and don't want to spend money to fix issues on site -sometimes willing to overlook vendor issues in order to save money

title: Great Company!
pros: JBG offers Unbeatable Benefits, they have a great management team, friendly environment, consistent training, plenty of growth opportunities and amazing teams.
cons: I can't think of any cons for this company. Mindy, Duanne, Michelle and Cynthia need to keep being great leaders!

title: I truly love my job…
pros: From leasing consultant to senior community manager, I have always felt supported and valued as an employee.
cons: The company’s portfolio is growing fast, I fear corporate support won’t be able to keep up with on-site needs to be as successful as they could be.

title: Great company
pros: If you have a great team then it helps a lot. The accounting department is large so you will encounter a variety of personalities and work styles. Depending on the person that could be a bad thing, but for me it felt like a pro because it was great exposure.
cons: I stayed as long as I have because I enjoyed my team, but not much room for advancement, and the work doesn't change much as you transition from entry to senior.

title: Great company who values their employees
pros: one of the things that stood out to me during my tenure at JBG is how down to earn upper management was. I truly felt valued as an employee. JBG invest a lot of time and resources into their employee therefore making you a better at your job. Not to mention the benefits are fantastic and salary competitive to other property management companies
cons: None that i can think of

title: Minimal support and non existent training.
pros: Good benefits and vacation, however management gets frustrated when you take it because they have to support you while you are gone.
cons: Support to the properties is minimal, you are expected to work with staff shortages for long periods of time, hiring process is very slow and does not benefit employees or residents.

title: Of all the great organizations I've worked for, JBG SMITH is the best of the best
pros: From the top down, everyone cares for and respects everyone else. Everyone focuses on helping our customers and helping each other help our customers.
cons: The pace is fast. There is always a lot to do. Mostly this is just a part of the challenge of being part of a successful team, but it can be very challenging sometimes.

title: Great place to work and start your career
pros: Incredible access to deal-level experience and key decision makers. Very flat organization run by the best in the business in the DC market. No hierarchy, will be given as much responsibility as you can handle.
cons: Work hard play hard environment. Exactly what you should expect from a PE shop. Base pay is low for the hours, but made up for in year-end bonus if you are a high performer.

title: Great Culture with the Ability to Advance
pros: JBG SMITH offers a great culture with a collaborative environment in a beautiful office setting with perks such as being able to wear shorts and bringing your dog to work. If you work hard, you will be rewarded.
cons: JBG SMITH offers lots of opportunities to be involved in unique and challenging transactions. If you are looking for an easy job, this is not the place for you.

title: Toxic environment, poor management, & lack of advancement
pros: The new office & decent benefits (unlimited PTO & good insurance coverage)
cons: I’m surprised by the amount of positive on this company considering the large turnover it has experience over the last couple of years, and the turnover continues even more so recently since the merger. This company loses quality employees because it lacks proper training structures within teams, an actual career path for many employees who are not in either accounting or development (as they are treated much differently than other teams), nepotism, negative/toxic work culture, and lack of work/life balance. The churn and burn from their field employees are even worse than corporate. They’re often left on their own and feel forgotten, unsupported, and less than next to corporate employees. There’s zero room for growth and this company has made it known they will keep their employee base status quo. Their retention strategies are to either offer to transfer an employee or promote them when it is too late. I see reviews that make claims about the positive direction the company is taking on diversity but it STILL severely lacks that across their executive management on down. Most of the executive leadership are there to stay and that makes it hard for others to attain upward movement unless those at the top leave. Not to mention, the executives and senior managers perpetuate the toxic culture, which was carried over from pre-merger. You’re seeing turnover in development, accounting, marketing, and HR. Very concerning to me, but not surprised. The management overseeing these groups are who cultivated and continue to perpetuate the negativity and toxicity. I don’t expect that to change unless they leave. You’ll either be pushed out or reach your breaking point here. It’s not worth it, especially for the below market pay that you’re given for the lack of work life balance. I would be cautious when reading these very vague, scripted positive reviews as it doesn’t reflect the current turn over they’re experiencing. Talk to any employee who is currently at the company and those who have left because you will hear the truth behind what goes on and this company is not headed in a positive, upward direction. Sad since this company has potential but I don’t see it succeeding.

title: Fast Paced
pros: Great team and great coworker's. hyrbid schedule and the company is working on some amazing projects that have HUGE impacts within the community. Tech is always changing and staying up to date .
cons: The company has a lot of big projects down the pipe line which is resulting in a very fast paced environment. There are long hours and lots of opportunities however, the team is under staffed with this transactions occurring.

title: Amazing company
pros: Many amazing corporate executives. Donna is beyond amazing and truly cares for everyone. They believe in you and will push you to grow as long as you want it. For anyone that works hard and wants to grow in the property management industry…this is the company for you.
cons: I can’t think of any. It’s an amazing company with great benefits and policies.

title: Leasing
pros: I work for JGB company well-known in DMV establish company
cons: No training! Upper management was a task master! My hours was from 8am to 9pm I was the first to work and last to leave constantly picking up the next employee slack! I believe In team work! But that was and understatement. The lynbrook and meadow creek office is manage very unorganized! Resident very aggressive and disrespectful no employee protection. You just left out there to fend for yourself! Resident would over crowd the leasing office with all kinds of demands. Management will not assisted would disappear from the office every time.

title: Toxic work environment, lack of advancement, poor management
pros: Office space (new) & healthcare benefits
cons: Extremely toxic work environment where employees are overworked, under appreciated, under paid, and treated poorly by their managers (particularly if you are in accounting and HR). Very much an ‘old boys club’ or ‘frat’ culture, especially in development where employees of this department act entitled, pretentious, and have overinflated egos because of their Ivy League degrees. Other departments have a ‘bully’ culture within their teams, showing favoritism and promoting inappropriate office behavior (I.e. gossip and poor treatment towards their employees). The accounting department has very high turnover, lacking proper management and training of their new employees. HR has had a lot of turnover since the change in their management. HR executives have replaced many long standing employees with their friends or colleagues from Marriott. Hiring and recruiting practices are questionable — a lot of favoritism and nepotism occur and are mostly driven by executives and managers who hire employees as a favor. Discrimination and biased hiring decisions happen often here (I.e. hiring managers give preference to candidates with Ivy League degrees or specific brick & mortar universities versus hiring a candidate based on skills and experience). Executives hire employees in secret and make drastic changes to their staff without notice, which creates distrust amongst their employees and reflects poor recruiting practices. Their recruiting team experienced high turnover and what once was a positive team that cared about their employees, has been replaced with employees who further perpetuate the toxic work culture and don’t seem to know what they’re doing. The company has made slight improvements to their diversity and inclusion when looking at their demographics, but there’s still a lack of female and minority representation at the executive and management level. For non-corporate positions — there is an extremely high turnover rate at the property sites. The company lacks competitive pay and strong work culture that extends to their field employees. This company doesn’t provide you with any advancement or a clear career path. Onboarding and training don’t exist. You will sink or swim. One day you’re ‘in’ the next day you are ‘out’ without warning. Don’t let the fancy new office space fool you, you’re better off at a company that is employee-centric with stronger values and ethics.

title: Learned a lot
pros: They like to promote within the company so there’s a lot of opportunity for growth.
cons: Heavy work load and does not match the pay.. and your experience is really based on who your manager is. There’s no consistency in the properties and every property manager does things differently.

cons: Expanding rapidly and hard to keep up with. Centralized model does not always consider individual objectives or obstacles.

title: Amazing company
pros: Kilroy is a collaborative, innovative, and supportive workplace that values growth, sustainability, and long-term vision.
cons: None at all its a great company

title: A Dynamic Journey of Growth and Opportunity at Kilroy
pros: Culture and Environment: Kilroy promotes a friendly and creative workplace where everyone collaborates and shares ideas. The company value their employees, making it easy to communicate and build lasting friendships within the team. Career Development: One of the standout aspects of Kilroy is its commitment to employee growth. I was encouraged to pursue professional development opportunities. I’ve had the privilege of being promoted multiple times, and each step along the way was supported by my managers, who genuinely invested in my success. Work-Life Balance: Kilroy understands that life outside of work is just as important as the work we do. I appreciate that my well-being is a priority. Innovation and Impact: Kilroy is at the forefront of innovation and sustainable practices in our industry that positively impact our communities and the environment. It’s inspiring to be part of a team that prioritizes not just profitability, but also social responsibility.
cons: While my experience at Kilroy has been overwhelmingly positive, there are a few areas that could use improvement: Workload Fluctuations: There are times when workload can get heavy. During these times, it is hard to balance work and life; and some team members may find it tough to keep up. Communication Gaps: While the open-door policy is great, there are times when departments don't communicate well. Keeping all teams updated on projects/tasks can help everyone work better together and improved efficiency.

title: Great Company with Supportive Culture and Growth Opportunities
pros: I thoroughly enjoy my time working at Kilroy Realty. The company fosters a collaborative and inclusive culture where employees feel valued and supported. Leadership genuinely cares about employee well-being, which is evident through their transparent communication and commitment to professional development. What stands out the most is the emphasis on growth. The company provides ample opportunities for learning, whether through training programs, mentorship, or challenging projects that allow you to expand your skill set. Team members are approachable and always willing to help, creating an environment where you can thrive both personally and professionally. Work-life balance is respected, and the benefits are competitive, making this an even more attractive place to work. The management team encourages innovation and truly listens to employee feedback, which has made a significant difference in day-to-day work satisfaction. Overall, Kilroy Realty is a fantastic place to build a fulfilling career. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a company that values its employees and encourages growth and collaboration!
cons: No Cons at this time

title: Not the worst, not the best
pros: Work life balance Snacks + lunches twice a week My team
cons: No flexibility to work remotely. Leadership doesn’t care about how employees feel about it. They have an annual survey asking employees what they like and don’t like, but when sharing the results they never go over the things that people noted that they disliked. Survey is pointless if they only highlight the good and don’t give as much as a mention of the bad.

title: it all depends on your department.
pros: if you have a good manager/department, they’ll protect you from corporate and HR’s mismanagement. good benefits.
cons: if you have a manager/department head that fears upper management, you’ll be subjected to some of the most outdated conditions and regulations imaginable. Upper management is floundering with the way things are moving towards remote office work. all decisions are driven by emotion and temper at the top. no consideration for the morale of worker bees. HUGE boys club/sexism is rampant.

title: Negative Work Environment
pros: As a former employee who dedicated many years with the company, the SD region doesn’t shine like it used to. I’ve seen the region in its glory days when we had talented leaderships who were competent at their jobs. They were professional, reasonable, supportive, and treated everyone like family. There was growth and clear directions for the team. It was the place where everyone wants to be.
cons: The current upper management is selective about who they want to promote. In the last several years, promotion has been based on favoritism vs performance. Employees who are dedicated and show up are often overlooked with little to no recognition. Asset managers would talk badly about their own teammates in front of others. You can hear them outside the office complaining loudly and not even trying to be discreet about it. Instead of fixing known issues, bad behaviors are often ignored and rewarded with constant praises and promotions which greatly affects office morale. Management is aware of the issues but instead of reporting it, some choose to jump on the bandwagon and disregard the problem, while others fear retaliation. High turnover of employees is a good indicator that there is a problem within the department. Often it is only talked about when the employee has left the company.

title: Great Company, supportive environment
pros: Kilroy really values their employees at all levels and encourages their growth, understanding each person's success yields even greater success for the Company as a whole.
cons: Expanding specialized IT resources is necessary to meet the demand of process improvement within all platforms companywide.

title: Great company!
pros: Fantastic offices, supportive team, and fair compensation.
cons: Long hours and semi-thankless job (property management as a whole).

title: Amazing company with supportive culture
pros: I’m a Senior Analyst at Kilroy Realty in Los Angeles, and I’ve had a great experience here. The team is supportive, and collaboration is encouraged at every level. Leadership is clear and transparent, which makes it easy to stay focused and aligned. There are plenty of opportunities for growth, and the benefits are excellent. The office is a great place to work, and the company genuinely cares about employee well-being. Work-life balance is a priority, which I really appreciate.
cons: It’s hard to find any real negatives. Sometimes there’s a lot happening at once, but the team is great at working together to handle it.

title: Great benefits
pros: lunches provided a few times per week
cons: not being able to work remotely

title: Recommend Against
pros: SD Region | There are some lovely people that you will work with who make the hard days much easier. This includes accounting, office managers, and engineering. Engineering especially props up Kilroy and is the backbone of the San Diego region.
cons: Upper management (Asset Managers/Vice President) are only looking out for themselves and falsely make you believe that you are part of a team. They love to pit employees against each other in order to weed out those they don't like. There is also an issue of favoritism amongst higher management and unfortunately, if you aren't part of their clique, you will be pushed out. During my tenor, 7 people came and left.

title: Poor Leadership and People Management
pros: Nice coworkers, good pay, high quality buildings and tenants. Willing to spend on capital
cons: The SD leadership team for Asset Mgmt was fast tracked for promotion with no real skills on leading a large team. Their default is now to put people on PIPs to “guide them” but they really just destroy morale with no actual feedback or path. No matter your role you are micromanaged to death and expected to run everything you do (literally every thing) by your manager. The lack of autonomy is inefficient and you’re left with Senior leadership who miss deadlines, don’t sign things for weeks, constantly canceling and rescheduling meetings. They will throw you under the bus to cover for their own inadequacies the first chance they get. The new Head of People brought in to “fix” the culture is demeaning and encourages PIPs as a people management tool. No warning, no conversation just immediate PIP.

title: Great Place to Work and New CEO Making Positive Changes

cons: Changes move slowly, procedures aren't well documented

Much of this was due to the personality of the former leader, who wanted to take sole credit for wins but spread blame for any losses.

title: No culture, poor management
pros: - Health and dental benefits are really amazing. Insurance covers some orthodontics.
cons: - No company culture. Different departments rarely if ever cross-socialize. Don't expect to make friends, get a free lunch, or enjoy any company-sponsored perks. - Pay is sub-par. The company is filthy rich, but you'll get paid like it's in trouble. Remember that the CEO has a private jet and personal driver. - Most of the positions are hourly, including mid-level professional positions. Have fun filling out every minute of your day on your time sheet. - There are toxic personalities who are in high positions and have sway with the CEO. - CEO needs to be babied and his opinion matters more than anyone else's. - Everyone does whatever the CEO asks, no matter how ridiculous. It's cult-like. - Certain managers will breathe down your neck, micro-manage, and otherwise only judge you for how many hours you have your butt in your seat and not the quality of work you do. - Ridiculous standard of what is good work (ie. sitting at your computer = good) and no benefit to putting in effort or producing quality work. - Babying parental controls on your computer.

title: Love It!

title: Okay as a Starting Point, Not as a Forever Home
pros: - Excellent health benefits and 401 policy - Well-kept offices and workspaces - A lot to learn depending on which department you’re in
cons: - The often touted “open door policy” by higher-ups is nothing more than lip service. Those at the VP and above are generally difficult to approach and not particularly engaging with the “lower level” staff - Promotions are arbitrarily handed out to those that have favored status with management (reflected in the high number of VPs and SVPs the company has for its size) - Pay is average however the promotion bumps are insultingly low - HR is unhelpful when it comes to inquiries and resolving disputes - CEO often espouses his personal political views in company wide emails

title: Great & Motivating Environment for Growth
pros: Successful at acquiring and managing buildings and developments. Focused on meeting Tenant demands, even the most outrageous, but also dedicated to satisfying environmental obligations. Very professional but still enjoyable atmosphere. I personally believe that a sense of humor is a necessity in life! Undoubtedly we have to be concerned about how our words affect others and this region makes sure it is done right. Kilroy Realty is awesome because of its employees, who are focused on work and growing the company and its reputation in the REIT world vs. pleasing select insecure, self-centered and dissatisfied employees. Management encourages professional growth and development through many opportunities like classes, promotions, organizational involvement. Good company..
cons: Communication needs to be more transparent between all levels of personnel.

title: Below Market Pay - Old Boys Club - No Room for Growth
pros: Summer Fridays, free parking, nice people (lower levels).
cons: Below Market Pay: All of their competitors pay significantly more, for similar work. "Discretionary" bonus instead of a target bonus so employees are unable to plan their finances or know how much they expect to make. Raises don't meet inflation. Public company but offers NO stock purchase plan, no stock grants, nothing (until VP+). Old Boys Club: Everything is relationship based, and that includes massive nepotism for those with relationships with the CEO. Promotions are relationship based not performance based. Senior leadership is very disconnected. No Room for Growth: Senior leadership never leaves and career opportunities stall fairly quickly. Flexibility isn't there, they are making people come in 4 days week after a year of doing well at home. Large attrition rate as people realize this and leave, usually around 1-2 years.

title: Disappointing Place
pros: Cool holiday party in LA and free parking at all of their buildings.
cons: This company tries to project a sleek and forward image, but acts backwards. -Everyone up to mid-level employees are hourly. The last time I was hourly was my first job out of college. -New employees start out on 90 day probationary periods, which again is not typical for mid level employees at this level. -They have web filters installed on everyone's computers, something I've only seen at small offices. It's also silly since everyone has a smart phone. -The promotions are very top heavy and seem to be based on personal relationships. This company has lots of Directors, VPs, and SVPs who are always getting promoted and expecting those below them to be super excited for them. -The CEO likes to spew his right wing political views during earnings calls, which is awkward considering the cities where the company conducts its business. -The medical insurance premiums are also very high compared to all the other places I've worked.

title: Great company with some bad apples
pros: -Very sleek, modern office -"Open Air" cubicles -Good amenities -Nice 401k -Free snacks, beverages, etc.
cons: -Internal promotion is EXTREMELY difficult (unless you have bosses who actually pay attention) -False "open door" policy -Long hours -Massive disconnect between "upper management" and "support staff" (VP & above) -Company culture -Lack of employee appreciation -When an employee continually (for years) causes strife and grief within your team - LET THEM GO. Just because a weak link has been there for a long time, does not mean it's good for the chain. -Management does not want to "rock the boat" / operates out of fear

title: The snake rots at the head
pros: I am unable to clearly define any positive attributes, as the hostile environment overshadows everything.
cons: A VP used vile and nasty language to openly speak about someone he had a strange fixation for. While a few autonomous thinkers recognized this obsessive, malicious, and gender specific harassment for what it was, more senior staff members consistently ignored it. This manager did not appear to have the confidence to stand alone in his bizarre and troubling contempt. Rather, he systematically influenced persuadable staff to isolate and harass his target, with no concern for their professional reputations whatsoever.

title: Loved working at this company and cherish my experience and time spent!

title: Tread carefully and proceed with caution
pros: As far as corporate America goes, Kite's probably pretty standard. There is nothing particularly extraordinary about them; they're not going to win "best place to work" anytime soon. The benefits at Kite are where it's at. While their base pay is subpar for the tenured employees, the bonus structure, benefits plans, stock options, PTO policy, and other fringe benefits are top-notch. There is a handful of amazing employees that go above and beyond for the team and company and will make the endless job so much more manageable. The financials and the numbers are good for Kite. They're a solid company with a secure future - number wise. If they don't shape up some of the personnel issues, the numbers might start suffering.
cons: You will be overworked while they tout work/life balance in your face. They (meaning the Leadership group) like to run as lean as possible. And yes, while this saves overhead costs, it runs employees ragged. You're given an above average amount of PTO but will struggle to find time to use it without digging yourself a nearly impossible hole upon return. Good news is that if you're a bad employee, it's almost impossible for you to get terminated from your job. The phrase "it's better to have a butt in the seat than a cold seat" was said a few times. It's an awful mindset and kills the morale of your good employees. The salary discrepancy between tenured employees and new employees is in the stratosphere. New employees are hired in lightyears above tenured employees and yet they wonder why tenured employees are few and far between these days. The only fairly compensated tenured employees are those at the VP or higher level. There is a boys-club and the Employee Experience (HR) team doesn't aid in curbing this perception. There is clear favoritism towards the males at the company. The bulk of the Senior Leadership team is white males; there are only 3 women in the senior leadership team. The lack of overall diversity in the leadership team also can't go unmentioned. Be careful who you tell things to at Kite; nothing is kept secret. It's a gossip mill. NOTHING is sacred at Kite. If you're lucky, you'll find a little group who you can confide in but be cautious of the bulk of people. It's a dog-eat-dog environment at Kite and people will use things you've said against you in a heartbeat if they think it will get them ahead. After the merger in October 2021, the company more than doubled in size. This was primarily handled okay, but Kite's been unsuccessful in bringing some departments around to Kite protocol. Asset Management is the biggest issue in this front - the leadership, or lack thereof, needs revamping here. They're running amuck for the most part in that department; doing their own thing on their own timelines, not following SOPs, throwing bottlenecks into processes. And with no repercussions.
