cons: I throughly enjoyed my time there. No complaints at all about management, perks or other employees. Great place to work.

title: Decent Company
pros: the office was centrally located, making it logistically easy to do my job.
cons: had to use my own car to drive upwards of 250-300 miles/wk in order to complete my job and compensation for gas, wear and tear on my car, and mileage use was dismal.

title: Still About 40 years Behind - Both in Culture and Technology
pros: Salaried employees are paid pretty well. Good 401K benefits. Some actually really great people if you take the time to get to know them. The fact the company is so disorganized means that you can get really good experience doing things you might technically not be qualified for on your resume. So it can be a great place to learn new skills if you're resourceful and get yourself on projects that your interested in.
cons: This company has so much potential that is constantly squandered by poor management and a cultural mindset that is still stuck in the "good old boys club" days of advertising. Management has absolutely zero interest in technology - even though they sure pretend to in pitch meetings to clients. Meanwhile, the inventory tracking system runs on a platform from the 80s. You literally open up to a black screen with a blinking neon green cursor. I feel like I might as well be in an SNL sketch. When I left at the end of 2019, they still did not even have Salesforce ... they said they were just about to launch it when I started in 2016. When the possibility of actually moving the company into the 21st century is raised to management there is a lot of push back from high level sales people who just feel more comfortable selling the same billboard the same way they've been selling it for the past 15 years. And there is a lot of favoritism, so when one of the good old boys complains, they usually get their way.

title: Good enough I guess.
pros: It is great if you want to be in Sales
cons: Too many acquisitions/buyouts. Company does not seems to have a set identity/culture.

title: Great company
pros: Love the people and the environment
cons: Nothing to share, everything is great over here

title: Good place to work
pros: Good people and great chance to learn
cons: Not flexible and office is a bit depressing

title: Sales Coordinator Review
pros: Flexibility, Autonomy, and great people
cons: Low Pay and not a lot of upward growth

title: Overall great culture and work environment
pros: Great management that empowers you to be your own leader. Remote work, family style employment. Listens to your concerns and does not micro manage you.
cons: Not great pay, not much room for career advancement

title: Good leadership but Slow to change
pros: Good leadership in many areas. They do a good job rotating people around.
cons: Diversity lacking in the senior level. Mostly white men in leadership positions. Slow to change & adapt.

title: Great workplace!
pros: It is a Fun Challenging workplace where Great people work
cons: I don’t have any downsides

title: Good
pros: Work life balance, culture, people
cons: Guidance, a lot of moving parts

title: Great Company to for
pros: Commissions, stock, 401, PTO, summer Fridays
cons: training for new hires could be better

title: Spokane manager John: Great, everyone else - bad
pros: Working with the Spokane team, mostly, is great!
cons: G Todd, NY management and HR are all a joke.

title: Easy going
pros: Easy going Comfortable pace great community
cons: Sometimes bureaucratic, sometimes cliquish, sometimes overwhelming

title: Great Company So Far
pros: Friendly work environment Flexible hours Good compensation
cons: Promotion can be tricky blah

title: Stable company
pros: Solid company with decent leadership
cons: Very political and outdated tools

title: Horrible Working Conditions
pros: Good hours for people with families
cons: Overworking in horrible conditions. Would sometimes put up 5-10 billboards in extremely hot or rainy weather. Dangerous and overworked.

title: Great Place for Creative Cultivation
pros: -supportive environment for fearless creative exploration -ownership of every project and client -friendly employees -corporate perks
cons: -you must have patience for those that do not understand out of home (that's most people)

title: The definition of cronyism
pros: Some really smart people work here but this is barely a pro because they are the most ignored.
cons: Outfront used to be called CBS outdoor and there is a clique of leadership that came over from that. If you suck up to them you will do well. Maybe. A lot of their decision making doesn't have much rhyme or reason. If you're not a straight white male....run as far as you can. The abuse, corruption, and nepotism here is unimaginable.

title: Good work environment but infrastructure needs refinjng
pros: Great work place and culture
cons: Not enough strong leaders making decisions

title: Good
pros: Good company good benefits and opportunity
cons: None no downside for the company

title: Solid
pros: Good people and good culture
cons: Pay could be more, coordinator position is hourly

title: Good company but do your research
pros: what i feel are fair/basic benefits. 2 weeks vacation, 8 sick days, holidays. 401K, United Healthcare (basic or plus), dental and vision. You get prorated time off depending on what quarter you began working, for example if you start in august you get 3 vacations and a personal, i think. something like that. Then on Jan 1 it resets for all current employees so there is no vesting/waiting period for insurance or PTO
cons: LOTS of systemic issues that are not being address because CEO and top managers either don't know or more likely, don't care as long as money is being made. Managers don't know what they're managing or how to do it, the software is created BY and FOR outfront media, and is very old. creates a lot of unnecessary work. They are TERRIFIED of auditors and will make you do every single little thing by the book no matter what.

title: Stuck in the 90s
pros: Recently there have been impressive hires. There is a woman from Time and CNN who started the “dream team” as it’s called. She is one of the smartest hires they’ve made yet true to form the company mutes her and pushes her down to conform with existing sub-par general marketing employees they think are great, so the fear is she’ll leave. She is transforming the sales support process. She’s a smart, strong and stable leader. Her group comes out with the best ideas and most impressive work. A breath of fresh air. Technology changes are coming thanks to new CTO. The amount of time wasted is at record levels. No ones computer works, wifi so slow it takes hours to download a file, public drives have no space to store work, employees aren’t allowed to use basic tools that other companies use like google docs. The offices are frozen in time, but seems like the new CTO is making improvements slowly. New creative hire in NY hopefully will be able to elevate that team.
cons: Favoritism over talent and intelligence. Management loves their chosen few even though they lack work ethic, lie on expense reports and are average at best. Operations teams are working in systems that are decades old. Time will tell if new talent gets left on the vine to die due to rampant favoritism and internal politics

title: Someone Blow Up the Life Rafts
pros: The people that work here are solid. My and others local General Managers and Sales Managers and office support staff are solid.
cons: Sales Force gets crumbs while the funding of our supposed "future" sucks us dry. No change in 2018 to the Commission program thats so complicated and retarded it's comical. It still has a 10% hold back of our money. Budgets when you finally get them are wrong and you have to fight with analysts to get it right. No respect for the Sales Force. Worse now then when we were part of CBS. Executive Leadership has no spine. Too much over hiring. Overspending. Don't trust the Executive Sales Leadership. Future looks grim for Sales Force. Morale sucks and Executive Leadership doesn't care. People are losing more respect for CEO Jeremy Male every day.

title: Great Company in Need of Modernization
pros: Good, strong company with great foundational assets to sell and good people throughout. Commitment to stay relevant through investments in technology, location, creativity. Digital transformation efforts underway to help modernize internal and client-facing platforms. Long-term income potential is strong, as top sellers can earn comparable pay to Sr. Enterprise Tech / SAAS sellers. Mid-levels are paid well too. People tend to stay for very long tenures.
cons: Traditional media roots show in their antiquated, disparate franken-systems and inefficient sales / support structure. Sellers waste far too much time doing media planning, proposal building, account management, contracting, etc. that are done by account managers and sales planners at modern organizations. Corporate push for full-time in-office work is out of touch with current reality that employees are far more productive and happy with flexible arrangements. Comp plan is terribly designed, lacks transparency is different for every seller.

title: Too much politics
pros: I absolutely loved the people i worked it, i truly did, they make coming in to work each day fun and exciting. the company tries to make it's employees happy, To little success, but at least they are trying.
cons: Too much politics at this company. Working hard really don't get you any where in this company, at least in the department i worked in. You can work as hard as you like, but if upper management doesn't take a liking to you (AKA part of the click), you are not going anywhere. I have seen people coming up with wonderful ideas, but gets rejected depending on who its coming from, only to be reintroduced by later, by one of click members. If you are not part of the click, your hard work is never reward, ever. Also a lot of upper management don't take too kindly to legit criticism

title: Excruciating.......
pros: I won't lie, I gained a lot of corporate/office experience which I was able to apply to move on and forward. I made some great connections internally and externally from co-workers to clients.
cons: Antiquated company with little to no regard of becoming part of the 21st century. Little to no chance of actually growth into management of Executive roles. Lack of diversity across the entire organization unless if you're a Sales Assistant or Receptionist. My direct manager was a Great Guy and superb sales man but his management skills are boot camp worthy. Terrible, undermining, rules with an iron fist and clearly borderline undertone of stereotyping based on the accounts I would get AND not get. I had a constant struggle wanting to actually come in to work. Not because of the job it self but because of the people running it. To put it in perspective I felt I was behind enemy lines in Nazi Germany every day I walked into the office.

title: Great industry, Great company
pros: A very forward thinking company that works hard to provide a great work atmosphere that treats employees fair. I was extremely impressed by a recent visit to our office by our CRO and VP of Operations. They spent individual time with every single employee and showed genuine interest in all employees. It was great to see the employees so motivated by this. They listened and took all feedback seriously. They further spent a great amount of time in a group meeting to explain the direction and vision of the company. They have a very clear vision for the company that will ensure long term success. This is a great industry with great upside and I feel very fortunate to be a part of this company. I would recommend Outfront Media to anyone looking for employment.
cons: Provide more training (internal/external).

title: Sales
pros: stock program is a bonus, 401k is good but below average. Expense account.
cons: The most complicated commission plan ever invented. It was told when I started they make it so confusing so you don't ask and therefore, never make commission. The upper management and CRO continue to change the plan so they get paid more and the sales people make less. If you're looking to make money in sales, this is not the company for you. Its full of terrible managers with no previous sales background outside of the company. The culture of the company is negative, micro-managing, and what can you do for me today mentality. Management doesn't appreciate the sales staff for how competitive the media market is and we're always 3-5 years behind technology as a "Media Company". They have about as many sales analysts in NY as they do sales in the US. Extremely top heavy company, and that's where all the money goes.

title: Account Executive
pros: You have a job. Some benefits… Some other miserable people to make friends with. Actually nice marketing team that supports sales staff.
cons: So much you can't list...look how recent and abundant the reviews are right now. Stay away at all costs...they used to get some you employees to be excited about being a part of VIACOM or CBS. Can't even get fool people into accepting a job anymore based on name recognition. Probably a few years away from being divided up and sold off. No positives since company broke off from CBS...everyone is weary about future and should be...even management that has been there since 2000s knows it's on it's way down.

title: Real Estate
pros: The people are amazing, lots of little perks here and there, upper management is easy to work with and I'm given enough autonomy to truly make a difference. My previous managers were nice but it takes that one right manager to make a difference. My new manager is easy to work with and truly listens to both my ideas and concerns. I get the right type of challenge I need to keep my interest. I'm made to feel like I'm part owner of this company so I have a lot of company pride. It's truly an enjoyable place to work.
cons: The holiday parties have been a little scaled back.

title: Working for the Enemy of USA
pros: Helping Local Business grow through Advertising Until they said in Spring 2019 well before the Plandemic - no more Local focus on National - Pure Evil Orders of the "Owners"
cons: This company cares about the top management and the big shareholders...all about greed. They make sure they all get their "unfair share" as the CEO Jeremy Male states on his calls with sales team. All goes to the top. Like the rest of media, they are corrupt and dishonest with an Agenda. The HR Dept covers by offering Non Disclosure Agreements to anyone who speaks up and complains.

title: Like fish. Begins to smell after three days.
pros: Management team follies provide endless entertainment for all.
cons: The phoenix must burn to emerge.

title: Bitter, not appreciated for many 65 hour plus work weeks. Learned Alot............
pros: Ability to work, at your own speed, Mgmt did not breath down your neck very often.
cons: Passed on promoting from within, Brought in new employees to fill senior positions, when positions were given to other new employee's, after positioned employees with 4 plus years was promised to proven ermployees with great track/sales record.

title: You can advance into senior management if you've been hit in the head pretty hard several times in your life.
pros: Decent experience if you can survive a "sink or swim" type of environment. Ok money to be made even if you're not appreciated for the effort. As long as you're generating results you can advance into sales management (if you can stand working for one of the company's senior managers)
cons: Ex-athlete senior management are less than intelligent, spiteful bullies. The East Coast Senior Vice President excels at management through harassment, interrogation and humiliation. Avoid working in one of his East Coast markets for sure. Totally unprofessional management approach.

title: Take Me to Your Leader
pros: Great people working at the company who truly care for one another and about the success of the organization.
cons: Senior Management is leading the company into the ground. Not trustworthy. Unethical. Several are unqualified to have their position and lean on people beneath them to do their work while taking undeserved credit. Lacks leadership skills. Spend more time playing corporate game than actually helping grow their people. All talk a big game how they care about people but they don't show it. When they try and show like they care it's contrived. All of us know it's all an act. Bottom line is because most of them are horrible people this company will continue to have high turnover which will lead to the ultimate demise of the company.

title: Awful?
pros: Aside from any management, great people.
cons: I don't know where to start. You would think that with a company like this, there would be some relationship between position and competence. Like a manager should know how to use a question mark in a sentence, or not make up words, or not say that their best skill is delegating. Unfortunately, that's not the case at all. I could really go on a rant here, but I’ll be brief. If you want to be in sales, there’s no training, so good luck. If you want a career path, it won’t happen unless you’re in sales and can network with the right guys. If you’re in anything other than a sales role, there’s no training and no opportunity for growth. I really like the people I worked with, but this company was a depressing dead end that was a total void in my career.

title: Good old boy network…
pros: Descent experience overall,ability to network with a variety of business owners, great personalities to work with, excellent graphic design artist,fortune 500 company
cons: Senior management receives largest accounts, major accounts are distributed amongst favorites, "sink or swim" type of environment, employees prefer a specific person to deal with overall in management hierarchy, uncomfortable office with awkward location.

title: House of Cards @ OUTFRONT
pros: The company has good outdoor advertising inventory throughout the US.
cons: The amount of ineffective managers OUTFRONT has is astounding and that all comes from the top. When you have an emotionally unintelligent leader in Clive running this sales organization it's no wonder that the corporation is rotten to the core. Clive and his cronies have spent boatloads of money on failed projects at a great disservice to OUTFRONTs shareholders. In the process, he has helped destroy the company culture and morale. A house of cards has been built under his leadership!

title: Super Toxic Stay Away!
pros: Decent 401k match, decent pto, some remote opportunities,
cons: I’ve literally never been treated so poorly in my life as I was by this company. I agree with the other reviews that the environment is extremely toxic- major backbiting among employees, bullying, no communication within the company whatsoever like no one even knows who does what, hr is both nonexistent and toxic- I worked here for over a year and only talked to hr once for hiring paperwork, there’s no one to go to with any issues and there are major issues. The pay is all over the place, a bro culture, they even randomly changed my job title multiple times to the point that I couldn’t even explain what was going on, while my manager kept saying I was an AE- overall my experience here was demoralizing and generally traumatic.

title: It is an ok job, but it may be boring and really difficult.
pros: You only work weekdays, great supervisor, you start at 6:00 am and you finish by 2:30 pm, you start with 12.00 and hour with a maximum of 23.00 dollars and hour every six month you get an extra dollar per hour until you reach max, you have vacations and holidays off.
cons: You get really tired, you have to carry too much paper in order to change as many posters in the train as you can, you can have back problems because of this job, sometimes it is boring, I think you don't get paid enough, you work with the MTA but not for the MTA

title: A Company That is Trying to Change
pros: - They foster (and spend a lot of money on) employee bonding activities - No micro-management - The company is trying to change and become a digital-focused company and there is the top-down message to make the change - In some departments, you really do have the ability to change things and make processes your own - You have the flexibility to grow your career in the direction you choose to
cons: - Lack of management and overall company direction - No process or change management - Sales makes promises that operations can't perform on - A heavily political environment with a lot of in-fighting amongst the executive level

title: Research, ask questions, assess your potential manager and think carefully before joining
pros: • Good medical and dental coverage • Compensation can be generous depending on role, manager, and department • Financially stable in the medium term. Long-term outlook difficult to predict due to the pandemic and changes to human OOH behavior
cons: • Business teams work in silos, and partnerships are not supported • Emphasis on DEI in company messaging but frequently not backed up in the company practices and not reflected in the senior leadership • Blame culture is present in many areas of the business

title: Anywhere else is better
pros: Some of the people you interact with daily are cool and make the job somewhat bearable
cons: - Management is trash. They make your job harder than it needs to be. - The company really doesn't care about you but pretends to - Senior management is full of entitled ass-kissers and yes-men

title: You'll either love it, or hate it.
pros: The connections, networking, etc. Account Executive positions are the reason to be here, they can pay six figures and put you in front of great clients. Clients would be Parmount, Dreamworks, Sony Pictures, etc.
cons: The management and the fact that its Advertising. People get shortened hours, hate when you work overtime and expect you to finish everything perfectly. You will get thrown under the bus everytime. You literally spend more time covering your footsteps than you do doing your job comfortably.

title: Unclear about who I report to because there seems to be several people doing the same job and no one talks to each other
pros: Haven't been there long so I really haven't seen many yet. Some of the people who work here are really nice and I like the stability of a big corporation
cons: Company appears confused and disorganized. No sure who to go to for each problem or issue. I am even unsure of who I report to and my boss is. Too many people in charge.

title: Great company to work for just prepare to work hard!
pros: They do the best they can with making everyone feel included. There are many different groups to join to meet fellow employees across all of the markets with similar interests and beliefs as well.
cons: They definitely could do better when it comes to compensation. They are good at piling on additional tasks that you might not have initially signed on for when accepting the job. Unless you ask or mention it during your review, you will not get compensated for the new work load that you will have accumulated and could possibly feel undervalued down the line. Unless your well liked by management, of course.

title: Wouldn't recommend unless you are really good at acting, manipulating & playing games
pros: I loved the autonomy of working for a big corporation, the 401K is the best in the business, they had great parties, for holidays and just randomly. The bonuses were good too.
cons: They very much played favorites, especially to typically favored races, discriminated against women, anyone who didn't suck up generously to the powers that be or anyone who didn't play their games. There were many, many people there that got paid hundreds of thousands of dollars that were horrible at their jobs, it was disheartening

title: OUTFRONT cares
pros: Culture is great and leadership is trying to make the company the best in the business. During a time of uncertainty with the pandemic, OUTFRONT stepped up and accommodated their clients and clients' businesses. I will never forget the significance of how much the company cares about people, whether they're employees or customers.
cons: The company has advanced from the good old boy way of doing things of the past, but new practices slow AEs down. Lots of CRM work, which is to be expected in sales, but we are inundated with corporate webinars, trainings, etc.

title: Good place to learn the business
pros: Leader in out of home advertising; great place to start career and learn about the business; good corporate structure and has offices in almost every city in the US
cons: Advancement is very difficult to come by; if you work in sales and are not an Account Executive it is very difficult to get promoted; only way to advance is laterally; training is very poor and disorganized

title: Wishy washy management
pros: Some of the staff are nice & willing to help with training. Lots of things to learn. You also get to know about events and sales before the public is aware.
cons: Management sells you a dream & are not detailed as to what they want from you. Computer systems are not integrated so you must constantly learn many databases. No clear cut as who to report to. Too much gossip.

title: Still a great job
pros: - Great health benefits - Fantastic teamwork environment for admin - I really feel like my work matters - Every year you are there you get vested
cons: - Prescription insurance company is a hassle - Once they get you in a position that benefits them there isn't really any room to grow - My job has changed considerably since I started, but my title hasn't.

title: Solid company
pros: Supportive positive sales management, varying degrees of innovation in media products, leading the industry in many areas. Even mediocre sales people make great livings
cons: While everyone seems to get along, there is a fair amount of whining and gossip around the work place. There is an undercurrent of insecurity about the future of the company.

title: Account Executive
pros: Some of my co-workers have become really close. It is nice to be in a unique industry where digital seems to run supreme in the marketing/advertising world. Very generous PTO.
cons: A lot of change and new procedures from upper management. The AE's have paperwork up to their ears and a lot of responsibility with unrealistic goals. Especially for a new AE. No teamwork. A manager isn't someone who hands AEs paperwork and says here evaluate yourself- get your hands dirty and sell yourself. AEs also are against other AEs with no territories and calling on other peoples accounts.. makes a fun office environment.

title: Old School Company; Get ready to Cold Call
pros: Ability to network with different business owners within the market you work; great co-workers; good benefits; team environment; managers have many contacts in the advertising industry.
cons: Low starting salaries; no possibility of moving into a management role unless you are in sales; a strong culture of nepotism; sales force is overworked; no training; "Behind the times" compared to other corporate advertising companies.

title: Photo Coordinator
pros: Overall a great company. Great benefits and management. I work with almost every sector of the company Operations, Sales, HR, Art Dept, and the guys that run everything. Great people that value great work.
cons: I wish I was compensated more. Other companies are paying people in similar roles like executive assists $10,000-$20,000 more.

title: Not really up to date in many ways, but then again, the technology of outdoor isn't exactly cutting edge is it?
pros: Established company with good name. Lots of experienced people to draw from. Good pay for the top tier/established folks. They clearly spell out all requirements for the job. Some of the young salespeople are totally rock stars and they are very impressive people to work with.
cons: You're on your own here if you're in sales -- no sales support people, no real help when it comes to CRMs or any other technological innovations (from 1999). The LA location was not the warmest bunch of salespeople on the planet. Every new person is treated as an interloper and potential competitor and is made to feel like they're an island unto themselves. Don't expect much in the way of training -- just go sell. You'll make some mistakes having to learn the products on your own, but most won't be fatal. Watch for massive overlap in cold calls (which you'll be doing a TON of) because the company refuses to use any kind of tracking/CRM system to let you know that the person you're calling as a new rep has been contacted 900 times before you have called -- or that they're already the client of an existing rep. You WILL upset people, and for some reason, management thinks that means you're doing your job, even if clients are perturbed by it. Plus, in a market as big as LA, good luck finding business that hasn't been mined six ways to Sunday already. The big dog salespeople take all the air out of the market well before you arrive.

title: Odd and unfriendly culture and sales leadership is lacking
pros: Benefits and 401k are solid. The sales product is good. And location of office convenient.
cons: You can't trust many people and the HR dept unprofessional, stirring up trouble. White male favoritism reigns and boys club.

title: Admin
pros: Dress code is very lax. Women wear workout attire, club attire, and weekend wear. No need to spend extra money on work attire. You can come and go as you please. Management does not verify hours worked.
cons: Unfortunately, not all employees are treated the same. Management has their special employees that are exempt from the rules and can do no harm. Very biased management, but you can wear whatever you want.

title: Good Company, Nice People, Horrible Job
pros: - Super nice coworkers and upper management - 2-3 Days in the office - Lunch often provided - Company happy hours often
cons: - Day to day task of a sales coordinator is horrible, demeaning work with little to no reward. Felt like I was doing an intern's job - They never provided me with a desk of my own (which everyone else had + name placards) so I was constantly moving around and wondering where to sit everyday - the office is old and needs updating, bathrooms were a little gross

title: CBS Outdoor treats their employees very well, and if you are in sales it's a good place to be.
pros: Great benefits, good work/life balance. Good managers and good company culture.
cons: Very focused on the sales staff, if you are not in sales it is easy to feel undervalued. If you are in Sales be prepared for a lot of pressure. There is definitely favoritism in what AEs handle what accounts. It can be very difficult to work your way to the top.

title: Mediocre
pros: Insurance is good, people are entertaining and genuinely good people, you can have a social life based on meeting people through your job here.
cons: Pay is disappointing/nonsensical pay structure. Communication to company changes is always scattered and delayed/through the grapevine.

title: Account
pros: Get a cupcake once a month with icing but can't get supplies because favorites only get them. Work is not hard. Some people are friendly others are rude,
cons: Favoritism is ridiculous! Managers retaliate against you if you are not part of the "I hail to you club ". Open door policy is supposed to be private but next day every one knows all your business and why you where in office. Spoke with HR and was surprised this person wasn't even interested in what I had say.

title: Great Company, Amazing Support of Employees
pros: excellent leadership, support of employees and families during COVID has been incredible. Use advertising assets to spread positive messages, support public service announcements, etc. Compensation plan rewards performance and gives large upside in salaries
cons: Comp plan is more complicated as it is based on collections versus billings. Managers don't want to leave (probably because jobs are so good) so limited opportunities to move into management although some recent internal promotions. Tech and IT are behind

title: Good company to develop in and would be a good idea for anyone early in their career.
pros: Excellent group to work with and provides you a very good sense of other business environments. Your ability to understand the market place provides you a solid foundation for success. If you are not curious of business in general, you may have a hard time speaking to potential clients.
cons: Possible to outgrow position fairly quickly and rare horizontal movement between CBS corporation

title: FAVORTISM Between Managers and Staff
pros: 401K and Health Insurance Benefits
cons: Too much favortism in the departments, favorites are switched around, titles are changed to fall under different income gaps, while other co workers earn less. They assume you that you are are not knowledge able enough, and do not wish to spend anytime training. they speak to you in a very condescending matter and when you speak up you are on their list. Management in H/R , Payroll, and Billing and Supervisors are in cahoots. There is no confidentiality.

title: Great Environment, some processes outdated but they are moving with the times
pros: Best General manger ever. Listened and implemented and rewarded us for good work, listened to all of our concerns and suggestions
cons: anything that had to do outside my office. Billing dept is absurdly dumb and lazy. Just plain and simple. Even had to call and train them on basic math and proration.

title: The best Job I've held to this point.
pros: Exceptional leadership provided by management. Laid back environment at the office, and every employee knows one another like a family member. That experience was so amazing because of the people who run and work in that office.
cons: Limited inventory of billboard locations.

title: Nice place if you have the experience they are looking for
pros: The people were great. Everyone there was nice, encouraging, and wanted to see you succeed.
cons: The managers could be more insightful when teaching new hires how to use their systems. I was by far the newest and least experienced in my market with everyone else having 10+ years of experience in this industry and I received extremely basic lessons about their systems and databases which I had to figure out on my own time.

title: Great team, fun environment
pros: Experienced sales team is great to learn from and confident enough to have a good sense of humor in the process. Help is always available and asking for it is never scrutinized. Do the job right or not at all.
cons: Highly corporate, no overtime, strict dress code even for assistants. Be prepared for logistical changes on the fly as departments clash over details.

title: Sales
pros: The benefits are good. The co-workers are a great group and can be a fun environment.
cons: The management is terrible in the Houston office. They play favoritism to the younger/single girls. They set rules for some and don't make others follow. If you get on the bad side of the Manager. He will make it a horrible work environment.

title: Good Place to Work and Learn
pros: Flexible hours, there are many things and people to learn and know. Every day is different, so you don't get bored. It's a great learning experience if you want to start a service business after ward.
cons: Salary was not bad but could be better. That is a key position and was not paid as it should.

title: Account exec
pros: Sector has big opportunity. Company well placed to out once competitors. People treated well. Exciting vision for future. A growth company with growth focused leadership. open and honest culture.
cons: Not technology focused. Need much grater focus on training. Progression for junior staff. Some people resistant to change. Variability from HQ and markets.

title: UNAPPRECIATIVE MANAGEMENT/CONDESCENDING ATTITUDE
pros: Benefits are ok. Managers throughout the US are great to work with because they are eager to learn in order to increase revenue.
cons: There is a danger is driving too much change too fast and I'm sure they are starting to see the consequences since a handful of their top Account Executives have resigned. Especially if you are trying to run an OOH company like a hedge fund. The root of the problem is having someone at the core making decisions without knowing what they are doing. Upper management seems to hide behind this individual because they don't have a clue as well.

title: Account Executive
pros: Large company with plenty of room for growth. Great assets along with a lot of diversity across outdoor advertising formats.
cons: Very political. If you are not on the right side of things you can easily see people not as deserving advance quicker. Also not an unlimited product, must compete to sell inventory not only against competitors but other sales people within company with large, national accounts.

title: It's a good company could be great if they rid of certain inexperienced managers.
pros: Great benefits, nice location to malls, restaurants & major highways. 2 weeks vacation pay, no overtime work week requires 37.5 hours. Flexible hours based on if your one of the mangers favorite person or loves to gossip with the mangers..
cons: Minority's are treated unfairly, you speak up and speak your mind you will be terminated. Company does not follow it's no discrimination or retaliation policy...managers are always right regardless of how many complaints are made against them. It's based of how long you worked there and how well you know the upper management....

title: No promotional opportunities. Over worked & under paid!
pros: Nice vacation, personal days, sick time and holiday package.
cons: Not any opportunity to advance. You're expected to go above and beyond for a company who at the end of the day treats you like you are replaceable.

title: Definitely Improving
pros: OUT is company that truly cares about improving its standing within the world of media sales. It is a competitive industry, but the management within OUT prepares its employees for any objections.
cons: While the company is improving every day it still has a ways to go when it comes to technology. The company is aware of this, though, and is working to improve procedures and practices.

title: Sales
pros: Great work colleagues . Good benefits.
cons: No base salary . All advance and strictly commission . Very very low pay out .Huge sales budgets and money goes to all top level management. Those making sales don't get paid accordingly. Crazy amount of turnover in all positionS. Expectation to work 24/7. Very long work days

title: Absolutely dreadful
pros: A paycheck and that’s about it
cons: So so many ... to start off with if you’re not part of the management “click” you are a total outsider. Managers don’t care about their sales people, they only care about keeping their own jobs. Systems are so so antiquated. Inventory is amazing, but the company is so cheap they won’t update anything internally. Finally if you are a female, good luck - this company is all about the old school boys club .

title: Account Executive
pros: If you work hard and put the time in, you will have the opportunity to make great money. Must be self motivated, organized, and driven.
cons: Account reassignment is not fair, the favorites game is played. Culture of the office is boys club like - you must not be intimidated to be outgoing and stake your claim.

title: The pay and potential were good, but i did not care for the company culture in the Berkeley office.
pros: If you want to keep your nose down, do your job, and leave at 4:45/5pm - this could be a decent place for you.
cons: If you like to drink large amounts of alcohol and brag about it on Monday morning, this is an ideal culture for you.

title: Good place to work if you are a beginner or an ex-football player
pros: It's the largest media company in the world, which will look good on your resume. It's a good place to start out if you are right out of school to gain some experience or if you are an ex-football player needing a job.
cons: The cons outweigh the pros by a long shot! It's not a good place to transfer too if you have any real world experience. I felt like I had to dumb myself down to work here. They didn't seem to value my experience at all. I think they hired me simply so they didn't have to train me. They didn't seem to care that they weren't doing things to the same level as the other companies in their industry. I worked a minimum of 10 hours a day in order to get everything done that needed to be done, but was never recognized for it. They seem to hire a lot of family members, friends, men and ex-ball players and favor them over the other employees. There were employees who dressed and spoke inappropriately, but no action was ever taken when they were complained about. The CEO Wally is a major hot head. On more than one occasion he was yelling so loud on the phone and to other employees that the whole office could hear him and made us all very uncomfortable. Very unprofessional.

title: Go to work for another media company, really there are better opportunities available!
pros: Don't see upper management at all.
cons: Commission plan is terrible! micro-managed, budgets are ridiculous considering what you have to work with inventory wise, national runs the company, no opportunities - income is really bad.

title: I have learned so much through my support position having responsibility added regularly.
pros: Coworkers. Fun management and work environment. Good benefits with 401k and stock options. Teamwork mentality across positions. Rewarded for positive performance.
cons: Inconsistency with management. No formal training. Old-school company with old-school company policies such as the inability to work from home if your position is classified a certain way based on an old scale of measurement.

title: Working At Outfront
pros: Good work life balance. Solid benefits and company culture. 401K match. Organization is primed for success for future with long term contracts. Pretty structured environment and great people work here. Management is pretty laid back and down to earth and genuinely seems to care about people. Free breakfast on Monday mornings!
cons: None that I can think of. Great place to work

title: Account Executive
pros: The pay is good and the hours are flexible. Management is also very helpful. The benefits were better than most places and the 401k program is great as well.
cons: It was difficult to find and develop new business being in a small market. This job would be easier and better paying in a bigger city.

title: Typical Corp Mentality
pros: The basics. Descent benefits and descent balance between home and work.
cons: The sales team gets all the perks. The support staff is the least valued in every aspect, but especially financially (no bonus options.)

title: Manager
pros: One of the largest Out-of-Home operators in the county. Have excellent advertising location assets in many large markets.
cons: Digital, Mobile, and Social media adverting is growing and eating up more and more of the marketing pie the out-of-home industry is competing for. OUTFRONT is trying to get into this space but maybe too late to make a difference.

title: Great place to work!
pros: Regular M-F hours, able to work from home when needed, generous vacation, personal, and sick time, managers are easily accessible, little to no micromanaging, comfortable work environment, company paid lunch once a week, fun team-building activities throughout the year, dogs allowed in office, proactive, helpful , and respectful team to work with
cons: I haven't experienced any yet.

title: Perfect place for someone inexperienced with a humane corporate culture.
pros: The medical plan should cover a portion of the therapy sessions necessary to remind yourself that you are worthy human being.
cons: People are managed by intimidation and if you are thrilled by the thought then this is the place for you. Extremely click-"ish." And diversity is minimal.

pros: Great benefits and coworkers. They love to have meeting about meeting. Selling time is restricted.
cons: Management wants to constantly change things. Including rates and client policies. This does not set well with business owners.

title: Accounting TOO MUCH FAVORITISM
pros: Flexible Hours Excellent benefits
cons: Management tends to treat "some subordinates" in a minute manner. They have already made a judgement about your knowledge and will not allow you to advance. They will pick on you when you make a mistake with your grammar writing emails or verbally. They are loud and will ridicule you in front of the staff as if you are a young child. No class or work ethics. Managers gossip w their subordinates. Ridiculous.

title: Sr. Account Executive
pros: Great media outdoor billboards and new digital units.
cons: Competition from not only other media, radio, tv , internet.

title: Internship
pros: Paid internship, friendly environment, had lots of training to prepare you for work in the summer
cons: none that come to mind. The company offered training in the internship as well as some flexibility with projects

title: I like working for CBS Outdoor, I have learned a lot about outside sales.
pros: You create your own schedule, you have flexibility on who to call on and you create your success!
cons: The company is changing and there is a lot of uncertainty of what will happen to the industry in the Northern California area.

title: Could have been a good place to work with better training and stable management.
pros: The pay was good and some of the people were nice.
cons: The benefits package was not great at all. Also the group of employees working for CBS Outdoor are old and out of touch from the current advertisement environment. Also, people were over work, which created a surviving mentality rather than a team work mentality. The work environment in the Fairfield office was depressing.

title: Just OK
pros: Good, comprehensive benefits. Unique line of work.
cons: Limited growth if not interested in being a salesperson. Any development opportunities are geared towards/offered to Sales. Siloed departments. Sales is the focus, much to the detriment of other departments within the company. Very reliant upon human effort and slow to improve existing, dated technologies.

title: Potential
pros: Decent benefit package. Diverse and interesting coworkers. Advertising is always interesting.
cons: Needs improvement on the organization/leadership side of things. Great experience during the hiring process, but fell flat after that with minimal communication from HR and leadership. Org chart could use some love and attention.

title: Account Executive
pros: Fun culture. Rewarding career. Diverse range of clients. Get to know the city really well!
cons: Not an independent sales position. Must check in at office everyday. However, it is a very fun office and great atmosphere.

title: Account Executive
pros: Fun product to sell, get to meet lots of agencies and businesses. Co-workers are usually cool.
cons: Management summed up : Old School, chauvinistic, and helpless. If you're looking for management that invests time, education and help, look someplace else. You're by yourself here.

title: Manage change & provide growth
pros: Great coworkers and best media to sell in the OOH sphere
cons: Systems are a bit out of date, and things are constantly changing without much communication to employees. Little room for growth.

title: Low pay, good stepping stone
pros: Free parking lot, very casual office that enjoys having fun while working hard. More diverse for a small office.
cons: Low pay. Unnecessary trainings. Computers out of date. Favoritism is clear. Not transparent- bumped certain workers to hourly who were told salary initially.

title: Should have left much sooner...
pros: Pay is good- since they have nothing else to offer they throw money at you.
cons: no reviews hence no opportunity for setting career path and advancement. Long hours and too much work unevenly distributed.

title: Account executive
pros: Great pay and a great atmosphere when it was CBS but after the seperation it was a stressful place to work with really bad direction
cons: The worst management I've ever worked for, unfair practices and upper management has favorites, racism at the top is very bad and I've seen management deal with people of color really unfairly

title: Great Short Term
pros: Competitive base salary and good benefits. Sales people have a lot of flexibility and freedom as long as you perform.
cons: You must be driven and aggressive. It's kind of like a never ending sprint, it gets old.

title: Sales
pros: Good personal/work life balance. Very friendly employees.
cons: The pay is not good unless you have an agency for National Accounts. Nepotism happens often.

title: Charting - Phoenix
pros: It was an upbeat and challenging environment and I reported directly to a well respected GM who has more charisma than anyone I have ever met in my 25 year career.
cons: I wish that they had pushed me harder to succeed.

title: Good Company, Individual Office have very different cultures
pros: Robust benefits, overtime available, Employee Resource Groups, in general the corporate culture is progressive.
cons: Individual offices have very different cultures based on who works there. This office is very clickish and unwelcoming to people not from the Philadelphia metro area.

title: average
pros: The location is pretty good. It's a huge company so you could transfer to other offices.
cons: Management is constantly watching you, you have assigned lunches, and have to sign in and out of the office every day.

title: Good Company with mixed messages

title: It has been a very uncomfortable experience. I have seen how favoritism amonst the managers and the sub ordinates.

cons: favortism w/ the managers, discrimination

title: No guidance

title: Great place to get solid Sales & Marketing experience!

cons: For support staff, the pay isn't very great.

title: Good Company
pros: Great Culture, Great Leadership, Takes initiative to stay current with new trends in technology, business practices, and training.Creative has excellent representation.

title: Stepping stone

title: Best Job I’ve ever had

cons: Furloughed people due to Covid-19, but the industry is making a strong comeback.

title: Software Engineer Outfront Media

title: Good experience. Though to get raises and promotions.

title: Run. Run, Fast!!!

title: Nice people, But too old school
pros: Fast-paced, given a lot of responsibilities (which is fulfilling). But there are also many helpful people willing to lend a hand. Everyone is super nice (attracts some wonderful, smart, hard-working people), the environment is encouraging and welcoming. It's a great place to learn and grow without fear of judgment. The company is big with a lot of different departments to branch out to and learn the business.
cons: Very old school. We have many different antiquated systems that aren't streamlined for efficiency. A lot of time gets eaten away performing routine tasks that aren't conducive to the pace of the industry. While people are nice, they are very old school - a lot of the older staff isn't willing to learn and they'll lean on the younger staff for many things. It's very hard to get your performance recognized. You'll have to go above and beyond to advocate for yourself, constantly knocking on managers doors (literally) for promotions, raises, different assignments. Good honest work just won't speak for itself. In fact a lot of good employees get over-looked for positions that they might have been better suited for than the actual hire. It's kind of about who you know, very old school.

title: Toxic Culture That Destroys Morale and Wellbeing
pros: One manager at the site level genuinely cared and tried to support their team. Talented coworkers who do their best despite the environment. Strong name recognition.
cons: This is not just a “high-pressure sales job.” It’s a culture built on fear, intimidation, and exhaustion. The division prioritizes metrics over people, and it shows in every aspect of the employee experience. Fear Over Feedback: Speaking up is dangerous. Employees who voice concerns are quickly labeled as negative or a “problem.” HR is not a safe option, and feedback sessions are tightly controlled to avoid real criticism. Unrealistic Metrics: Success is measured by spreadsheets, not actual effort or customer experience. Performance standards are punishing and often based on factors outside employees’ control. Call Distribution Games: Leads are not distributed evenly. Some get better calls while others are left with recycled, low-quality prospects—yet everyone is held to the same national targets. The system is fundamentally unfair. Health Toll: The stress here is extreme. Employees report anxiety, burnout, sleeplessness, and the feeling that work consumes their lives. The lack of acknowledgment from leadership only deepens the damage. Revolving Door: Turnover is constant. People leave burned out and disillusioned. Many return briefly out of necessity, only to leave again once they find something healthier.

title: A Soul-Crushing Machine Disguised as a Job
pros: • You might make money if you get golden leads (don’t count on it). • Base pay during non-tenured months gives you temporary breathing room.
cons: Training is a joke: six weeks of slide decks and half-baked “shadowing” where you often can’t even hear the borrower. You’re thrown in blind and blamed when you sink. • Non-tenure lasts ~3 months. Sounds safe—until your last non-tenured month rolls over and drags down your first three months of tenure. You’re haunted by numbers you had no chance to escape. • Calls are a trap: you can lock as many as you want, but if they don’t fund, you’re accused of “costing the company” thousands. Instead of coaching, you get public shaming. • Leadership is chaos. Some managers hide, others panic, all live in fear. Genuine support is extinct. The culture is built on intimidation, finger-pointing, and fear. • Toxicity is woven into every metric. You can fund loans and still be told you’re failing. The system is designed to chew you up and spit you out. • Upcoming comp plan change—expect to work harder each year for less.

title: Wizard of OZ
pros: Stress, wrinkles and annoying managers
cons: Working at PennyMac was a highly discouraging experience. The culture is heavily micromanaged, leaving little room for trust or autonomy. Compensation is below industry standards, and the workload is consistently overwhelming due to chronic understaffing. Employees are expected to take on far more than is reasonable, which quickly leads to burnout and frustration. Opportunities for career growth are minimal, and employee well-being doesn’t seem to be a priority. Overall, PennyMac places too much emphasis on control and output, while failing to invest in its people. I would not recommend this company to anyone seeking fair pay, balance, or a supportive environment.

cons: Hyper political environment, some of the worst aspects of the old Countrywide culture. If you aren't personally aligned with the right senior execs, you can get laid off in an instant. Very little loyalty, litany of carnage of VPs to EVPs who were screwed over but then given a pay off to sign non-disparagement agreements. If you get an offer from them, ask for a guaranteed severance package. If they won't provide it, don't accept the offer.

title: Great managers and interesting work
pros: I really like my job at PennyMac. The work is challenging and the development culture is really great. I feel fully supported by my leaders and enjoy the people. Culture is good.
cons: This company is obsessed with RTO. You have to fill out an online form to be able to WFH and they set the goal of in office of 85% of the time, meaning you can only WFH once every 2 weeks.

title: It's a job that doesn't value you.
pros: Health insurance premiums, while high, did not raise in cost year to year. They gave an additional 5 days of PTO this year. The office environment is pretty casual and friendly. Management tries to keep it fun with provided lunches & optional after work events. If you do your job, no one bothers you about being on your phone during calls.
cons: There are no annual raises. It doesn't matter how well you perform yearly, your pay will never increase which means you are losing money the longer you work. They do not promote from within, I have been fully qualified yet rejected while the jobs are offered to external candidates. Pennymac decided to spend hundreds of millions of dollars sponsoring the Olympics one day after the CEO sold nearly 7,000 stock shares and a lot of their execs seem to have sold a lot of their stock in the months post election. The sick time is given as a bundle of 40 hours that replenishes annually on your anniversary, and you earn a little over 3 hours PTO every two weeks. The management is very anti-WFH and will rarely give you that option even on a holiday.

cons: I think the company values speed and agility to the detriment of accuracy, execution, and efficiency. The company could really benefit from a robust, and ongoing, operations training program, especially in the Retail and TPO channels. The company needs a consistent hybrid WFH policy, needs to abandon a full RTO policy, and needs to re-implement hybrid for higher management levels. These positions are hard to hire for, and we've already lost several highly valued and high performing individuals at higher management levels due to a no remote/ hybrid policy at those levels.

title: Never work at a company you wouldn't do business with
pros: Lunch purchased for office at least once a week. Nice office space. Good location where office is located.
cons: Other Loan Officers steal loans from one another. Four months after starting they lowered everyone's pay company wide. Terrible processing department, People with VP titles who do not have work experience or life experience and it shows. Training is terrible. My class had a guy who has never trained a day in his life and only in the mortgage business for a year. Had 60 loans in pipeline and only ten closed, caught underwriting and processing turning down loans incorrectly, Purposely delaying loan closings by a few days to prevent people from making high bonus, several questionable practices and in the State of TN commission is supposed to be paid within 30 days, you're lucky if you see that money in three months. Way too many emails, financial software that is so outdated and not conducive to doing the job.

title: Love Pennymac!
pros: There's lots of room for growth and career development. Love my team and the people I work with!
cons: No cons at this time.

title: There are a lot of pros and cons
pros: Less red tape than most companies in regards to cross team problem solving and collaboration. Friendly and supportive management that let you play into your strengths and develop new skills.
cons: Very pushy on the in office collaboration and resistance of remote and hybrid options. Culture is very college fraternity/sorority feeling. Very slow at pay raises. There are no yearly cost of living or merit raises only "market adjustments" every 2-3 years. Bonuses are capped at a certain percentage. So even if you do go "above and beyond" you get the same bonus as your slacker teammate. The mortgage industry is very feast or famine. I survived 2 layoffs at the beginning and then working a skeleton crews until rates got better. In busy season management tends to give all resources and energy to new hires and leaves more senior people to figure things out on there own.

title: Upper Management is too much
pros: The people here are great and mostly all of us get along.
cons: Upper management has turned into control freaks. Employees are judged and viewed based on numbers on a screen but not the quality of their work. Most departments have to report to the office every day. Some still have hybrid, but if you utilize their hybrid schedule you will get scolded and will have it used against you if you want a promotion or raise (not that they’d give you one anyways). The company has a whole has a “control” problem where they have this old school mentality of wanting to control people. They will find every excuse in the book to delay and put off raises/promotions, but will swing and change an entire organization over night. They will constantly tell you why they “can’t” do things that would benefit the employee, but will change the entire dynamic of the department on a moments notice when it does t benefit the employees.

title: Dj Ford at the Tampa office will yell at you
pros: Money is great when the market is good
cons: Dj ford has temper tantrums. When the market gets slow he calls meetings saying the following . “You think the grass is greener on the outside. That’s why most of you came back to penny mac because it’s a great company” Remember what you were making before penny mac Everyone in the room needs to be grateful to have jobs You truly do get yelled at if your not making enough money for managment

title: Low Compensation
pros: Family oriented. Great benefits for mothers and new fathers. Very team based.
cons: CEO/Executives - do not want to pay their employees appropriately. You will be overworked. You will be paid under the average salaries of your peers with other companies. They do jot plan on giving raises when annual reviews are completed. They do not share the profit sharing’s, end of year bonus is not a thing here. The use their Penny Pantry as a way of an incentive for having to be fully on site. The CEO hates Work from home models and currently in the process of eliminating this. The CEO and executives prefer to eliminate departments instead of giving justified pay raises for the work load presented. Growth is not a priority with PENNYMAC.

title: Great Enviornment to Build Career and Network

title: Terrible
pros: Cross training opportunities, straight forward job
cons: Pay, growth opportunities, work life balance

title: Legal Theft
pros: Income was decent during low rate environment. End of Pros.
cons: Company looks for every avenue in which to exploit a LOs job security as well as commission payouts. Micromanaged every minute of every hour of every day, with the threat of being terminated held over your head daily. Absurd metrics that must be met on a daily basis. Calls are recorded and monitored by a 3rd party company, by people who's only job is to make sure you read every single word on every single page of the company's 10 page sales script. You miss one word and you are hit with a critical fail, which not only places you in the termination pile-but the company then keeps your commission on that loan when it funds. Technology that is spotty at best, taking up to 30 minutes simply to get logged into the system. If you're more than 5 minutes late logging in to your shift, you are written up -all because Pennymacs servers are bogged down and won't let you in. Multiple months in which I would miss hitting 125% payouts on commission by 1 funding unit-only to see that unit literally fund the very next day on the 1st of the next month. This alone costs me tens of thousands of dollars every quarter in commissions. Shady practices and nonpayment of entitled commissions to loan officers should be scrutinized and red flagged by government entities, because clearly this is not legal and unethical. Hmmm....this just gave me an idea.

cons: Poor management and retaliation when folks speak up about said poor management, by targeting performance instead of implementing positive management changes. Lack of training when asked by employees Excuses of being “too busy” to be efficient at management tasks or reviews Never expect a pay raise here it’s not in their company policy to offer annual increases on base pay and are very low on base pay offerrings Always expect to lose your bonus as they will find every reason, that is not a sale-able issue, to refrain from paying you for your hard work.

title: Lies and deception
pros: Free coffee and safety pin day in Agoura Hills once a year, hooray, we now have culture.
cons: Top leadership of the company, especially in Agoura Hills are liars, incompetent bullies, and will stab you in the back without you knowing about it. Some of the most poisonous culture I’ve ever worked with in my entire life. I’m so happy I left. Honestly, don’t trust anything they say. The grass is definitely greener on the other side, so run.

title: Unfair treatment
pros: Not many pros I can think of.
cons: I work on an underwriting team of 15. I took a promotion and only got a pay increase of $1000 from my non underwriting role. Also the 13 other underwriters get to be fully remote and due to a hot head VP, two of us have to work In the office. We have brought up to him multiple times how it isn’t fair to make the 2 of us office employees when the other 13 are fully remote and his response is he doesn’t care, it is what it is so get over it. Our direct supervisor is remote and we don’t even have anyone to report to so we are essentially alone at the office.

There are several individuals that have literally yelled and demeaned another individual in the middle of the IT floor and still have a job. They are protected. I worked under a great team, who genuinely cared for me.
cons: Tons of layoffs starting happening and they decided to switch me to another team. The team I was placed on had a horrible manager who acted like she cared for my well being but essentially bullied me out of a job. She would constantly contradict herself and had no idea how to manage someone. The culture is not good. They do not care about their people and retention. They were a revolving door.

title: Horrible Company/Management
pros: Please run, don't walk. Stay away from this place.
cons: This is easily one of the worst companies I have ever had the displeasure of working for. 0 Raises. They'll make up some BS like "Oh our budget only allows for this and this, but not this. If you want a raise, you'll have to go above and beyond and do things outside of your pay grade to receive it". I had this job because I need money, not because I need to break my back (metaphorically) being overworked. Management has absolutely 0 concept of actual managing. They not only lack people skills, but they lack the ability to do what their title entails, manage. I understand micromanaging comes with the territory, but that's not the issue. Nobody is ever on the same page. Constant disagreements on how to do something. Only for them to come back and change their answer again, and again, and again. Additionally, they have a toxic mindset and constantly threaten our job. They tell us to "change our mindset" when we are telling them we're overworked. Heaven forbid you have a complaint. "Deal with it" is the typical response. They have the whole, "it's my way or the highway' approach. Look at the decline in reviews. There's a reason. Please stay far, far away.

title: Good place to start, not much room to grow

cons: Not much room to grow and the pay is not the best in comparison to the market rate. Even after a promotion they lag behind competitors. Management is also very old school. In a society where most things can be done electronically, the company is lead by old school copywriters and file cabinets where they refuse to adapt to the resources most tech companies use today. Turnover has also been high this past year, as it seems with every interest rate hike was followed by a round of layoffs. Most of the problems that the teams face have already been discovered but management refuses to invest into addressing them.

title: Great Experience with Consummate Professionals
pros: Working at PennyMac has been one of the most rewarding professional experiences I’ve ever had. The environment is marked by a high level of professionalism and courtesy. The team, from upper management to entry-level employees, is composed of genuine and kind individuals. The company is situated in a prime area with a reasonable commute, enhancing the overall work-life balance. During the COVID lockdowns, PennyMac demonstrated its commitment to employee well-being by providing care packages and thoughtful gifts, which were a nice touch. Management is highly accessible and possesses a diverse range of expertise, always ready to offer guidance. I appreciate the company’s metrics-driven approach, which fosters transparency and clear expectations. I am enthusiastic about the prospect of returning to PennyMac after completing my degree and look forward to advancing my career here with higher compensation.
cons: ummate Professionals

title: Training is horrible, access to data takes forever
pros: I liked the culture, most people were friendly
cons: I worked there for only a month, and wasn't able to even start doing my job for 2 weeks due to bad training and no access to the data that I required. The team I worked with was on a hybrid schedule, so they worked M-F in office, then Th- Fri were from home. I was only trained a couple of hours a day for the first 3 days I was there, then left to figure it out. This means figuring out a new system, new processes, etc. The Processes and Procedures was horribly written and left out a lot of important material, especially if you got an Error message which happened a lot with the horrible system they use, so on Thursdays and Fridays I tried using them when I was finally given work to do, but made mistakes due to the P/P's missing a whole lot of information. Then if I wanted to ask a question I got dirty looks and slow answers to my questions. When I was let go I still didn't have access to all of the databases that I needed, (it took them 2 weeks just to get me a phone) so I don't feel like they even gave me a chance to prove myself, and the team lead seemed like she didn't want to help or answer any questions. But then when I made a mistake she was all over me for it, and not in a positive way. I appreciate feedback when it is constructive, but they way she did it was demeaning and demoralizing. I was moving work along by the 3rd week and completing the tasks they gave me, and doing my best to figure it out on my own, but that wasn't enough I guess. Some of they other teams seemed to work together, this team didn't want to help or work as a team. If I asked the manager for help, which wasn't often because she was so busy, I would get a patronizing look and answer, like " you should know this". Well, if I would have had real training and P&P's that were written well, I wouldn't have to be asking you questions. would I?

title: Profit over people
pros: Paycheck Job security Co-workers Paid Time Off (when you're not forced to use it for regional emergencies)
cons: With a hurricane approaching, I was shocked that my employer expected, if not demanded, that I come into the office or use Paid Time Off. The local government issued mandatory emergency evacuations and told people to stay home. The US government suspended mail service. Bridges in the Tampa Bay area were closed to traffic, as well as city streets. Yet Pennymac told us to ignore these orders and come into the office. We are constantly told how important employees are, but we only seem to matter when we're closing loans, not when you and your family's safety is on the line. People forced to come into the officer found elevators out of service for "safety" reasons. We've been told repeatedly to go online and vote for Pennymac as a "best place to work" but a best place to work doesn't prioritize loan processing over human lives during a hurricane.

title: A Company Trying to be New School with Old School Toxicity
pros: There's hybrid flexibility for most roles. I would say the pay is decent. Work-life balance is ok to a point. There is some attempt at employee engagement but I did not see a lot in my time there.
cons: There was a major focus on production for my role, which was not clearly defined as a production role when I agreed to the position. Loans reviewed per hour are heavily scrutinized by management in order to maximize employee productivity. Failing to hit a certain number per hour meant that an employee would be reprimanded for productivity. The department's ultimate goal is to have a team of 2 to 3 employees do as much as possible within a workday, rather than employing the appropriate number of employees to handle the workload. The end result is employees become micromanaged to ensure that a rigid production schedule is met that isn't necessary and can be obtained by other means. When the workload is very heavy, other departments are often recruited to help disposition files. As one may have guessed, the end result is that many arbitrary errors are found when the files are reviewed. There is no consistency about what the job is meant to be or how day-to-day processes should be conducted between frontline employees, middle management, and top management. Front-line specialists may have. completely different understanding of how certain scenarios should be handled than management. Because of this, new employees may become frustrated or confused because of the different answers that may receive when asking questions. Management lacks actual managerial skills and many are in leadership roles due to being high producers in their past positions. This is a common trope within the mortgage industry, and it would even seem like an appropriate idea if managers were expected to produce just as their subordinates are. However, this is not the case. Managers in this department are strictly salaried supervisors and their expectations are to lead, coach, and give feedback. Since they were promoted for past production and not their potential to motivate and influence employees, they lack the necessary skills to accomplish their intended goal. The end result is that there is a hyper-fixation on production with little to no feedback detailing how to improve or a realistic view that some days production can vary. Essentially middle management views their position as literal micromanagement, leading to a toxic work culture. From personal experience, not only was my hourly production monitored closely, but my emails were monitored by management to ensure screenshots looked appropriate. There are also times when I was reprimanded for not answering an email quickly enough, even when the email had been received within 30 minutes and not marked as urgent. Not only is severe micromanagement an issue, but some managers have no way to conduct themselves in the office. My manager made a habit of frequent inappropriate remarks/stories. These ranged from stories of drug use to a remark made regarding a physical I had requested PTO for.

title: Remove Unnecessary Parts and Pay Better
pros: Great mid-level management that truly cares about you. They are pretty flexible with you within reason when you have urgent matters come up when life happens. They cater in lunch from time to time and do employee appreciation events. Cafeteria with awesome food options at an affordable cost to employees.
cons: Very segmented workflows and processes comparatively to other companies which results in terrible pay. This also slows down your production drastically which makes it difficult to hit quotas that are necessary to bonus. The pay is way below industry standards and upper management is the problem, like above the VP, etc. They hire people with decades of experience at very entry level cost. New loan operating system for some of the departments has a lot of kinks, but they are actively working on this. Training and development of new hires needs some work, but they are also actively working on it. The bonus structure is abysmal too, way over complicated and is paid quarterly. They cannot keep educated overqualified candidates because they are underpaying so much, so it’s a revolving door when those employees find better paying jobs.

title: I Was Warned…
pros: - I had THEE absolute BEST manager on the PLANET (RW) and I honestly couldn’t have handpicked a better group of coworkers. - Decent benefits - Decent pay - Received a promotion while working from home
cons: *sigh* - As trainers, we were on a rolling 6 week class schedule with literally ZERO time off. When I first began, I went five months without so much as a half day to go to a doctor’s appointment. Every trainer was on this schedule, so there was no opportunity for backup or standby in case the primary trainer had any kind of emergency. I worked sick, with a broke down car in my garage that I couldn’t take to the shop…yeah. - No continuity with the line of business. Our procedures and manuals were embarrassingly outdated and I always felt horrible knowing that the information we were giving participants would be COMPLETELY different once they actually started doing the work. - We were forced to turn in report cards weekly to track individual improvement…not the easiest feat when there are 20 people in your class - and again, you don’t have any type of help. - I went on leave and had to email HR and ask them when I was returning. They took three days to answer me. I returned on the day they gave me, reached out to them and again…three days of nothing. Once they finally acknowledged me, I received a check with two instead of five days of pay because THEY chose to disregard the fact that I was there. - Everything had changed when I returned. We’d returned to the office and gone to a “modular” training style, where we could share one another’s load and not train every single day. Seemed cool, but I wondered why we had to come into the office if we 1) were still training virtually, and 2) not working on a particular day. No joke…out of a 6 week class, I was only scheduled to train 4 days - but was still expected to come in the office every day (in terrible traffic)? Made NO sense. I would go to work, literally sit and do nothing, and go home. I’d ask for extra work/projects to no avail. - What kind of company pushes their employees to go back into the office when gas prices were literally the highest in HISTORY?! A California based company at that, where gas prices are the highest! Completely insensitive and callous call. Also, I was told that going back into the office helped with revenue for the county/city…but I live in the same county/city as the building, so they could have kept that lie for somebody else. - Of the three departments in our division, one was totally remote and the other was Hybrid. It was hard not to take having to come in daily (again, most days for nothing) personally. We kept hearing “PennyMac is a WFO company”, but kept pulling up to a half empty building every day. Whatever the COMPANY is doing, that’s what the COMPANY as a WHOLE needs to do. - Three hours of vacation a paycheck is an absolute joke. You have to work a year just to get a week’s vacation. It’s insane!!!! And I’ve heard “HR is working on it” since I got there in 2019.
