It often feels like the company would love us to be robots, only capable of reciting the very limited scripts they give us. But obviously thats not enforced because otherwise no one would want to do business with us.

title: No Job Security
pros: Not micromanaged. Most coworkers are nice and friendly.
cons: No job security. They will low ball you concerning salary. Do your research before you agree to a rate. Management is not consistent on procedural changes. Feedback is not discussed. Once bonus time rolls around they tell you you had feedback but never let you know what is was. You cannot “fight” it, even if you are in the right.

title: Overworked, underpaid, the dangling carrot is being dragged from behind Stan's Benz.
pros: Subsidized cafeteria food costs slightly more than Taco Bell and tastes the same! Oh yeah and you can see about 1,000 crows on a daily basis.
cons: Management style is to bully while overworking and underpaying. They don’t reward for loyalty, time served, performance or education. New hires are brought on and make more than current tenured employees. PennyMac TV is propaganda spewing BS that makes everybody forced to look at it nauseous with disgust.

title: Very poor management and no respect for employees
pros: There are some really smart and nice people, very friendly and talented. Good cafeteria.
cons: Very poor management from HR to IT. No one cares unless its something that effects them. No respect to employees. Management don't take any responsibility of solving any issues/concerns raised and they play very bad politics. Also, there are some employees with real bad attitude... This is my experience, from the short time I have been there.. couldn't hurt my self further and no body deserves it... and the very reason I am writing this review.. just be cautions and don't believe looking at the appearance...

title: Overall good company to work for
pros: Growing company with opportunity to advance your career. Offers good benefits and retirement plan. The Penny Pantry offers both breakfast and lunch with a great menu. Most of the locations are very festive and is a great place to work during the holidays.
cons: Would prefer more vacation time and some senior leadership can be viewed as micro managers.

title: Great Job, Poor Leadership
pros: The job is not exactly as advertised, but could certainly be a great one to have if led by better management. Coworkers were awesome and easy to socialize with. Job was challenging enough to keep engagement, while remaining an easy task.
cons: The reason why I would not recommend this job is because there is no ambition to strive for greater. Leadership does not appreciate any collaboration to boost job performance. From my experience, my manager preferred to control and dictate the way in which a person must do their daily job functions. Manager was allowed to force the team to take lunch at a specific time with set times to take a break with no regards to the preferences of the the customers in regards to contacting them in relation to their loans. Also, the hours constantly changed. Management provided that hours would change from training to the official start, but they did not explain that hours would also change after you started the job. If this is the job that you would like to work, be prepared to be treated as a robot that is expected to do exactly as told. Free thinking is not allowed, even if it optimizes your job performance. Be sure to keep tabs on all of your job processes, but do not make it known. Screenshots are a necessity to have, but not need rather than to need and not have. I would also recommend that you get management to provide you either written or recorded affirmations of what you have been told. This is not to say that management is to not be trusted, but it is to say that you want to be well prepared just in case the job starts to become stressful and records start to age into a forgotten zone.

title: Great company!
pros: Compensation is the most competitive in the industry
cons: Long days if you do not hit your numbers.

title: From Great Team & SM to Finding out the True Company Colors
pros: The *people* in the office truly got along in most cases and supported one another. My sales manager and team specifically were amazing! Great dynamic we personally had; nearby teams essentially followed! Most of the tenure was great with these individuals! Picked mostly wonderful staff. ********************************** The Con is a review of the Finale of most of their employees. I will still provide 3 stars for an average rating. I could’ve been tricked into giving 5 for how great my team was but it would not be fair. The following Con was true in my experience and shows the company colors (tiger stripes) when looked beyond the team pond and out.
cons: When the industry changed due to this year’s tip in inflation, they demoted every female SM in my branch to LO. Many of the males retained their positions and fewer were demoted. Loyal employees were mislead though to the end with the Ultimate Layoff; almost every single LO terminated. (No prior official warning) In general, a member of senior management verbally assured employees that they were built for such changes via the company structure; throughout the beginning of the year to the very end. They said essentially “we always pivot and succeed.” Pivoted their staff off the roster, and the opposite of being direct, I see. Some leadership even commented on other companies doing such layoffs with distaste. Can you spell h y p o c r i c y? Assuming they surely knew their own plans all along they’d have been best to have prepared their employees to step aside and find new opportunities before other companies in the same industry did just the same. Disrespectful to employees efforts. I had a feeling it was coming months ahead but asking a couple peers privately if they thought it would happen, they said, “no way!” Because of assurances. Then they all became unprepared, unlike me, I left very shortly before The Event. I felt tension, I felt fake, and like I was being lied to not by my SM but by those above about that certain reality, and felt expected to smile, and not ask questions as those leadership pawns talked of assurance and how they’d PIVOT and get better. Thanks PNMAC, loved your staff! Glad to see you valued them immensely and let them down easy! (not..) Last con: this probably won’t matter because of capitalism; they seem to have demonstrated at the end they cared less for those who had supported the company for months or years and their livelihood/quality of life than their bottom dollar. Least they could do it was say it than leave everyone else unprepared in the market. Things likely won’t change next time. But they hurt a lot of people I knew in an already historically bad year with cold regard. Surely this is not all the Phoenix branch and could be corporate orders, but that is to say it should not have been the case.

title: There's Better Options
pros: It was a work from home environment
cons: Micromanaging, constantly having work questioned by not only managers but other departments almost every day. Company did not know what to do with overtime so never offered it. On top of that they started an ad campaign and then laid off a bunch of employees right after. From what I have heard, customers don't like it either. If you think you can put up with that, go for it. They paid okay and hired quick, just don't be surprised when they lay you off quickly too.

title: Great People, Terrible Work-Life Balance
pros: The people you work with as an MLO are great. I love working for my direct manager and channel manager. The site lead is nice and personable. The money is good as well. I enjoy the culture and inclusivity that Pennymac offers.
cons: No flexibility in schedule. It is a VERY strict 9-6 schedule with no room to shift unless approved 48 hours in advance. There is no ability to work from home. If you do happen to have something happen personally and need time off, you're made to feel like your job is in jeopardy.

title: No wage increases even for cost of living
pros: The culture was good and they had a good meal plan
cons: No raises unless you advance, no annual cost of living increase, and poor bonus structure. They didn't seem to care about burnout or allowing employees to use their vacation time when requested. Overstepped personal and private boundaries at times as well.

title: Extremely happy loan officer, but extremely disappointed by the company in the end.
pros: During COVID the executive team sent very thoughtful gifts out almost monthly to help keep the camaraderie going. It was a nice gesture. Sadly, the rest of the culture is just awful. It’s just another lender ran by “the good old boys” from the now defunct lenders who created the turmoil of the last lending crisis. The pay was decent but could be better. Benefits were fairly priced. Met many great managers and fellow LO’s and Ops members. Tremendous talent there until the mass layoffs. The good talented people got cut, leaving just the good old boys and their BFF’s like it’s high school all over again. Top performers with stellar quarterly and annual reviews IN writing/documented. ALL gone! If you don’t know mortgage they do have decent training program. I came on as a Senior LO so I didn’t need the training but got to see it firsthand and it’s good. Office is very nice. Modern. HQ has a restaurant inside! Very cool facilities. Coffee is good. That is important too for any hard working LO. Get rid of the toxic old school individuals here and you’ve got a company that will last! Many things could be solved by asking the hard working employees who work there. I’d go back in a heartbeat if the flaws were addressed head first. I truly believe in this company.
cons: Low Comp, Leads aren’t consistent. You can’t go from making $200K to $60K due to lead inconsistency. Don’t blame the market because I’m referencing the time before rates went up. Lack of true culture that’s inclusive and welcoming to everyone including women and minorities. It’s 2023 soon! Not 1990! The diversity and inclusion program is a joke currently. Upper Management is aged out, stuck in their old toxic ways. Too buddy buddy/ high school popularity contest nonsense. Trim the true fat. Them! Stop laying off all the talented folks who have given years of hard work here. Give both the LO and Processors more control over their files. Then you’ll stop the crazy fallout! Listen to your employees from the bottom up. Less micromanagement of preforming employees. It’s counterproductive to many. The company gave up too quick, too easily just to keep stockholders happy. Mass layoffs could’ve been avoided and done more strategically. Stop lying to the media and fess up on layoffs. Soon you will need quality employees again and a lot of those same people who were displaced by the mass layoff will still be looking for a job while you do not have enough individuals to run the business. It’s just a vicious circle and very avoidable. The cost of onboarding and laying off employees is not cheap.

title: horrible experience
pros: some of the people were nice and the processes were clear
cons: following timing of time off phone and reviewing phone calls constantly if you are underselling. There is more of a push to get people to close than to help people. You are to skate around items people ask to get them to close.

title: Disenchanted
pros: Company is growing and hiring more staff, so layoffs are unlikely. Still relatively small, so there are opportunities to acquire skills that would take many more years in a larger company.
cons: Management is not generous with sharing the benefits of growth. No increases in pay, sometimes for years, even with a promotion, it is entirely discretionary and every pay increase has to be approved by the President! Bonuses for ordinary employees are paid out at less than target. Benefits are very expensive.

title: PennyMac celebrates its 10th anniversary
pros: Agoura has casual work attire and I hear they are building a gym. IT has a laid back culture the people are fun to work with, however do not be fooled by their culture, they work extremely hard. On site, restaurant Penny Pantry prices are reasonable and the food is excellent.
cons: Management is very different depending on the department and location; I see many sub cultures. PennyMac seems to be going through some growing pains reorganization etc.

title: Offshore hiring
pros: Good benefits. Some positions are remote
cons: PennyMac as of 5/9/22 fired 100 people at our location alone and meanwhile I have to listen to someone training offshore ( cheap labor ) over the phone all day to replace the jobs here in the U.S. . Also they throw left wing politics in your face all the time and in “training courses” they literally make you click and drag what a transgender is? I thought I would be just learning about the mortgage industry but apparently they want you to know what the difference is between a sex stereotype and a transgender woman?

title: My time with PennyMac
pros: PennyMac is a great company with a wide door that welcomes its new employees. I was given great training and help from many employees virtually as I transition from being a full-time college student to a full-time employee. Such a great working environment. Very easy to adjust to work from a remote location. Employees are always ready to give a helping hand.
cons: The only con I can think of is there are no bonuses.

title: Great Company to work for
pros: I love the team work we have with other team members. There is lots of communication and that's what I love. Everyone is very helpful when there is an issue and is real quick with getting this resolved. Most of all I love how amazing my managers are to us!
cons: We do come across some delays that we need to share with our borrowers and sometimes they are not too happy with the news. We do sometimes work longer hours to keep up with the workload. Communication is the key!

title: Loan Processor
pros: My main pro here is that we have a good base pay. Pay can increase depending when you join the site.
cons: Not a lot of room for growth. No annual increases, no increases based on annual reviews. You get paid less than new hires. (It becomes your job to train the new people.

title: A company with great growth potential
pros: A High volume of loans
cons: Plenty of work to keep you busy, Still a good thing

title: PennyMac
pros: As a 5+ year employee for PennyMac, this is one of the best companies I have worked for. From their core values to the culture that has been created makes this a wonderful workplace that anyone can thrive in. PennyMac offers a great lead source of existing customers and a booming comp plan with a work life balance that is hard to find. Career opportunities for growth are always available as PennyMac continues to grow.
cons: Due to Covid, I am no longer able to work side by side with my team members.

title: Adaptability
pros: In my few years at PennyMac I have seen them adapt and evolve in terms schedules, holidays and benefits. It's great that we are trying to enhance these benefits but I think we are still behind some comparable companies.
cons: We still need to evolve on the strategy around raises and promotions which do not happen often enough

title: Okay
pros: Paid training, Good intro to industry
cons: Extremely driven to return all employees to offices without really explaining why. Extremely High Quotas for Production. Not a lot of clear communication on how to accomplish complex problems acquired.

title: BEST JOB EVER
pros: I would like to share how much i enjoy working here. I like coming into work every morning with a positive energy. I really enjoy all the feedback i get from my peers and management good or bad its always great to know where i stand. I am happy with all the support i have received throughout the time i have been here and the future as well.
cons: There really is no downside working at PennyMac, such a great company and there is room for growth.

title: Excellent Company, Even better employees and Culture.
pros: Management is always open to questions and ready to assist in all opportunities to help us learn. I feel as if we are trusted in our rolls and pick up new skills every day.
cons: If you are not ready to work in a fast paced environment, or shy to ask questions, this is a huge part of getting over the learning curve. Ask as many questions as you can early on so you’re not stuck once your process becomes more of your individual responsibility.

title: Home Loan Specialist
pros: Coming with no experience in this industry, their training is amazing, some of the best in the industry. You will work very hard but compensation and recognition will be on par. Very organized, health benefits great, cares about employees
cons: May take a while to move up, if quick advancement is your goal, then you will really have to put in the work and rub shoulders with the right people

title: Compliance
pros: The people are helpful and mid. management were good leaders
cons: People are overworked, you're expected to skip lunches and work until 1am if that means an unrealistic deadline will be met. Moving up within this department is extremely difficult, unless someone quits. The pay is well under what it should be... overworked and underpaid is an understatement. Upper management EVP and above are there to make the CEO happy, they are not interested in helping the growth of their employees.

title: Feels like coming home
pros: Even in a virtual environment where I haven't technically meet my colleagues, they have made me feel a part of the team. I love my job and the people I work with.
cons: For the amount of incoming volume, I'm surprised more hasn't been done sooner to update the system.

title: Used to be a great company
pros: Used to be a great company to work for.
cons: Even before mass layoffs in March and May the company was going downhill. Executives have no idea how to think ahead, didn't plan for market turn. They went on an executive retreat in fall 2021 and by mid January all the priorities had changed. Terrible corporate culture. They will force you to overwork, turn teams against each other, then hand out corporate crap like a branded backpack to make you feel better. Office only culture. Extremely low morale. Overworked employees. Entire groups quit from under the same manager or in the same department and they still keep ineffective and toxic managers.

title: Systems/Processes Need Overhauled
pros: I enjoyed the people I worked with.
cons: Systems are slow and need to be streamlined. Apps/programs that are required to do your job are piecemealed together. Processing/underwriting is a crapshoot. Your file may get closed in 10 days or it may take 60 days. Too many cooks in the kitchen and nobody is responsible for getting the file closed. New pay/bonus structure is too low given the market.

title: Love/Hate Relationship
pros: - Enjoyed working with my peers - Good health, dental, and 401k match - Got to work out of multiple offices they have in different states to meet my peers there and explore a new city - The amount of people you get to pitch even if it is essentially a cold touch
cons: - Micro management - Commission structure could be way more competitive - All the required line for line scripts you have to read - “Retail Control Tower” need I say more

title: Correspondent Customer Service Rep
pros: Smartest Management Team in the business. Perfect at executing executing a customer experience. Compensation was fair when there in a smaller market size. Solid training in varying departments.
cons: Smartest Management Team in the business. No opportunity to grow. Compensation is limited when the market up, margins are wide and shareholder returns are yielding favorably.

title: Micro management taken to an extreme
pros: Growing company, great people, great business model.
cons: Management pounds you with reporting multiple times per day and manage with an iron fist. Constantly negative and threatens your pay all the time. Every aspect of the job has a report and they choose a new one highlight each month.

title: Phenomenal Place to Work
pros: PennyMac is the exception to the rule and not your regular employer. In my experience, our management and employees work well together. This growth and relationship with our staff, customer base and company success is a reflection of this working relationship. Great benefits, advancement with other perks included. Also, we have groups in place for employee and peer recognition, Diversion and Inclusion and our ACT programs just to name a few.
cons: We are in an everchanging industry so things can update from day to day.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: PennyMac is growing the right way and is making changes consistently to be a leader in the business. Management is very supportive and involved with staff. Having been in the business for a long time I value the culture, leadership, and opportunities for growth here at PennyMac. Would certainly recommend working here to anyone thinking of joining a top notch mortgage sales team.
cons: Technology and systems needed improvement. However many changes have been made and am confident they will continue to be made.

title: Great Place to Build a Career in the Mortgage Industry
pros: - Surrounded by experienced, intelligent industry experts - Opportunities for career growth - Inclusive, respectful culture
cons: - Loan Officers do too many loan processing tasks; Processors should be able to handle collecting documents and manage all borrower contact after initial application.

title: Great place for the short term to learn, bad place to grow for and LO
pros: Health benefits and coworkers are great to know.
cons: Pay is way too low for the amount of work, micro management is through the roof, forget about being recognized for doing your job well. Moving up is close to impossible.

title: Activity does NOT equal Achievement
pros: The team collaboration has been consistent and voicing operational changes are always welcomed. Training & Development are consistent and teams allows for continues improvement. Critical work is always challenging but the teams will recognize your performance when deliverables are achieved. I have also seen many around me advance in roles by exceeding performance goals and helping others. This environment is tough to beat and other companies are not able to scale at these levels.
cons: Business trends are tied to federal rates.

title: Do yourself a favor and avoid this place
pros: The company is growing out of control, the amount of work that it's creating for itself means that there will always be insufficient staffing, and therefore you will always be tasked with learning a new skill because no one else will be put into the position that actually handles those tasks.
cons: Where do I start? This company's projections are irrational. They are biting off more than they can chew, stressing out employees and every single department. They are lacking in infrastructure, aside for being understaffed and having the feel of a sweatshop. You get 10 vacation days per year, which you have to accumulate. Also the case with sick time, you accumulate 4 hours per month. Things here are grim on every perspective. starting with lack of parking spots, (translating into having to walk from a different company's parking lot on a different street for 10 minutes until you get to your building), continued with the crowded work environment (which is often so loud you can't actually focus on work) to the poor computing technology that hardly supports the tasks needed to be done on a regular basis. The absolute worst of this company is that management is severely lacking in leadership skills. often managers will not acknowledge their employees or even realize how knowledgeable and experienced they are. Career pathing is formally not on the agenda. nepotism rages out of control. You will most likely not get a raise, ever. I have seen people get promoted 2 or 3 times, without getting a raise, with the title change being delayed up to 3 months, and taking on additional responsibilities while minimizing their personal life outside of work for the sake of being able to function. HR is a joke, they take forever to handle claims, and in some cases they even drop the ball to a point where medical workers comp claims get denied because they don't provide forms in due time. Executives pretty much will not acknowledge your existence even if you interact with them on a daily basis. Unless a manager need something from you, he will not even say hello. Promotions are often based on veterancy and position availability. most of the time because of the high turnover rate - positions will just become available and it will be cheaper for the company to promote somebody from within without giving them a raise, rather than hiring somebody from the outside and to try and match market salaries.

title: Business Analyst
pros: not a far commute from where I live. There really is none. There aren't even enough microwaves to heat food.
cons: hmm... There is no room for growth. Even when you switch positions your pay doesn't increase. We were told we would get a bonus and guess what? they took it back lol. Benefits are terrible, morale is terrible, communication within internal parties is HORRIBLE. Goodluck asking a question to another department and getting a response. Even when your manager reaches out to the other department sometimes they still don't respond. The place is laughable. If I could give negative stars I would.

title: Good people, messy operation
pros: Great people, work life balance, relaxed atmosphere
cons: They are a mess- very disorganized, resources ALL over the place. It actually make it very difficult to do the job well. No consistency, poor communication and the managers (in Arizona at least) really lack in the leadership department (you’re basically on your own).

title: Customer service representative
pros: Good pay, work hours, work from home, no experience needed, training provided.
cons: Work hours are during other business ours, so it’s hard to handle personal business and the vacation policy is non existent. I have always been able to travel on vacation on previous jobs every time I request vacation it’s denied I will be coming up on a year and have yet to have any of my request approved.

title: AVOID THIS CUTTHROAT, PRIMADONNA PLACE!! – UNLESS YOU ARE DESPERATE FOR A JOB
pros: I enjoyed working with smart, dynamic people and learning new skills. The cafeteria also served decent food at times. The gym is decent given the size of the room.
cons: I would describe the company culture as being TOXIC at best due to WEAK MANAGEMENT. I had the misfortune of working with managers who were very unapproachable (even narcissistic) and only talked to you when they needed something ASAP (not even a “Good Morning”). In addition, there were many managers who were INCOMPETENT and LACKED FUNDAMENTAL SKILLS to do the job as managed with an “IRON FIST”. Many times, they will take credit for your ideas and work to cover up their own shortcomings. I also felt there was a LACK OF TRANSPARENCY working on projects since I was NOT INVITED TO CRITICAL MEETINGS and UNREALISTIC DEADLINES WERE PROMISED to the stakeholder. To make matters worse, I wasted more time having to re-clarify what deliverables are needed as well as being under intense pressure to get things done. In addition to WEAK MANAGEMENT, I would also describe the atmosphere as being a “SECRET SOCIETY” where privileged people (those that have tight connections as a result of nepotism) are allowed to prosper and surpass me (in terms of growth and future opportunities) after I’ve shared all of my valuable knowledge (which took years to develop) with them. Largely, I felt that whatever significant contributions that I have made to the department go unnoticed by upper management unless one of their “privileged” kids had done it (or stolen credit for it). If you decide to join PennyMac, just know that: 1. The commute is horrible and parking is problematic (no work from options allowed). 2. You will be low-balled on salary. 3. Their health benefits are expensive. 4. It will take a very, very long time to accrue any vacation time. 5. You must wait 1 year after start date before you can enroll in 401k program. 6. No work/life balance. 7. No raises or merit increases or promotions unless the CEO approved it (which can take an eternity – this is where it helps to have “tight connections”). 8. Be prepared to be exploited and/or marginalized. 9. Have headphones on to drown out obnoxious, fake laughs. Do not have headphones on when the CEO is in the vicinity (as this is one of his pet peeves). Although I am grateful for the skills that I’ve learned and for the relationships that I’ve developed there, but if I had a do-over, I would have only USED the PennyMac OFFER letter as LEVERAGE (without any intent of ever joining).

title: Fantastic and caring company
pros: This company goes above and beyond to make sure we are well taken care of and good performance does not go unnoticed. I am so thankful to work here!
cons: There aren't really any cons except that the hiring process did take a little longer than I had hoped, however, in the long run it was worth the wait!

title: Amazing Company
pros: I love working for PennyMac. My management team is great and understands work life balance. Production needs go high and low but I am fortunate to be on a team that mostly supports one another
cons: It is easy to slack off and many times it is hard for management to hold those people accountable in a remote environment. I'm not a fan of watching someone in my pay field to half as much as I do and not be counseled for it.

title: Not so great
pros: Its a job The Cafe is decent and convenient
cons: Poor undermarket pay. No room for advancement and without advancement absolutely no decent raises. Senior management and executive management do not care about cost of living increases. Executive management wants people in the office because they have paid rent on huge buildings but will say you have to be in the office for "culture". Laid off 1000 people in March 2022.

title: Account Executive
pros: Large portfolio of lead sources, although the quick expansion and hiring of additional LOs diluted the pool.
cons: Very similar to old Countrywide culture with average management who are unable to meet tech and production advances of the competition. Poor understanding of compliance results in overabundance of punishing policies and unnecessary rules.

title: The worst company I have ever worked for
pros: The meal plan is excellent. For $125 you have unlimited lunch and breakfast. Great if you want to follow a certain fitness-related diet.
cons: - You're regularly expected to work until 9 or 10 pm. By regularly I mean 2-3 times per week. Normal business hours are 9 to 7, but you will often have meetings as early as 8 am; that doesn't mean you get to leave earlier. During certain times of the year you will be expected to come in on Saturday and/or Sunday. - They purposely don't provide laptops, so you have to be in the office to do your work. It's considered a great honor if you're lucky enough to ask for and receive a laptop, but even then, you're expected to work from the office. - 2 weeks of vacation until you've been at the company for 5 years. 3 weeks after that. - Day after Thanksgiving and day after Christmas are not off. - During the fires last year, even if your office was closed, you were expected to show up at another office. People were scrambling to find seats. They just didn't want to give you a 'day off.' - Coworkers are generally pretty unimpressive and one-dimensional. - Mediocre health insurance benefits. - You get half of your bonus every 6 months, so if you need to leave between April and October, you're forfeiting half of your bonus. This is done deliberately to make you stay at the company, or maybe it's another indication of PennyMac nickel and diming literally everything. - No company holiday party, but a couple times a year they bring food trucks and you get to wait in long lines to get a bite to eat and a lukewarm beer. - Extremely steep organization with layers upon layers of middle management. A VP title means squat. They also don't promote quickly, both in title and pay. - They lowball on salary but bonus targets are high. That's how they get ya!

title: Fair. Could be better.
pros: Nice friendly people. The cafeteria is amazing, great food and good prices.
cons: Benefits are average - They are not as competitive for IT employees. Job Title inflation - Seems everyone is a Manager or VP. Some of them don't even have reports. If you are in IT don't expect to get training or grow your knowledge much, you will mostly stay locked into your place for good.

title: PennyMac Honest Review 05/2021
pros: GREAT leadership, obtainable lock goals (adjustable with the market as well), fantastic training, VERY large commission structure, amazing atmosphere, continual hot leads, and a great company culture from the top down.
cons: Must work one Saturday every three weeks, must have COVID-19 vaccine to work in office (can't provide antibody test, or Tcell test), cannot send LE's to borrowers via email, work life balance can be a bit tipsy depending on market/monthly goals, etc..

title: Boring Outdated Company Culture
pros: Can pay well if you can make use of the outdated systems to be efficient
cons: Old school mindset when it comes to culture. Have to wear business casual and business professional in office when special guests arrrive (they have an internal dress weather schedule I kid you not) Remote work is really poor with the lack of Slack or modern systems to make it feasible.

title: If you are in the club, your golden
pros: Leads Support Walk in, jump on phones, sell
cons: Overtime is a must Pay is terrible for industry No real mentoring for new guys, Front door is a turn style

title: Don't even Apply
pros: Pay is decent some roles working from home
cons: Forced 10 hour days, 6 day work weeks Micromanaged down to the minute Impossible to contact supervisors and managers even during work hours, but will text you at 10pm with questions Instead of hiring new people, you will just get your workload quadrupled. Training, when it happens, is a joke, and if you pay attention- you'll be the one re-training team members because managers and supervisors don't care No raises or bonuses even if you're doing the work of 5 team members

title: Loan Officer
pros: Good pay when the market is good.
cons: Extremely long hours are expected (often 12 hour days) Very competitive, high-stress environment Weekends are expected

title: It was great while it lasted
pros: Great Coworkers, pleasant working experience, quarterly bonuses, health care was good and inexpensive, company 401K and HSA contribution.
cons: Too many people working on one file made it difficult to track progress and determine root cause of problems . Not enough well trained people in credit solutions or precision testing made the job more difficult than it was.

title: They will lay you off with no remorse
pros: Good starting pay, but limited room for growth.
cons: I was laid off right before Christmas after 2 other mass layoffs where we were already spread extremely thin. The company tries to outsource as much labor as possible to India. The time difference and language barriers made for frustrating customer service and internal employee communication. Very little employee input is valued and the upper management is not aware of the real limitations of the positions. They break up key roles to try to streamline the mortgage process, but it leads to a lot of errors and two or three people doing the work of one quality person.

title: Call center
pros: No pros at all
cons: The company is a thief !!! They have lots of corporate politics going on and your performance as employee doesn't matter. I worked for 4 years and micro managed to the second and lots discrimination goes in within the company !!! Minority's are not accounted for and they know how to falsify stuff on you a corporate way which nothing can be done but one day will catch on to them !! They talk about being ethical but they should be ethnically themselves before preaching to others

title: Not a great culture
pros: Nice colleagues. Food is decent at the pantry.
cons: Depending on who you know at the top will determine your career at this company. People who have no business being promoted move up very quickly while hard working people get passed up and treated like crap. Constant turnover with nothing being done to fix. HR is a joke and does nothing about it cause they are part of the problem.

title: Love being a PennyMac'er!
pros: There is such a great feeling of community among the team, even while working through home. Management is wonderful and always understanding and helpful. There is a lot of room for growth and movement within PennyMac as well which is great!
cons: I started working from PennyMac during the pandemic so I have not yet had the opportunity to meet my fellow co-workers in person yet. Aside from that I really haven't experienced any cons to working here.

title: Hired too many, then fired access
pros: Pay - Appropriate for work load
cons: They hire though a temp agency and that would be fine but they told about 4 of us that it was a temp to hire position. Then volume dropped and they fired us. So they do not care about the people at all. I would not have taken the position if I knew it was temporary. But they know if they would have said that they would have gat garbage temps.

title: Overstaff
pros: It’s a good company but they overhire then do massive layoffs. They have not figured out that they are the lender and needs to lay down a complete broker guideline and procedures with realistic turn times then they could manage workforce much better
cons: It is an end to end process where they have a sar dept but the people are not fully trained va. They have people clearing conditions that really don’t know what they are actually clearing

title: Industry dinosaur
pros: You will work with very intelligent dedicated people, until they are let go in order for the company to have a good earnings call.
cons: Salary is 10-15% below market Many token employees to satisfy diversity quota They live in the shadow of Bank of America No raises, they think the annual bonus should cover it No promotions, 3-5 years if you decide to stay.

title: You're a passionate Engineer? Don't work here. Period.
pros: Great cafeteria options (although a little expensive) Great gym and facilities
cons: If you're a passionate software or infrastructure engineer, just stay away from this place. Not only is there unnecessary process and office politics at every turn, but you have to deal with bully managers and a systemic toxic culture that leaves no room for work/life balance. And as others have mentioned, you will never get a raise at this place, ever. No bonus for you either, while most managers and executives roll into work in their $60k+ cars and have performance incentives in the form of QUARTERLY bonuses. Engineering is seen as nothing more than overhead and a bottom pyramid servicing department (like is the case with most financial services companies). This means they need you to follow orders, and not ask too many questions. Don't expect to have any freedom at all while writing code, or architecting systems either. They might lead you on to thinking you have control, but you have no authority over projects, yet are expected to be responsible for the outcome. Responsibility and authority are inseparable. This dynamic does inevitably lead to failures, that will hang over your head. Still feel like you wanna give this company a try and see for yourself? Well, you'll be looking at legacy code and poorly documented systems all day and working on a ton of dead end projects. Hard work will earn you no credibility whatsoever. You'll spend hours stuck in meetings and managers will then wonder why you're still debugging. You will then be asked to work weekends because "things just need to get done around here". If this is what you want day in and day out, then go for it. They're always hiring Engineers because people keep quitting, so you could very well end up getting an offer fairly quick.

title: PennyMac
pros: I have been with PennyMac for 4 years. They are an ok company, not great. It is close to home.
cons: The company does not pay their employees well and does not offer much in terms of benefits. Favoritism can be seen.

title: Loan Officer
pros: Management is trying to improve, company is getting more youthful and slowly things changing for better, not worse. Compensation is very good for industry/education level of employees
cons: The work itself is taxing, benefits are simply alright, and opportunities to move up, while fairly assessed, seem somewhat rare

title: Opportunity Advancement
pros: I have been with PennyMac for 5 years in
cons: umer Direct Lending. I have worked extremely hard in my time here but I have been rewarded by being promoted twice. PennyMac is a true meritocracy...if you work hard it will not go unnoticed!

title: Great Place to Work
pros: PennyMac values the advise and experience of its employees. The company strives for efficiency in what it does, and I like that model. PennyMac strives to see their employees succeed and they also provide the tools to help with that success.
cons: Because of all the growth happening inside the company, job duties and responsibilities can change frequently. As a result, if someone is a person that does not adapt quickly to change, it could be stressful.

title: Happy Employee
pros: Good leadership and solid teams. All of the management teams I have met or talk to are friendly and make it easy to come to for questions.
cons: So far the only con is how vacation days are earn and how little vacation is given compare to many other companies today. Most companies start off with 3 weeks and go up from there.

title: Terrible
pros: The only pro to this company is that the people are nice
cons: Management is completely disconnected from everything involved, clients, transfers, processing, etc. Poor communication, poor management at all levels, very few leads (even when rates are lower) and a LOT of wasted time from managers, processing and corporate. Too much extra paperwork and reports on EVERY file Pay structure is setup for success ONLY at the top tier, all other tiers don't pay much at all. Also, the processing and back end team are incapable of closing many loans anyway. The only people who see success work 18 hours a day and every weekend.

title: Very nice people
pros: On site cafeteria, gym, benefits
cons: Finding out what you will actually do versus what you think you are being hired for can be eye-opening. It takes awhile to learn the business.

title: Good luck finding employment with PNMAC on your resume
pros: Well, they have a great sales pitch to reel you in, and they give you a draw so you're not starving at first
cons: I could easily write a 90 page novel here that would have so many details the review would not get approved and so I'm forced to keep it as general as possible since Corporate America rules the country these days. God forbid we have transparency... I'll echo what many have said below: 1) Poor systems - yes, your loan application will take anywhere from 1-4+ hours, and don't complain about the systems, all roads lead to: It's your fault 2) Hours - plan on gaining weight, eating microwave food, never seeing the light of day, and putting family time on hold 3) Plan on having any/all "concerns" dismissed by the sociopaths in charge. They've sold their souls, and they expect you to do the same. 4) Without going into detail, if you're a highly ethical/empathetic/caring individual, it's not the place for you to work. You'll continually get to deliver bad news to clients for reasons I cannot discuss here. 5) They put the "Cult" in "Culture" - So anyone that's caught speaking up, will be tracked down and pulled into meetings; So if you want a taste of what employment might be like in China, or other authoritarian dictatorships, PNMAC is a great place to learn what that's like. 6) Fundings - Anytime you think you're going to have that "great month" watch as fulfillment/processing and others that you count on simply disappear at key points in the process, leaving your clients calling you asking why the notary didn't show up. 7) Expect contradictory guidance - at one moment you're told to do X, then plan on being pulled into a meeting for doing too much of X. 8) Watch as people are promoted SOLELY for parroting management. It truly is like High School 9) Plan on having your loans purposefully and strategically delayed so that by the time you DO decide you want out, you'll be forced to walk away from many clients you worked hard at covering up all of the shortcomings of the company and keeping them on board with the process, because you wont' get paid and in fact, PNMAC hires "special" bean counters to go through your pipeline to try to reduce any/all income before you leave. They love what they do and will send you condescending emails with voice of resentment, as if it's your fault that the company has made poor choices and you're now leaving. 10) Finale' time!!! Good luck finding employement anywhere else in a direct to consumer MLO role. When recruiters see PennyMac on your resume, you'll be passed up, OR if you do actually go through the long list of reasons why you left, they simply will not believe you and label you as "jaded." Recruiters have zero clue as to how tragically poor the operation here is, that they will actually believe you're just making it up. My advice to recruiters: Believe the reviews here. The negative reviews are not simply weak willed individuals whom lacked grit, perseverance and willingness to succeed. I watched some VERY talented top producers leave the company during my time there.

title: Lacks empathy
pros: Remote work due to covid
cons: Management lacks any sort of empathy. Death in the family? Written up for not hitting goal. Need to take lunch 5 minutes late because you were on a call? Written up. This company is draining.

title: New customer Acquisition
pros: Great place to learn and enter the industry. Be prepared to work hard. Lots of overtime opportunity that is highly encourage. Everyone is pretty helpful and encouraging.
cons: Not much to say except don't work at Pnmac if you're not ready to work hard and put in the time. You get out what you put in. (so not much of a con) You also get scheduled to work one Saturday a month, which isn't that bad in my opinion.

title: Good, but could have been netter
pros: Immediate management was very supportive and helpful. Quarterly production bonuses were great. Work from home (although they are making us go back to office)
cons: Senior management seemed to treat employees like numbers.

title: Ok if you NEED a job
pros: It was work from home and you learn a lot about the mortgage industry.
cons: You're required to get so many customers transferred to the loan officers, if not you'll be coached and then written up. When the housing market changed and rates increased, it was harder to keep your transfer rate up. The calls of customers not even knowing what kind of loan they have and wondering why their monthly payment increased was irritating.

title: worst company ever, with unethical upper mgmt
pros: paid parking, cafeteria on site
cons: i repeat long long hours, uncomfortable working conditions, low pay, no appreciation for hard work, long hours, unethical business practices, boring atmosphere with no personality within employees

title: Sales Manager
pros: Plano is a new site with lots of opportunity for growth and career advancement. PennyMac believes on promoting from with in! Compensation plan is very aggressive. Great culture and benefits.
cons: Some of the systems we use can use updating. PennyMac is currently in the process of advancing our technology to make our daily activities easier and add more automation to the process benefiting both internal and external customers.

title: Depends on the Department
pros: A great manager that will vouch for you will make this experience wonderful. Many nice people. Sometimes remote work is possible, depending on department. HQ has an excellent meal plan.
cons: Takes a whole year to vest for matching 401k. Turnover. Any raise beyond 6% requires CEO and/or Chairman of the Board sign off.

title: Expect same pay for awhile
pros: So many different departments so you can learn new things. Decent benefits, could be better.
cons: The only way to get a raise is to get promoted which doesn't happen often. I have friends that were there for years and got one raise. Not a ton of opportunity for growth. Some of their management shouldn't be management. Micro managing. You have to track everything you do and submit it daily which is a real pain.

title: PennyMac needs management restructuring
pros: Excellent benefits package & paid time off.
cons: Bad senior & mid-level management. The Retail purchase division has key people in upper management positions that don't understand their role or the Industry as a whole. Company CORE values don't line up with the way the company is being run

title: Leading the way in Mortgage Servicing
pros: As an IT professional we get to work with many of the latest and greatest technologies in AWS. Managers take to the time to thank and recognize hard work. PennyMac values all their employees and sends frequent care packages in these unprecedented times with COVID pandemic.
cons: The process for new infrastructure or minor design changes is arduous.

title: Wolves in Sheeps Clothing
pros: Pay was decent and overtime was offered when 'they' needed us and WE pulled through for 'them'. I did take away more knowledge in a particular area of mortgage from this job.
cons: I was laid off 5/9/22. The 'WE' I speak of are the numerous 'bodies/numbers' that handled the load when the market was exploding when covid hit and all the bodies before me that gave their best to PennyMac over the years, namely many veterans, including myself, who were there in the trenches when it counted. Upper management has no idea of key employee contributions and stellar records because they don't care to know. I was under a management team that came to the company connected to each other and used our knowledge and ideas making them their own promising help and support to advance in the company when, in the end, they cut us loose once they had what they needed. No efforts by management to communicate with other managers in the company to move key, talented employees into other areas of interest. They say they will do this but never follow through with the support of their statements that they will do all they can to help you succeed. I felt used in the end and taken advantage of, BUT knew in my heart all along the kind of 'clickish' people I was under anyway. I still showed up to my job each day and proved my worth so felt good having helped 'MY clients' in my role with PennyMac on a personal level. I felt sad when I was laid off, BUT also felt a weight of lies and deceipt lifted off my life of which I am the wiser for. You always hear of large companies in this manner. "It's corporate America, they (the big fishes) are all about revenue never thinking of the LOYAL LITTLE FISHES that are helping them swimming in the trenches, taking care of the customers each day going above and beyond." From the biggest fishes (upper management) down to lower management, unless you fit their idea of staying a subservient employee ALWAYS, never having a desire to advance your career, you will lose in the end with PennyMac. Save yourself the trouble and STEER CLEAR OF THIS COMPANY! OR, take advantage of learning 1 thing really well expecting once you do, you will be ready to move on to another company cause' this one does not have an interest in paying you your worth in the end. I believe one of the reasons PennyMac is set up the way it is, namely people working only 1 specific area of the loan process is to keep them hungry for more knowledge and leaving them trapped with expertise only in only one skill set as many they hire don't have broad experience in the mortgage industry. They can't have people learning and knowing too much because it's NOT this companies practice to advance people in their careers and PAY THEM MORE MONEY. This is truly a revolving door company where advancement is not based on merit. I saw MANY talented AND CLASSY people leave the company on their own, wise to this practice, before lay offs and even after the first round of layoffs. I happened to be laid off in the second round having top production numbers for 2 and 1/2 years while having the best record of helping loans to close on time, etc.

title: Worked there in the FT worth Tx location for less than a yr Bad management all the way around
pros: Just a job to get a paycheck
cons: stressful , not organized , low company meral , fired me thru voicemail was approved for vacation they fired me while i was on vacation , talks about employess pay on the floor to other supv an reps , i had 6 yrs of short sale an mod exp they made me an customer service rep an complained that they where paying me to much

title: Lot of micromanagement although it's a trade off for constant leads and processing support
pros: Leads provided as well as corporate structure allowing for plenty of support on all ends. Can't find many places that have consistently solid lead sources.
cons: Receive 10 +reports a day from management and judged on every aspect of your day to day work. Operations often miscommunicate, and there are always IT issues

title: Loved the people
pros: supervisors and mid level management is very supportive co workers make the day enjoyable with collaboration and support fun work get togethers and team building actives generous PTO of 3 weeks
cons: no raises hard to move into new opportunities for growth pay level does not match time and effort put into my position. Salary based with no overtime however put in several hours a day over the 8 hours.

title: Why take steps when you can take leaps forward w/ PennyMac
pros: Excellent base and commission opportunities. You work a lot of hours but not a second is wasted and the income is ready for the taking.
cons: Working past scheduled shift, but thats mainly because I can end early knowing so many solid internal leads are there to originate.

title: Love PennyMac!
pros: Very employee focused. They really rallied for the employees and their families/friends with COVID. Starting a program for displaced workers and moved everyone home immediately and almost seamlessly so there was no disruption to the employee or the customer. I am proud to work here.
cons: I don't think the salaries and bonuses are as high as many mortgage companies, however the growth potential is high and encouraged.

title: They run a tight ship...
pros: Flexible IT organization allowed for working remote.
cons: Lack of direction or desire for ownership of services/processes. Never enough resources for BA roles. Most of the Senior IT is run by engineers who were there when the company started. This lead to a lot of customized IT processes that were never properly documented. Has a feel of a "Old boys club" in order to advance.

title: Treated like a cog in the machine under a microscope
pros: pay is good when the market is good and rates are low
cons: pay is completely reliant on where the % rate market is, if the market goes up pay goes down. The most micro managed I've ever been or ever even heard of from a company

title: Do Not step a foot in this place!!
pros: Casual days, OT will compensate for the pay since much needed to work your loans
cons: This company will not tolerate complainers, employees that gets sick (noone will work your loans until you come back), employees that are struggling w monthly goal (they do not train newcomers, couple days of general NOT actual job function training, good luck if you get to sit side by side w someone in your team who even has the time (they are all stressed out and gets moody when you even ask questions), company does NOT give raises as this was mentioned by older employees still there and ones that had left, be careful as this company has families and relatives all over locations and watch who you communicate with and what you say, no life as you work weekends to catch up w piled up loans. I've seen a lot of employees getting fired left and right and employees walking out Not returning back to work. It's a shame that they do not recognize good knowledgeable employees as they look at quantity not quality. Currently awaiting responses from outside interviews to get away from this sweatshop, would be gone right away if i was not suffering financially. Company environment is very loud and people on phones cannot hear customers w alot of distraction from other employees talking on the side. Micro managed pipelines so make sure not to forget to put notes on files at least every other day.

title: Excellent place to work!!
pros: Company provides constant learning opportunities to grow yourself and improve your self professionally. Benefits - Great health insurance coverage with Vitality wellness program (gives monthly insurance discount) HSA, Retirement/401K, Great pay-scale.
cons: Transfer opportunities are limited unless you initiate and fight for them!

title: PennyMac doesn’t give raises
pros: Working from home Most managers don’t micromanage
cons: You can literally work at PennyMac for years and never get a raise. When you do, it’s a $2 raise. Go elsewhere unless you are planning to work there for 6 years while never getting a promotion.

title: Worst company ever
pros: My manager was great and she tried to help bring our department up to date
cons: No raises, any move to a higher position was considered lateral

title: Overall a good place to work
pros: Great people, nice work environment, no micro-managing, Awesome cafeteria food. Clean environment, equipment is current and efficient for work
cons: Poor Health Benefits, no annual merit increases or compensation, Many are overworked due to high turnover in the IT environment.

title: Great Company to Work For!
pros: I came into PennyMac not knowing anything about the mortgage industry since I was in food service prior. They gave me a chance and taught me everything I needed to know about succeeding in my career with PennyMac. The managers are all great. I don't have anything bad to say about this company. Looking forward to growing with this company.
cons: I haven't found anything bad about PennyMac.

title: loan counselor
pros: great work environment; always able to get answers to my questions
cons: my 90 days was on May 9th and i have to work 112 days before i receive my sick time. I'm a single parent and i wish they would have told us that before 90 days was promised that it may actually be longer

title: Absolutely Love it here!
pros: *Job Security *Best workplace environment and amazing people! *Management really helps and wants you to grow within the company * Working from home can be a challenge elsewhere but Pennymac has really owned it and made sure we are all taken care of during this pandemic.
cons: None - Great Company to work for.

title: Good Company with old mentality
pros: Good People, focused on equality and current events, good compensation.
cons: Closed minded about work from home options.

title: Do better Management
pros: Decent pay and work from home opportunity
cons: Lack of help/assistance for every new daily tasks that are assigned for the workers.

title: Could be more employee driven
pros: Depending on your direct management some mangers are VERY compassionate and understanding and always work around your schedules.
cons: Pennymac High Ups seem to not care about what the employees want. They do not care about what may work best for a good home/work balance and REFUSE to pay well.

title: Customer Service
pros: Good opportunity to make commission with a livable pay rate and good work environment, friendly staff, and if you put in the work then you will see it reflect in your commission.
cons: I don't really think there is any cons to this place it all comes down to how you make it to be, and if you have a positive attitude then it will be a good experience working here.

title: Great place to work if you’re looking for a “Good ‘Ol Boys Club”!!
pros: Sadly the only two things I can think of are decent benefits and a subsidized cafeteria.
cons: They do not treat women as equals, and even border on sexual harassment, which seems to be a part of their culture. Right before the pandemic, any managers with employees working under them were pulled into a meeting, not shockingly, most of them were men. When they returned, they gathered around near my desk and joked and laughed at a mandate to hire more women. My manager turned to me, and said, “yeah, I was pretty much told I HAD to hire you because you were female.” Another incident with an MD, reviewing presentation materials with my group. It was stressed that everything needed to be perfect, to which the male MD turned and looked at me (the only female in the room), and said, “well that’s why she’s here. To make things pretty.” I also witnessed my male colleague, hired at the same time as me, get one on one training on a daily basis. I was never afforded the same, and in fact, when I asked questions I was treated like I was stupid and told to figure it out myself. Not only was he given more training, but also more work to do. There would be hours upon hours that I was given little to no work to do, but he would be kept busy…it was so obvious that the manager in charge of our work actually said to me, “I know I’m giving him all the work right now, but he needs to learn how to use Excel.” So…because he was under qualified he gets all the work? Or is it because Im female and they were trying to squeeze me out? It’s truly a wonder they haven’t seen sued. Steer clear unless you have thick skin and are prepared to put up with this 1950’s mentality. Truly appalling!

title: Disappointing.
pros: Parking is free and there is an on-site cafeteria.
cons: Unfriendly and unprofessional environment. The middle manager over our department delegated a lot of responsibility to seniors or "team-leads". The people in these positions were not only very young and inexperienced but also downright immature and catty. They clearly held their personal friends to more lenient standards than the rest of us and took good care of their friends when doling out various work assignments. There were times when people at adjacent desks would be supposedly working on important projects and I would hear nothing but whispering and giggling (not exaggerating here) or in some cases loud talking and flirting for 10, 15, and 20 minutes at a time as I was working my hardest during a very busy day. I eventually invested in some earbuds. Also, I witnessed cases of well-connected people getting picked for promotions over those who were clearly superior candidates in terms of tenure and performance. I noticed that (shocker) young entry-level people whose parents or family members worked at the company or BoA/CW managed to move out of the trenches and into much better positions with the most incredible speed. The Moorpark location is a long drive from most parts of L.A. It is actually in a business park on the outskirts of town which is even worse because you have to drive 5-10 minutes into town if you want to eat somewhere other than the company cafeteria. It was announced to us that everyone in the company would lose one of their discretionary days but the exact explanation given was that both discretionary days were to be replaced with a single "religious freedom" day. Interesting. Around the same time, the company became much more aggressive about hiring many more new workers as temps and also keeping them at temp status for as long as possible. Many temps (I was not a temp) of over 6 months tenure who had proven themselves to be solid employees were still being denied conversion to full employee status (and therefore all benefits). Given what I know and what I've heard about the history of Countrywide and Kurland's involvement in it, I probably should have come in with lower expectations.

title: Great growth company.
pros: If you work hard enough and are placed in the right departments, you can expect fast promotions and good compensations if you work hard.
cons: Company is still small, so benefits and time-off policies are not that great compared to other larger, financial firms. Also, Moorpark is not the best location to have a financial services firm.

title: Senior Underwriter - Worse place I've worked since being in the mortgage industry
pros: Fantastic co-workers, other than that there aren't any pros. Stay away at all costs.
cons: Absolutely terrible management in the underwriting department in Texas. Favortism is rampant, no company culture, low balled on salary, employee input not received and suggestions not taken well. I absolutely despise this place. STAY AWAY UNLESS YOU ABSOLUTELY NEED A JOB.

title: Good starting level
pros: Fair pay, flexible hours, very willing to train new overtime is available. Very few very welcoming employees, sick time policy and vacation available
cons: Unfair goals set for production and quality. Very stringent on the review process benefit accrual and amount of time given is fair but accrues so slowly

title: Great company!
pros: The culture is amazing and they really care about my personal success and growth. There are weekly site meetings that keep me informed of everything that is going on company and office wide. Overall the communication is better than everywhere I have worked in the past and everyone is very accessible.
cons: At this time, there is nothing I could put in this section.

title: great place to work
pros: This company has a very collegial atmosphere; everyone is friendly and welcoming. There does not seem to be any finger prointing or back-stabbing.
cons: Headquarters are in CA, so I imagine that TX employees may have to stay late in order to fully engage with counterparts there (on the plus side, you're unlikely to have to come in early for a meeting).

title: Good company, low benefits, low concern for people
pros: The company will be around a while if you're seeking employment for the long term.
cons: The company is a reasonably well run, but its management theories are back in the 60-70's. Benefits, such as vacation are not up today's standards. Hard to move up unless you're willing to give up your life.

title: Dysfunctional and ineffective management
pros: Lots of great people, some flexibility in work life balance. This company will challenge you and you will learn self reliance.
cons: Upper management is disconnected and does not support staff. Unprofessional behavior by managers is ignored or otherwise minimized. Support if you are female or LGBTQ+ is uneven and perfunctory at best. Annual review process is virtually useless and performance based increases are nonexistent for the majority of staff.

title: Talent Acquisition
pros: PennyMac is a wonderful company to work for. The management team is very supportive, and will go above and beyond to ensure their associates needs are met. I love the culture, the location is great, and the people I work with are like family. I'm here for the long haul!
cons: The only downside is 401k does not being the first day of employment.

title: Caring Company, ExcitingTechnology,
pros: Smart, fun people, cool technology, purpose-driven
cons: Haven't gotten to personally meet anyone due to work from home

title: Nepotism everywhere
pros: Some great people work here and I did like the company culture.
cons: Nepotism runs rampant here. If you are not with the in crowd you stay in low positions. When I worked there they were only giving raises if you were promoted only.

title: Decent place to work if you’re willing to put in the time
pros: Decent compensation and ok management.
cons: Taking days off will affect the quality of calls you get. You have to put in the time to get paid well even on weekends.

title: Great Company
pros: Great leadership, Great people, the Company cares, great PennyPantry, Great culture
cons: Not the highest paying company (but the perks and culture makes up for it), vacation time low

title: Strong Company with a lot of potential
pros: PennyMac has a strong company culture and they strive to continue to make it a great place to work. Always looking to improve their employee's experience and they really listen to the voice of their employees.
cons: It would benefit employees to have a bit more work-life balance and/or the ability to work remotely.

title: PennyMac is an Amazing place to work!
pros: The work place is very positive and extremely supportive . The site feels like a huge family working together to assist our customers.
cons: To ensure the best Customer Service we do work a couple holidays like President's Day and Veterans Day but are off on the major holidays.

title: Tough
pros: Clean work space and office.
cons: Total top down control, no consideration for personal life, some good people work here and the leaders are good people but don't realize that they are not providing a good and positive work environment.

title: Crazy Metrics High turn over
pros: Cool colleagues. Clean bathrooms. Good training.
cons: One of the highest turnovers in the industry. I think their goal is to have a high turnover so you work yourself to death trying to meet their metrics only to get fired or resign and walk away from your pipeline so they don't have to pay you. Terrible upper management who puts pressure on lower management and in turn all others suffer. Unattainable metrics (everyone has had a write-up at some point at this company). As your call #'s go up, your call-to-app will go down because it's impossible to do an application on people who were transferred to you who have no intention of refinancing. As your call-to-app goes down, you will receive a write-up. If you increase the number of applications you take to increase those numbers (doing applications on people who you know the loan won't close), your call to app will go up but your app to funding will go down. Micromanaged to death. No work-life balance. I have a friend who still works there. He is in the top 15 Loan Officers by funding and currently has a write-up. He has to hear his manager complain on a daily basis about his call volume. Nothing anyone does is good enough at this company. They care more about metrics than the bottom line. This goes to show, even if your end goal is to close many loans, you still aren't good enough. Their goal is to get you to meet their metrics, not close loans. While I was there (one of the only females), I had a perverted manager who always stood really close and when I was sitting down he'd lunge his crotch in my face when my head was at his waist level.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: The Culture The People The Processes Quality of Work Life
cons: The first day of orientation is brutal trying to log into the systems. Requires you to have 2 devices such as your smart phone and PC. If you can get through that first day without being too aggravated you've done better than most.

title: Great Atmosphere and People
pros: Growing company rapidly, love getting referrals from employees
cons: Pay is not competitive with the positions and duties performed.

title: Best platform in the industry!
pros: Pennymac cares about its employees! They provide the most up to date support to help you perform at your highest level and achieve maximum compensation. I’ve been in the business for 16 years and this is by far the best place I’ve worked.
cons: If you’re not ready to work hard then this isn’t the place for you.

title: Okay place to work
pros: Good pay, lots of overtime if you like overtime
cons: Mandatory overtime, working 12 hours with one 30 min lunch, no bathroom breaks, they will text you on your personal cellphone to see if your okay while on a restroom break, no opportunity for growth, no raises

title: Work Experience
pros: Growth Opportunities, People, Flexibility, Culture
cons: Management, Rush Training, Stress with Goals, Compensation

title: Excellent company to work for and excellent possibilities to succeed.
pros: Collaborative work environment (even when working remote) with management that will go above and beyond to help you achieve your daily, weekly and monthly goals. Excellent opportunities for growth and for massive financial success.
cons: Communication between departments is oftentimes lacking which leads to difficulties in assisting clients properly.

title: Not bad but not great either
pros: Laid Back, Casual, not too buttoned up and stuffy.
cons: Pay, advancement, poor training (if any), knowledgeable people about the task do not make the best leaders and managers.

title: Solid company
pros: Not too stressful still have quotas, but the management team is pretty realistic
cons: sometimes unrealistic sales quotas its kind of a loan sweatshop. in my opinion there shouldn't be quotas on mortgage sales because then it just feels like we are churning and burning through people without regard

title: good job- bad time
pros: pay is decent. 12 weeks paid family leave benefits. I think my location was set for greatness when it first opened. some other sites do not seem that great based on how unhappy their employees were.
cons: they laid off hundreds of ppl when the market shifted- they only care about the bottom line and will not think twice about lay offs

title: Great Company with Great Opportunities
pros: PennyMac is a fast growing company with lots of great opportunities. Everyone I have worked for in my 2 year tenure with the company, have been very supportive and have welcomed my ambition to grow and learn in other departments.
cons: No cons to report yet.

title: No hope
pros: Compensation, there is plenty of over time if you are needing to make extra money. Coworkers, you're not the only one suffering.
cons: Management is very disorganized and unprofessional. They do not value their employees. Will make you believe that there is room for advancement and growth. Make you work like a robot. No raises. With the exception of a few, there are some managers that are unapproachable and make it seem like they are bothered when you need help. Unless you really need a job do not work here.

title: Great Leadership, great velocity, positive outlook
pros: Competent and intelligent management. Care about your career development. Flexible with scheduling - focused on results. Has strong ethical values.
cons: Culture does not tolerate mistakes - Prefers you contain/ hide them. A lot of the work being done is very manual and time intensive. Automation is key.

title: Company doesn’t care about your hard work & dedication
pros: Systems are easy to use
cons: Management is very similar to high school. Favoritisms run through the company. The friends of Management are pampered and kept around and their work is passed on to the real workers.

pros: they train you and feed you for the first 2-3 weeks you're there.
cons: they throw you to the wolves. you're on your after their inadequate training. they gas you up when you do well, but it's all pretty fake. no work/life balance even when they say they value it. don't be surprised if you work 13 hour days as you first start.

title: "Leave the team and rejoin for a higher raise"
pros: Great food for breakfast and lunch choices in cafeteria (partially subsidized), Good leadership to learn from
cons: Salary pay is a joke for associate and senior level, Better off hourly with Overtime, Internal promotion schedule and raise schedule is a joke and archaic

title: LOVE WORKING HERE
pros: All of your coworkers genuinely want you to succeed Plenty opportunities for work to challenge you Mentorship provided by manager (unofficial mentorship, but daily checkins make it easy to ask questions whenever needed) Very thoughtful leadership -- whether covid or otherwise related genuinely the best place I've ever worked at, and I've been in the workplace for about 3 years now.
cons: I really cannot think of one

title: Poor Communication, Treated as Expendable
pros: -Base pay was fair for the role.
cons: -Awful communication from management down. -Laid off with no notice. -Rude/abrasive management. -Forced to get vaccinated in order to get the job. Our entire department was dissolved and laid off just months into employment.

title: Analyst
pros: Came in under good salary, but promotions aren't looked at quickly
cons: Micromanagement is the worst part. If I am going to be micromanaged I hope my salary fits the stress level of that kind of management style.

title: Great place to work, best of all worlds
pros: 1. Big corporate company but feels like a family 2. They promote within, if you work hard and efficient, you will likely be up for a promotion 3. Strong leadership on top, great business model
cons: Company is still growing which means there is usually more work than people hired

title: Best job !!!
pros: They care about their employmees! Main reason, they arent greedy and allow you to overtime if needed. During this covid situation they cared about our health im super happy with my job!
cons: I dont have any downsides, they truly gave us so much training and alot of great people work there too

title: Great salary and good work environment
pros: - Very competitive starting salary - Casual attire at all offices starting in 2020 - PTO starts at three weeks - Pretty good work/life balance but sometimes you have to be proactive about setting that balance yourself.
cons: - Very siloed work streams so you don't learn much outside of your specific duties - The gears turn very slowly on raises and promotions

title: Home Loan Specialist I
pros: The money was great and all of my coworkers were very friendly
cons: Everything from managers to policies and especially the non existent loan officers. Little room for growth and always piling work onto people with no extra pay. Will definitely take a toll on your mental and the work-life balance is awful

title: Great Company to Work For!
pros: Career Development Opportunities, Structure and Order, Stability, Diversity, Lots of Support and Flexibility Working Remotely, Corporate Values and Reputation, Open to Changes for making a Difference
cons: Out of my past employers, this has been, by far, the most rewarding career. I have zero cons working for PennyMac. You do not feel like a number at this company. Everyone feels appreciated.

title: Good money, but not sustainable for everyone
pros: As long as you hit your daily sales goals (e.g., getting the required minimum # of locks each day), then you can earn a lot of $ in this role.
cons: Be prepared that the Loan Officer role at PennyMac is truly a sales job, first and foremost. Management takes an aggressive approach and pushes everyone for more sales every day.

title: Great Place to Learn (High Volume)
pros: Opportunity to learn and grow. Working 6 months at PennyMac is like working 1.5 years elsewhere. High earning potential on portfolio customers.
